Fate/Nasuverse
lets play TL archive / lets-play-mandala-with-fallacies
fallacies 04-Dec-20 05:09 PM
Nemo gives that the Nautilus has docked at the Wandering Sea, and asks that Chaldea Staff quickly disembarks.
Mashu gives that the Storm Border is presently situated outside the base — roughly a 20 minute trip via the Nautilus, which separated forth from the main ship. (edited)
Nemo gives that if it's in the ocean, the Nautilus doesn't lose out against the Storm Border.
The Nautilus will no longer be serving as the command post within the Storm Border.
By the way, discussion mentions that Meuniere's handlename in online games is Mister M. Meuniere's surprised that Holmes knows of it, asking if Holmes is also an online game addict. Holmes gives that he's just an amateur, but doesn't deny that he's an addict.
8
Holmes gives that digging up secrets is to him alike to breathing, and this just now was just a demonstration. In response, Meuniere wonders if being a detective is for Holmes not so much a profession as it is a sexual fetish.
Gordorf concludes from this exchange that Holmes' mental faculties are mostly restored. (edited)
After an exchange wherein it's revealed that it slipped the minds of Nemo and Sion that Gordorf had before departure requested the construction of a "gorgeous" personal office, Nemo gives that he'll be returning to the Storm Border, on account that he cannot yet consider it a stable ship.
Therefore, he'll be revamping it such that it can operate in the absence of himself and the Shadow Border.
fallacies 04-Dec-20 05:37 PM
Holmes surmises that Nemo's intent would be to replace with real existences the "imaginary" (仮想, kasou; not to be confused with the 虚数, kyosuu, of "imaginary numbers") elements of the ship projected forth by the Aronnax Phantasm / Evidential Faculty (証憑機構, shouhyou kikou, "proof mechanism").
Ergo, an undertaking of materialization and stabilization. Nemo clarifies that the central control system of the Storm Border is presently reliant upon the hardware of the Shadow Border. Thus, he'll be replacing it as to remove this reliance.
This is as to relieve da Vinci of one of the functions she's burdened with.
In essence, da Vinci and Nemo will be supervising another revamp of the Storm Border for the time being.
Holmes gives that in the meantime, other base staff will be preparing for the incursion into the subsequent Lostbelt.
Holmes summarizes that Guda should be working to improve her abilities as a Master. Mashu will be tasked with adjusting the Ortenaus. Meanwhile, Holmes and Sion will be investigating and analyzing the Alien God.
Guda is surprised, asking if such a thing is now achievable.
Holmes gives that it'll strictly involve reviewing the materials presently at hand — inclusive of the data on the Animuspheres, brought over from the Antarctic Base.
He doesn't intend merely to look into Olgamarie, who is presently manifested as "the Alien God." Records pertaining to Marisbury will be reviewed as well.
Sion, meanwhile, will be tasked with efforts toward "the Alien God" that presently exists upon this Earth. (edited)
Prompted again by Gordorf as to whether such a thing is achievable, Sion gives with pride that Novum Chaldea is armed with the analytical capabilities of the TRISMEGISTOS II. (edited)
She gives that it can be thought of as something alike to the SHEBA installed at Chaldea.
The signature of the Alien God has presently departed the Atlantic Lostbelt, ceasing its advance as of the Lostbelt of South America.
Per the analysis of TRISMEGISTOS II, "so long as the environment's rendition to Tabula Rasa persists, no future wherein said signature departs from South America can be observed."
Ergo, for the time being, the Alien God should remain in South America.
Mashu and Guda wonder if this isn't on account of injuries sustained from Kirschtaria's final attack.
Holmes concurs with such a conclusion, saying that he sees no reason that the Alien God wouldn't otherwise launch an offensive against Novum Chaldea.
At Gordorf's reaction that this could be a good opportunity to engage the Alien God, da Vinci interrupts via communicator.
In her capacity as Novum Chaldea's Technologies Advisor, she gives that she firmly opposes such a course of action. (edited)
fallacies 04-Dec-20 06:09 PM
Even that the Alien God has hypothetically sustained injuries, per the observations recorded in Olympus, its existential scale (存在規模, sonzai kibo) and Saint Graph Output (霊基出力, reiki shutsuryoku) are of the 3rd Class Planet Level (三等惑星級, santou wakusei kyuu).
4
Per this same scaling, the mana output volume (魔力放出量, maryoku houshutsu ryou) of Beast I - Goetia would subsequently be of the 2nd Class Planet Level (二等惑星級).
da Vinci gives that even if the Storm Border were operating a maximum capacity, Chaldea doesn't presently carry the offensive capability to defeat something like that. (edited)
Mashu recalls that quite a number of conditions had to be met as to render the defeat of Goetia. So thinking, she wonders if the Black Barrel wouldn't be capable of rendering damage irrelevant of the opponent's existential scale.
Sion gives that though she takes pride in the Black Barrel. she thinks that it would be difficult.
To begin with, there's the matter that the opponent's Common Sense (常識, joushiki) is distinct from that of humanity.
The Black Barrel is restricted in its observation to the lifespans (生命寿命, seimei jyumyou) of existences within the comprehension of the humans of Earth. (edited)
Sion isn't certain that the Alien God would necessarily fall within these boundaries.
She gives that perhaps a chance exists, on account that verbal communication seems to be possible. However ... (edited)
fallacies 04-Dec-20 06:35 PM
She believes that the Accomplish Measure / Engraved Lifespan Measuring Pin (刻寿測定針, kokujyu sokutei chi) of the Black Barrel cannot determine the lifespan of the Alien God. (edited)
Holmes asks her if she has evidence to support her position.
To this, Sion replies that the Alien God seems capable of easily instantiating a gravitational field. To her thinking, what manifested resembled nothing so much as a black hole. On this account, Sion believes that there isn't any probability of victory. (edited)
An opponent that can casually iterate a black hole isn't something that Novum Chaldea can upon its current resources mount a response against. (edited)
At Gordorf's questioning, Sion clarifies that isn't specifically because the opponent can manifest a black that she regards them as strong.
She gives that it isn't actually difficult to escalate gravitational pull. All that's necessary is to render the compression of matter to higher densities. For example, if the Earth were compressed to the size of a fingertip, it would become as a black hole.
The principle isn't complicated, but such a thing is beyond current human technology, even that as a naturally occurring phenomena, it's observed with some frequency within the Universe. (edited)
But to casually instantiate a black hole — Holmes surmises that such a thing would be grounded in making use of the System of the Universe.
It's a phenomenon that within its scale exceeds the Common Sense of Man.
Sion gives that though it's regretful, humanity hasn't acquired the formulas as to assess and calculate the lifespans of Stars (恒星, kousei) and Planets (惑星, wakusei) so as to weaponize such per the Black Barrel. (edited)
The fact that the Black Barrel was able to counter the Gods of Olympus owed to an anticipation that they were the party responsible for the Atlantic Lostbelt; or more to the point, that to begin within, they existed as of the foundations of the History of Man. (edited)
Mashu asks again if by the above, Sion means that the Black Barrel wouldn't be able to overcome the Alien God. Sion replies in the affirmative, giving that an engagement against the Alien God would entail a battle of pure energy.
And being that the opponent has a planetary-scale energy output, defeating it would be impossible without acquiring a weapon likewise of the planetary scale.
Holmes asks da Vinci if something wasn't acquired of Kadoc before he was interred within the healing pod. da Vinci seems surprised, and then asks how he knew; if someone informed him. Meuniere gives that Holmes heard it from him — asking if that wasn't some sort of memory chip.
Meuniere guesses that it might contain intelligence shared amongst the Crypters.
da Vinci confirms that Kadoc seems to have made a copy of the data held by Kirschtaria. (edited)
She gives that per her perusal, most of it seems to comprise of records pertaining to the Atlantic Lostbelt. However, two points of interest turned up.
First, the invasion wasn't something initiated from the Trees of Fantasy. The rendition of the Earth to Tabula Rasa came first.
Second, the Tabula Rasa was initiated as of North America — from Area 51.
8
Thinking to conclude the discussion for now, Sion gives that per TRISMEGISTOS II's predictions, there isn't any sign that annihilation will manifest in the coming month.
-> Finally finished with the Prologue. Will move on to Chapter 1 after dinner, presumably.

General Type-Moon Discussion Thread 2: Unlimited Titles Works! (PLE...

fallacies 04-Dec-20 08:21 PM
Chapter 1:
"— the Moon observes." (edited)
"The third quarter of the Hour of the Ox."
"Indeed, as of a time suitable that men sink unto slumber; that beasts bate their breath; the spectacle of the Capital (京, miyako) wherein aberrations (魔, ma) writhe." (edited)
"Only the Moon observes."
"The land of wonders — Heian-Kyo."
fallacies 04-Dec-20 08:39 PM
"Alike to the Isle of Britain ... It is as a sphere of aberrations wherein living legends yet draw breath; alike to the distant antiquity, where rampant run the Mysteries potent and numerous — where warriors of incomparable strength do these hunt." (edited)
"For example —"
"Heian-Kyo, southern edge of the central district; Saiji (西寺, "western temple").
"There is here a temple freshly rebuilt, following a fire years prior."
"On the occasion of the reconstruction, the Minister of the Left did perhaps compose a celebratory poem, addressed to the steward of Saiji."
"If it is in regards to the Minister of the Left, a certain Fujiwara, he would be as a man deeply trusted even by his gracious majesty the Emperor; a personage that embodies the authority and the flourishing of the Capital." (edited)
"The spiritual efficacy of the Saiji, to which he bears En, is certain —"
"Or, it should've been so, but —"
"What existed was grudge." (edited)
"What existed was aberration."
"Within the boundaries of this pure temple —"
"were, alike to the word 'grudge' manifested to form, the likes of ayamono and mamono!"
Kintoki tells the monsters he's surrounded with to shut up.
He wonders at the fact that a great spirit of resentment would manifest within the bounds of the Capital.
fallacies 04-Dec-20 09:18 PM
The narration gives that this would be as a warrior of the Heian, who risks his own live to preserve this realm of men (人界, jinkai) as of the Aberrant Sphere (魔圏, maken). (edited)
Kintoki is somehow dissatisfied with his performance, giving that there's something missing — even that things weren't so when he was still in the mountains. (edited)
He feels that he doesn't measure up to the title of one amongst the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu.
Ergo, he won't be able to qualify as a Tenran Musha (天覧武者) / Master.
Looking at the Moon, he rhetorically asks of Tsuna — who he addresses as Aniki — what he would do.
Elsewhere, at a bridge over a canal — Ichijyou Modoribashi (一条大路) — Tsuna encounters a young girl. (edited)
Addressing him as if he were a guard, the girl asks what business he has with her.
He replies that rather, he's a warrior of the Genji, in the service of the Minister of the Left.
The girl speaks appreciatively, asking what she can do for a warrior such as Tsuna.
Tsuna replies that he would like for her to dance.
He gives that there's a beautiful Moon tonight, and that he would therefore like to see her dancing form, reflected in the river beneath. (edited)
At her confusion, he clarifies.
Addressing her as Ibaraki, he gives that she forgot to conceal her true form within her reflection.
It seems that Ibaraki has been defeated by Tsuna at some point in the past.
However, she's since coming to reside with Shuten grown in strength, and now seeks a rematch — giving that she's the one who shall one day unite the oni of the east and the west. (edited)
Observing that she apparently hasn't noticed that he's had his eyes closed since the beginning of the engagement, Tsuna gives that it won't be hereforth that she stands alongside Shuten as a chieftain amongst the oni, but rather "until now."
This angers Ibaraki, and she attempts to attack again. However, before she can really do anything, he cuts off her right arm. (edited)
7
5
3
Rather than finishing her off, though, he sheathes his sword. This confuses and angers her, but rather than responding to her threats, he observes that he doesn't sense the presence of a Servant.
He concludes that she therefore isn't as a Tenran Musha / Master. (edited)
Ibaraki is confused at the terminology he's using, uncertain as to what a Servant or a Master are.
Tsuna clarifies that being as she's without a Caster, she's just an oni.
Therefore, he sees no reason to persist in hostilities.
Ibaraki is angered. Though she doesn't understand what he's saying, she thinks that he's looking down on her. Thus, she attacks him with fire, using the brightness of the flames to quickly conceal her form. (edited)
He compliments her skill with escape. In response, Ibaraki vows that she'll repay him for cutting off her arm another day.
Once Ibaraki's departed, Tsuna addresses a "Caster." Medea Lily emerges from the shadows.
Medea observes that Ibaraki's mana capacity exceeds that of a normal human; but that it doesn't appear that she's a Servant. She wonders if Ibaraki is therefore a Phantasmal. (edited)
Tsuna replies that Ibaraki is an oni.
Having said that, he notes that it would appear that oni don't exist as of Medea's homeland. He says that he bears some En to Ibaraki.
Medea was reinforcing Tsuna's senses during the battle just now. Tsuna gives that it was on this account that he wasn't at all injured by Ibaraki.
Medea wonders what he's even saying. What she cast just now was nothing more than a temporary reinforcement of the senses; not a reinforcement of the body, or a protection against blades or fire.
She scolds him for engaging against a wild beast with his eyes closed.
Arrow 2:
Gordorf gives that a Singularity has instantiated.
da Vinci reports that 30 minutes prior, the instantiation of a new Singularity was observed.
As of the Earth rendered to Tabula Rasa, the only Singularities instantiated should be small in scale.
Rhetorically, she asks if Guda recalls Sion's explanation on small-scale Singularities — giving that disturbances of this like are fundamentally of no real issue even if left alone; that would only be of "slight" concern if the Earth were to revert to normal.
However, the Singularity observed this time around isn't like that. That is to say, it's a true and proper Singularity.
Mashu asks if she's referring to something akin to the seven Singularities created by Goetia. To this, Holmes gives that this is indeed the case.
Ergo, he says, even that the Earth has been rendered to Tabula Rasa, a Singularity "that predicates the collapse of the Human Order" has manifested.
Being that even as of an Earth wherein nothing exists, the black stagnation of a Singularity has been observed, the influence of such is vastly potent. (edited)
This, says Holmes, is quite unfortunately what TRISMEGISTOS II has calculated.
Guda wonders at the fact that Holmes refers to it as a "black stagnation." To this, da Vinci gives that it's something alike to a sunspot. In reply, Guda recalls that TRISMEGISTOS II previously indicated that in the current month, there shouldn't be any disasters.
Over the coms, Sion apologizes, saying that though she stated that there weren't any portents of annihilation, the instantiation of Singularities is beyond her observation.
Moving into the briefing proper, da Vinci gives that Guda's destination this time around is the 5th Year of Kankou (寛弘); the year AD 1008, in Heian Era Japan.
The location is the city of Kyoto — referred to within the era as the Miyako / Capital.
Holmes gives that it can alternatively be called as Heian-Kyo. (edited)
Mashu recalls that Heian-Kyo would be the origin of Raikou, Kintoki, Ibaraki, and Shuten; also of Murasaki and Sei Shounagon.
fallacies 04-Dec-20 10:37 PM
Kintoki takes the stage, giving that in the era at the destination, the warriors of the Genji were as of active duty, though it was slightly before the campaign against the Oni of Ooe. Thus, he gives that Guda can look forward to the appearance of his actual self.
da Vinci gives that if it were possible for Kintoki to be deployed, based on his personality, it would lend to better exchanging information with his living iteration. However ...
Kintoki asks da Vinci why she's making a face. However, before da Vinci can explain, Kotarou and Danzou appear, shocking Gordorf.
Kotarou gives that 30 minutes ago, he and Danzou both sensed the presence of Alter Ego Limbo.
Kintoki gives that he's heard about this Limbo guy. Based on the description, he thinks there's no mistake that the man is indeed Ashiya Douman.
He doesn't know that "Limbo" is in fact the Ashiya Douman he's familiar with, but it's indeed the case that the man was present in Heian-Kyo as of AD 1008.
However, he recalls that that was a bit prior to Ashiya's prosecution of villainous deeds.
Kotarou requests that he and Danzou be permitted the opportunity to travel unto the Singularity, and put an end to the tie of En that they bear to Ashiya Douman.
Gordorf gives that perhaps it's otherwise for a Subspecies or a small-scale Singularity, but as far as he recalls from perusing records of past missions, in rayshifting to a proper Singularity, approximately two agents can be dispatched.
fallacies 04-Dec-20 11:05 PM
da Vinci explains that though in the circumstance that a Servant accompanies their Master in their full capacity (完全同行, kanzen dougyou), they would be as a potent ally, particularly as energy provision from Chaldea would permit that they can remain manifest at all times.
However, many contracted Servants are incapable of maintaining sufficient synchronization (同期, douki) as to accompany their Master in a complete capacity.
Though it's been confirmed that certain Servants are borne of Skills that lend toward compatibility as to independently rayshift unto a Singularity, fundamentally, Servants are incapable of such. Ergo, deployment possible only alongside a Master to which they maintain synchronization. (edited)
Viability is furthermore dependent upon the nature of the Singularity; upon the extent to which a Singularity exerts enforcement against "that which is extraneous to history." (edited)
As of Singularities instantiated at key points in the proper History of Man, regulation is strictly enforced. Comparatively, as of small-scale Singularities that aren't positioned at such key points, enforcement is more relaxed. Therefore, in the latter circumstance, it isn't impossible that Heroic Spirits can accompany their Master in rayshift. (edited)
As of Subspecies Singularities, synchronization is likewise possible, per En; affinity; nature; and other such relational capacities.
da Vinci briefly recaps the circumstances involved at the inception of the Epic of Remnant missions.
Kintoki asks her if synchronization can be achieved this time around. To this, da Vinci replies that it's perhaps appropriate to describe the situation as impossible.
Per the calculations obtained from Paper Moon, there aren't any Servants easily capable of attaining synchronization.
However, here Sion and Nemo interject that after rerunning calculations with the Paper Moon, the system's somehow produced a different outcome. (edited)
Giving that it feels as if somebody's intentionally manipulated results as to issue an "invitation," Sion reports that Kotarou and Danzou are projected to be capable of maintaining sufficient synchronization as to accompany Guda's rayshift in their complete capacity. (edited)
However, Kintoki and the other Servants that originated of the Heian cannot be deployed. Neither can Servants of other eras and locales. (edited)
Kintoki isn't discouraged at the announcement, giving that he and the others will of course provide combat support in the capacity of temporary instantiations. He asks that Guda, Mashu, Kotarou, and Danzou assist him in protecting Raikou.
Further, as advice, he tells Guda to seek out the living iterations of himself and the other Heian natives, as they should be able to provide information as to the circumstances within the Singularity.
At the very least, Guda should be able to place her trust in himself and Raikou.
Protection of the realm of men is the obligation of the Genji.
If it's to such an end, Kintoki gives that Raikou should stop as nothing to assist.
Even that there's something she cannot comprehend, she'll forcibly comprehend it.
2
The discussion draws to a close. Holmes reminds Guda that there's a high probability that the Singularity is a trap of some sort laid forth by Limbo.
Despite that, this is a necessary misadventure. The probability that the Alien God will depart South America is quite low, and Limbo appears to be acting alone within the Singularity.
In other words, he won't have backup. That being the case, even that this is a trap, it's likewise an opportunity that cannot be overlooked.
Holmes gives that it would be ideal if Guda can manage to extract from Limbo intelligence pertaining to the Alien God.
The objective this time isn't merely to resolve the Singularity, says Holmes. Before the Alien God resumes activity, it's necessary to shave away at the combat potential of Chaldea's opposition. (edited)
Highly detailed map of Heian-era Kyoto.
Arrow 3:
The destination of the rayshift is the yard of a ruined building.
However, Guda finds herself alone.
She calls out to Mashu, Kotarou, and Danzou.
Danzou responds, but gives that there isn't any sign of Mashu and Kotarou.
She cannot locate their mana signatures.
Per the map installed within her memory, Danzou gives that she and Guda are currently in an uninhabited area. However, she cannot establish communications with Novum Chaldea.
Thus, she concludes that it's her and Guda alone that have arrived at their present location.
Guda gives that it must be the case that Limbo's interfered with the rayshift.
Danzou explains that subsequent to Moriarty's interference with rayshift during Subspecies Singularity Shinjuku, da Vinci established interference countermeasures for Servants deployed alongside Guda.
Generally, these would take the form of Skill engagement during rayshift.
Assassins are to engage Presence Concealment.
Sabers are to engage Thaumaturgical Resistance.
Casters are to engage Territory Creation.
Danzou gives that she and Kotarou both engaged the Skill designated per da Vinci's advisory.
However, immediately before completion of the rayshift, she sensed a strange oscillation of mana, akin to a Bounded Field. (edited)
Guda asks if that would be what interfered with Mashu and Kotarou's rayshift.
Danzou affirms this, giving that that at the time, she was able to slightly discern Kotarou's mana. (edited)
She offers the hypothesis that Kotarou might've elected to act as a decoy. Ergo, if it wasn't permissible that two Servants were deployed, perhaps he intended that at the very least, Danzou would arrive at destination alongside Guda. (edited)
To summarize, Danzou gives that at present time, the current whereabouts of Kotarou and Mashu cannot be determined. It could be that they've been returned to Chaldea; or that they're somewhere else in Heian-Kyo.
Guda gives that she and Danzou should act as circumstances permit — to establish communications with Chaldea; to acquire the support of parties local to the Singularity; and all the while, to seek out Mashu and Kotarou if possible.
Danzou agrees, giving that if communications are being suppressed by something alike to a Bounded Field, perhaps the suppression can be circumvented at the perimeter; or, if not, then at some manner of opening or flaw.
As the two of them prepare to move, Danzou abruptly picks up a mana signature nearby. She guesses that it's either an Assassin-Class Saint Graph, or some manner of youkai capable of killing its own presence.
fallacies 05-Dec-20 12:43 AM
The enemy is eliminated with slight injuries on Danzou's side. She repairs herself in short order.
Danzou gives that though her records on the subject are few, she doesn't recall that the spider youkai just now encountered existed as of the Warring States.
Guda gives that if these are the kai'i that exist as of the Heian Era, then perhaps it's preferable that combat is avoided.
Danzou replies that she's heard from da Vinci that Japan is in fact a land that brims of numerous ancient Mysteries.
If creatures akin to what was just now encountered could so easily appear in the midst of a city, it's possible that the World of Heian is as of an unimaginable sphere of aberration — even that it's only a few centuries earlier than her time.
Guda gives that if the warriors of the Heian are capable of contending against such monstrosities, their combat potential must be quite impressive.
To this, Danzou replies that it would be of great aid if they can ally themselves with such a warrior. However, privately, she's wary of the possibility that they might assume the role of opposition.
Arrow 4:
Danzou gives that she's committed to record the characteristics of the kai'i just now encountered. Though it would seem to bear a technique similar in nature to Presence Suppression, it's rather a capability distinct from such, rendered by way of mimicry.
That being the case, if she maximizes the output of her sensors, she should be able to detect them.
Though she isn't confident that this is a perfect solution, at the very least, it should maximize probability of detection.
A little ways along their path, Guda and Danzou encounter another kai'i. Danzou recommends that Guda run to a larger street while she holds the kai'i off — thinking that Guda might run across a guard, and thereby reach safety. However, Guda refuses to leave Danzou alone, saying that they should fight together. (edited)
fallacies 05-Dec-20 01:29 AM
After combat:
Guda remarks that the enemy just now looks familiar. Danzou agrees, giving that though she's absent of records pertaining to Shimousa, per her perusal of Chaldea's database, the black armor of the kai'i closely resembles something of the Warring States.
Guda gives that she can't be certain of it, but she feels that this is perhaps related to Limbo.
After a bit of silence, Danzou gives that more importantly, Guda should quickly advance to a larger street.
She has a bad feeling, she says; but corrects herself, giving that her I Ching Circuits are expressing a response of some inflection.
There's a strange noise, and Danzou announces that she's discerned a match to a prediction derived of her records. She judges that this would be as a unique mimicry that accompanies an alteration of terrain.
A spider kai'i manifests, launching at attack at Guda. Danzou places herself in front of the attack, and is injured in the process.
She calls for Guda to escape while she holds the spiders off.
Again, Guda refuses, saying that she refuses to abandon Danzou. (edited)
Here, Tsuna arrives, giving that Guda's sentiment in protecting her companion isn't poor.
Tsuna wonders if this girl targeted by the tsuchigumo isn't a child or a relative of a warrior house; or perhaps of noble blood.
Danzou calls out to Tsuna, giving that it isn't safe to go at these monsters alone. Rather, she asks that he calls for help.
To this, Tsuna asks if she implies that calling for help would result in the arrival of aid.
He finds amusement in the notion that somebody like him would call for assistance.
Guda tells him that it's no time to be putting up a nonchalant expression; that he should run away, as the monsters are advancing on him.
In response, Tsuna cuts down the tsuchigumo with a single slash of his blade.
Danzou is shocked, as her sensors weren't able to follow the path of the blade.
Looking to Guda, Tsuna observes that though she somewhat trembles in fear before the tsuchigumo, her back hasn't given out of her shock. Moreover, her eyes brim with life.
He notes that her attire rather stands out, being perhaps the light attire of a foreign land.
Assessing the mana that radiates of Guda and Danzou, Tsuna asks if they aren't a Tenran Musha / Master and a Heroic Spirit / Servant.
Chapter 1, complete.

fallacies 05-Dec-20 11:33 AM
Chapter 2:
Tsuna introduces himself to Guda and Danzou.
He gives that his name is Watanabe-no-Tsuna, an Udoneri (内舎人). As an explanation not within the game, this is a guard posting appointed to the Imperial Palace — roughly equivalent to the modern-day Secret Service.
Danzou is on her guard, privately thinking that her instincts are calling for her not to disengage from combat readiness, as this man could be a threat.
Tsuna calls for Caster to appear, and Medea emerges from the shadows.
Recognizing her, Guda speaks her name. In response, Medea gives that there's no mistaking it; "the one over there" should be the Servant.
Tsuna asks forgiveness, but gives that it's a life he just now saved, he'll be stealing it away, as of this Tenran Grail War, such a thing is unavoidable. (edited)
fallacies 05-Dec-20 12:13 PM
Such is the decree of Fujiwara-no-Michinaga (藤原道長), which is presently as alike to Imperial edict. (edited)
Addressing Guda as a Caster / a Spellcaster of a Foreign Land (異境の術者, ikyou no jutsusha), Tsuna gives that she should resign herself.
Guda is confused, asking what he means by "Caster."
Danzou places herself to protect Guda, which earns her praise from Tsuna.
Privately, however, Danzou once again notes that she cannot track the movement of Tsuna's blade.
She observes that his capabilities are a match for her, a Servant; that his techniques are extremely refined.
However, she's confused as to why he's attacking her and Guda; or why he's in the company of a Servant.
After several turns of combat:
Medea gives that Tsuna should remain on guard, as the capabilities of the enemy Servant are as yet unknown.
Mistaking Danzou for a warrior from out in the country, Tsuna gives that she seems quite fragile.
He asks if she's holding back — not going for the kill; not committing as to be seriously wounded.
He takes it that she's mocking him.
Danzou thinks that as a martial artist, Tsuna exceeds her reach. (edited)
Even that he's a living human, and not a Heroic Spirit, the strategy he's taken entails that he himself is the primary combatant.
Tsuna is making use of Medea solely in the capacity of support; not even making use of her a shield, even that she's a Heroic Spirit who cannot be harmed by physical means absent of Mystery.
1
Aloud, Danzou gives that she hasn't any reason to persist in hostilities, but observes that that doesn't seem to be the case on Tsuna's side.
To this, Tsuna replies that there's only but a single course by which a Tenran Musha can advance. Thus, he wonders what she's speaking of, so late into the game.
Tsuna gives that per regulation, the Miyako is presently as "our" designated field of battle.
Tsuna gives that further discussion is unnecessary.
Hearing him, Danzou concludes that there's no further space for negotiations.
As Tsuna prepares again to engage, Danzou tosses a smoke bomb, and calls for Guda to escape.
Once Guda and Danzou have departed, Medea gives that the smoke may be poisonous. Therefore, she thinks to neutralize potential poisons, and to ensure that Tsuna can breathe.
Tsuna contradicts her, giving that there is no poison.
When Medea warns him not to put himself at risk, Tsuna asks if she doesn't understand. That female warrior was looking to protect that girl. That being the case, at the very least, this smoke shouldn't be as a poison unto death.
However, he gives that their footsteps are by now far distant.
Medea gives that they should pursue, and Tsuna concurs.
Next arrow:
Danzou asks Guda to forgive her, but it's necessary that she carries her as she runs. (edited)
She gives that under normal circumstances, she would leap high into the air, but her mechanisms are for the time being not as of a properly functional state.
Observing that Danzou is injured, Guda gives that she can run by herself.
Danzou replies that she can't abide by that; that her injuries are not of a level that Guda should worry.
However, just as she says so, she makes a noise of surprise, and comes to a halt, giving that it appears that her Thousand-Leagues-in-an-Instant Faculty has been damaged as well.
Guda offers to help her walk.
As they hobble along, Danzou gives that when Tsuna reaches them, she'll sacrifice herself to make an opening for Guda's escape.
She asks that Guda carries with her her right arm, as it holds within it a communication device of specs superior to the one issued to Guda. With this, she gives that Guda should be able make contact with Novum Chaldea.
Guda repeats that she's not going to abandon Danzou; that it's too early to give up, as she still bears three Command Seals. (edited)
However, hear, a voice interrupts.
It's Kintoki. He gives that if they're in need of assistance, he'd be happy to help.
Seeing him, Guda's first reaction is to say, "Golden ..."
Hearing that, Kintoki gives that he doesn't know what it means, but that he likes the sound of the word.
Taking a closer look at them, he asks if they were attacked by tsuchigumo. However, before Danzou can respond, Tsuna arrives.
He gives that though indeed, they were attacked by tsuchigumo, Danzou's wounds come of his own blade.
Tsuna dismisses Kintoki, giving that he has no business with him here. His targets are the black-haired woman and the girl in her company.
To this, Kintoki asks if that's so.
He gives that being as it's so late into the night — the 3rd quarter of the Hour of the Ox — he was thinking that he should escort these young women home, as they shouldn't be wandering around.
Danzou wonders if Kintoki intends to protect them, even that their names and nature aren't known to him.
She observes that his decision was instantaneous, without any resignation.
Tsuna gives that as Yorimitsu-dono would be saddened by such a thing, he acts against his own intentions.
Kintoki gives that he doesn't comprehend why the man said to be the strongest warrior in the Heian would be rendering injury to women and children.
Women and children are to be protected, says Kintoki; not to be cut down with a blade.
Tsuna gives that what he's saying has a bit of logic to it.
However, neither of the women here are so young as to be regarded as "children."
Kintoki gives that maybe Tsuna doesn't see it, but the red haired girl is still just a brat.
3
fallacies 05-Dec-20 01:30 PM
She's of an age to still be afraid of the dark; to cry when she loses her way.
However, even so, Kintoki feels that she's the sort of lost child with the courage not to be frightened; who wouldn't cry; who would seek her own way home. (edited)
Tsuna gives that Kintoki is quite pleasant; but being as this is the Tenran Grail War, he should stand down.
Kintoki refuses, and Tsuna orders him again to stand down.
Again, Kintoki refuses.
Tsuna: "In that case, I'll cut you down!"
fallacies 05-Dec-20 01:57 PM
After combat: Tsuna gives to Medea that should disperse her bone shikigami, as they're getting in the way.
Medea objects, but Tsuna gives that they're of no use against Kintoki.
Tsuna gives that while this match against Kintoki has ben enjoyable, he isn't so much of an idiot as to waste his time fighting against one amongst the Four Heavenly Kings who hasn't obtained qualification as a Tenran Musha.
There are two Casters present, says Tsuna. Thus, he'll be claiming the head of one of them.
Danzou notices that Tsuna's killing intent isn't directed at Kintoki or herself. She concludes therefore that he's aiming to kill Guda.
Guda calls for Danzou to astralize.
Tsuna is surprised that Danzou's disappeared, but quickly realizes that it's the astralization of a Heroic Spirit.
He calls to Medea, who responds that Danzou is indeed a Servant.
Tsuna backs away from Guda, concluding that she isn't a target. (edited)
Rather than that his eyes were deceived, he gives that perhaps his mistake was on account that he's still a greenhorn. (edited)
Realizing his misapprehension, Medea apologizes, giving that she wasn't clear with her words. It's the woman with the long black hair whose form is now concealed that's the Servant; not the girl with the red hair. (edited)
Further, Medea gives that the Saint Graph of the black-haired woman is likely not of the Caster Class.
She believes that Danzou is an Assassin.
Tsuna is confused, asking if Servants outside of the Caster Class exist.
Tsuna apologizes, giving that it was he who jumped to conclusions.
He gives that Guda is clad in attire unseen in the Miyako; and that she wields some manner of youjutsu (妖術). (edited)
He wasn't able to turn his thinking around to properly assess the situation. Therefore, the present circumstances are a result of his immaturity.
Kintoki, meanwhile, is confused that Danzou suddenly vanished.
Tsuna gives to Kintoki that he's withdrawing, as his objective is solely to claim the heads of Casters.
He tells Kintoki to escort Guda where he wishes.
However, apparently thinking that Kintoki is qualified as a Tenran Musha, Tsuna gives that the next they meet, he might be claiming Kintoki's left hand. (edited)
It's best that nothing happens, says Tsuna; but if a crest surfaces on the back of Kintoki's hand —
Kintoki still isn't certain as to what Tsuna is suggesting.
Tsuna completes his sentence: "I'll cut it off." (edited)
Hearing this, Kintoki laughs, giving that he'll enjoy a serious match against Tsuna.
So saying, Tsuna gives to Medea that they're leaving.
Giving a sigh of relief after Tsuna departs, Kintoki praises Guda, giving that she did well to keep her neck and limbs intact in a match against "that" Watanabe-no-Tsuna. (edited)
Guda thanks Kintoki, giving that he's reliable as always, even in the Heian Era.
Kintoki isn't certain as to what she's talking about.
Guda gives that it's as if he were a "seigi no mikata." Kintoki doesn't grasp what "seigi" is. (edited)
Danzou rematerializes, and Kintoki is shocked, incredulous that she was able even to entirely conceal her presence.
Answering Kintoki's question — what a "seigi no mikata" is — Danzou gives that it's a righteous person who renders justice.
Kintoki gives that he isn't entirely certain what "righteousness" would refer to.
He was merely lending a hand to a lost child. It isn't anything to make a big deal about. (edited)
Offhand, he gives that the Miyako is currently in the midst of the Tenran Grail War.
Chapter 3:
fallacies 05-Dec-20 02:43 PM
An unknown speaker gives that this is a once-in-a-millennium opportunity — (edited)
a ritual devised by Abe-no-Seimei; a Grand Ritual unseen in the east or the west in any era. (edited)
Its designation is the Tenran Grail War.
By the decree of Fujiwara-no-Michinaga, the Minister of the Left, and per the preparations of "we," the Ministry of Onmyou, the speaker gives that this is a ritual to should be brought to completion. (edited)
From foreign lands and otherworlds, seven Casters are to be called forth. To serve as their Masters, seven mighty warriors shall be appointed.
Of the seven pairs, the partnership that attains victory shall be granted any manner of wish. (edited)
This would be a matter guaranteed per the word of the Minister of the Left. (edited)
By committing the lives of the Casters, the protections of the Miyako shall be reinforced, rendering that the Peace — the Heian (平安, lit. "peace") — shall endure for yet another millennium.
The speaker gives that such was recorded as of the writings of Abe-no-Seimei.
Fujiwara-no-Michinaga takes the stage, asking the speaker to confirm that it would be these foreign jutsusha who would be committing their lives.
The speaker affirms this. Michinaga replies that it would be foolish to consume the lives of the warriors that protect the Miyako.
However, if it's lives of those come of foreign lands and otherworlds, he has no objection.
That being the case, he approves of the plan — giving that the unknown speaker should take his approval as being backed by the word of the Emperor.
He laughs, giving that Heian-Kyo shall by such be known in subsequent eras as the Thousand-Year Capital. (edited)
The narration gives that such an event took place several days prior.
In the present:
Guda exclaims: "A Grail War!?"
Kintoki gives that "as expected," Guda would of course know about the Grail War. Guda isn't certain what he means by that.
Kintoki is surprised that Danzou's wounds are healed. At his exclamation, Danzou replies that it's thanks to her Master's restorative spells and her own self-regeneration.
Kintoki gives that the Tenran Grail War is an ongoing ritual presently pursued by the Interior. Roughly seven days have passed since its initiation. Presently of the seven Heroic Spirits summoned forth, two have been eliminated.
The Tenran Musha partnered with them were members of the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu. (edited)
Danzou asks if these would be Usui Sadamitsu and Urabe-no-Suetake. (edited)
Kintoki answers in the affirmative, giving that their injuries seem not to be serious, and that they've presumably withdrawn to the hot springs near Arima as to nurse their wounds. (edited)
The one who eliminated their Heroic Spirits was Tsuna.
fallacies 05-Dec-20 03:28 PM
Kintoki gives that their Daishou — Minamoto-no-Yorimitsu, the current head of the Genji — names Tsuna a manifestation of the greatest possible strength within the means of the flesh of man; the strongest warrior in the Realm of Man (人界, jinkai).
Kintoki gives that he himself isn't so great at dealing with opponents that aren't kai'i. (edited)
Guda repeats the title, "the strongest warrior in the Realm of Man." Hearing her, Kintoki gives that if one doesn't restrict consideration to humans, Tsuna's standing might change a bit. Even so, it isn't for nothing that he's called the strongest.
Kintoki gives that if things advance as they have, Tsuna should emerge as the victor of the War.
Guda concludes that the Grail War itself may be the trap that Limbo's prepared for Chaldea.
Danzou gives that though this "Tenran Grail War" sounds to be a subspecies Grail War, Kintoki's explanation gives no mention of a Grail.
To her view, circumstances deviate far too much from the standard.
Kintoki is confused as to what this talk of "Limbo" would refer to.
Danzou answers that Caster Limbo — alternatively, Alter-Ego Limbo — is a deviant monk who embodies evil itself.
After a bit of explanation, Kintoki gives that he understands the situation; that Guda and Danzou are here in pursuit of a villain. (edited)
Danzou gives that he's called as Alter-Ego Limbo. His true identity, she poses, is presumably as the Onmyouji, Ashiya Douman.
She gives that the year of Ashiya Douman's death is as of the History of Man not entirely clear.
However, as of AD 1008 — as of the Miyako in the 5th year of Kankou — it wouldn't be incredible that Ashiya Douman is as yet alive.
Though she cannot conclude anything about the relationship between the still-living Ashiya Douman and Alter-Ego Limbo, the inception of the Tenran Grail War is suspicious.
Guda points out that per Kintoki's explanation, the ritual was devised by Abe-no-Seimei.
Kintoki gives that there's room for doubt in the premise that Abe-no-Seimei was the one who devised the Grail War.
Danzou notes it's given that Seimei died in the 2nd year of Kankou — three years prior.
Kintoki laughs, asking if that's indeed what's recorded; giving that though Seimei-dono appears quite young, he's actually an old man. (edited)
He gives that being as a young-looking old man is quite implausible, it wouldn't be strange if in subsequent eras, his activities toward the end of his life were attributed to a Seimei the 2nd or 3rd. (edited)
But to Kintoki's knowledge, Seimei was present until maybe a month ago, when he abruptly vanished. Looking into it, the Interior discovered documentation for the Grand Ritual of the Tenran Grail War.
Hearing of the circumstances of the ritual, the Minister of the Left was overjoyed at the prospect of obtaining a Thousand-Year Miyako for the very low price of the lives of jutsusha from foreign lands and otherworlds.
Furthermore, says Kintoki, the who asserted control of the Ministry of Onmyou in the absence of Abe-no-Seimei was none other than Ashiya Douman.
In any case, after hearing out the explanation, Kintoki reveals that he himself is amongst the Tenran Musha — revealing beneath the gauntlet on his left hand a set of Command Seals.
He asks Guda if she won't be as his Servant.
Arrow 2:
There are strange noises that sound like flesh and blood being squished.
An unknown speaker expresses his pleasure.
"Nnnnnnn — what doesn't exist even as of the numerous 'what ifs' of the original History of Man; the impossible ritual — the Tenran Grail War."
Clearly, it's Limbo.
He gives that this is fruit of the independent research he's pursued since his manifestation in the capacity of an Apostle of the Alien God.
"Within mine grasp; mine Subspecies Adjacent Reality ..."
He invites Chaldea to have a taste of the plot he's contrived.
Arrow 3: (edited)
Kintoki apologizes, giving that he misunderstood.
He thought that Guda was herself a Heroic Spirit, and didn't expect that Danzou was Guda's Servant. Further, he's surprised that Danzou seems to be a scout rather than a spellcaster. (edited)
Danzou is a bit taken aback, giving that she thought Kintoki would've picked it up from the dialogue with Tsuna.
Kintoki realizes finally that it was on account of comprehending that Guda wasn't a Caster that Tsuna announced his withdrawal.
It dawns on him that Guda and Danzou have nothing to do with the Tenran Grail War.
After a bit more explanation, Kintoki roughly comprehends that Guda is in fact a visitor from the distant future. (edited)
He remarks that though it's complicated, he believes Guda, giving that she hasn't the look of a liar. (edited)
Also, he remarks that it seems that his instinct was on the mark — that Guda is indeed a lost child.
He gives that he'll see her home to Chaldea with all her limbs intact. (edited)
However, before advancing elsewhere, he gives that he's in the same boat as her, with nowhere to return to.
Danzou is confused, asking what he means, given that he's one amongst the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu, and one amongst the protectors of the Miyako.
She gives that he should have a mansion or something; or if not, perhaps he lives with his master, Raikou.
Kintoki gives that on account of various circumstances, it's a bit difficult for him to show his face at Raikou's at present.
To put it more simply, he's run away from home.
There's a lull in the conversation after Kintoki roughly explains his situation. Here, Danzou picks up the sound of an ox carriage in the distance.
Kintoki gives that it's presumably the carriage of some lord or other, telling Danzou and Guda not to stand in its path. (edited)
However, the carriage comes to a stop in front of them.
It's Sei Shounagon, though she refers to herself as Seiko. (edited)
She's apparently an acquaintance of Kintoki. The two of them make a bit of small talk.
Guda and Danzou are surprised that she's turned up. At their discussion of who Sei Shounagon, Sei observes that they seem to be quite familiar with her, and asks if she's met them before. She gives that she doesn't recall having encountered when she was still in the palace. (edited)
Guda wonders privately as to Sei's age, as she appears quite young. However, Kintoki gives that the subject of her name and age are taboo. (edited)
He says that though she appears youthful, her actual age is —
Before he can say anything, Sei whaps him.
By the way, Sei was born somewhere around AD 966. This would make her about 42 in AD 1008.
4
Kintoki gives that he was in her care when he was still a brat. At this, Danzou notes privately that per the accounts of Kintoki's life popular in the Edo period, Kintoki should've been born somewhat earlier than Sei Shounagon. However, it would seem that reality somewhat differs, and Sei is in fact older than Kintoki.
She observes that this may be another case wherein the Heroic Spirit is incongruent to their representation in the minds of men. (edited)
fallacies 05-Dec-20 05:05 PM
Hearing that Kintoki's run away from home, Sei's mind jumps to a number of conclusions relating to the circumstances of the Genji. However, Kintoki gives that it's not what she thinks.
However, he doesn't clarify, and merely gives that for certain reasons, he's looking for a place to stay the night.
Sei invites them to come with her, saying that she knows a place that they can stay at. Owing that Danzou's been injured several times this evening, Guda gives that she should accompany Sei in the carriage, while Guda and Kintoki walk alongside. Danzou doesn't like that she isn't at Guda's side, but relents. (edited)
Sei remarks that with a warrior of the Genji to guard the carriage, the monsters that lurk the streets of the Miyako at night should be somewhat deterred.
At this, Danzou privately notes that in later years, Sei's brother, Kiyohara-no-Munenobu (清原致信) was said to be killed by none other than the Genji.
However, she doesn't think it would be appropriate to mention such a thing.
Sei continues speaking, giving that while under normal circumstances, the larger streets are safe at night, these past few days, something's changed.
Hearing her say this, Kintoki becomes contemplative, remarking, "the past few days, huh?"
But as he says this, a kai'i appears directly ahead.
Kintoki says that he's on it, but he asks that Danzou sits out the current engagement.
fallacies 05-Dec-20 05:32 PM
Arrow 4: (edited)
Concluding the battle, Kintoki remarks that there's something he doesn't about the fight just now.
When Guda asks him to elaborate however, he can't seem to properly explain.
After a short while, Sei announces that they've arrived. (edited)
Danzou asks where they are. To this, Sei asks them if they're familiar with Genji Monogatari — currently, the talk of the town.
This would be the home of the author, Murasaki Shikibu.
Danzou asks if Sei is acquainted with Murasaki. To this, Sei replies that they've never met.
Sei replies that in her imagination, Murasaki must be a graceful maiden with beautiful black hair. That being the case, she's definitely the sort of girl-child who wouldn't ignore a person in need. (edited)
Privately, Kintoki thinks that Murasaki shouldn't be of such an age that referring to her as a girl-child is appropriate.
As if she can tell what Kintoki is thinking, Sei whaps him.
Guda remarks that it's maybe a bit too much to ask somebody who's never met them before to take them in for the night.
To this, Sei remarks that they should tell Murasaki that the Kusa no Iori (草の庵, "the hermitage of grass") sends its regards. (edited)
As Sei makes to leave to her own home, Danzou gives that it's dangerous for her to travel with nothing but a servant and an ox carriage to keep her safe.
However, Kintoki contradicts her, giving that Sei's ox carriage should be furnished with a number of defensive shikigami.
Furthermore, the larger streets of the Miyako are protected by the Bounded Fields of the Ministry of Onmyou.
Small-scale kai'i should be of no issue for the shikigami of Sei's carriage.
Guda is surprised to hear this, remarking that the security measures of the Heian Era are quite impressive. (edited)
Sei gives that personally, she would like it if she didn't have to rely on onmyouji for protection.
Hearing Kintoki's explanation, Danzou asks him why the shikigami of the carriage didn't engage in the battle just now. Ergo, wasn't it just Kintoki that fought off the kai'i?
Kintoki gives that to repay Sei's kindness, he allowed that she could spectate as he fought the monsters.
Sei is appreciative, but gives that he really shouldn't be risking his life doing dangerous things. It isn't to her liking that young people end up dying.
Sei departs, and the party approaches Murasaki.
Murasaki isn't quite certain what to make of the situation. To begin with, she doesn't know who this 'Seiko' person is.
She recognizes Kintoki however, having seen him multiple times in the mansion of Fujiwara-no-Michinaga.
Kintoki thought that he'd never met her before, and apologizes.
Murasaki wonders why Kintoki-sama would be visiting her house so late at night.
She wonders if she's committed some grave error in the palace.
To calm her down, Kintoki gives that she has nothing to worry about — addressing her as Murasaki Shikibu, rather than her personal name, Fujiwara Kaoruko. (edited)
Hearing the invocation of her pen-name, Murasaki is embarassed.
Kintoki explains that he isn't here on account of any trespass on her part. Unlike Tsuna, he isn't the sort to serve as a police inspector (検非違使, kebiishi, lit. "officer that scrutinizes violations of law"; i.e. the police). Rather, he has a favor to ask of her. (edited)
At Kintoki's comment, Danzou is surprised, giving that, come to think of it, Tsuna was indeed dressed in the uniform of a police inspector.
However, per the records in her recollection, Watanabe-no-Tsuna never served in the capacity of a police inspector.
Kintoki is surprised, giving that it seems that not everything in the present ends up being preserved.
fallacies 05-Dec-20 06:28 PM
He gives that Tsuna isn't the same as a typical police inspector. Rather, being as his duty entailed the protection of the Miyako, he felt that it was appropriate to acquaint himself with the work of police inspectors, and so suborned himself to the Ministry of Police. (edited)
Murasaki finds it difficult to follow the conversation.
At her confusion, Guda tells her that the Kusa no Iori sends its regards.
Hearing the name "Kusa no Iori," Murasaki surmises that it was Sei Shounagon who entrusted Kintoki and company to her care.
Murasaki gives that she'll furnish the party with rooms. Being as there are females present in the company, she'll provide two rooms. (edited)
To this, Danzou objects, giving that so as to easily protect her Master, she would like that Murasaki provides a shared room. (edited)
Guda asks Kintoki if he's alright with that. Thinking on it a bit, he concludes that this is best option considering the circumstances, and gives aloud that he agrees.
Murasaki asks them if they're certain. To this, Danzou answers in the affirmative, and tells her not to worry.
Murasaki remarks offhand that Danzou's attire is indeed quite daring. Danzou doesn't understand the implication.
Once they're settled into their room, Danzou asks that Guda retire for the night, as they've been in combat since arriving in the city. Danzou gives that she herself will work to restore her body as possible.
Guda gives that Danzou should take her rest as well. To this, Danzou gives that she should be restored to full functionality by morning.
Thereon, they should pursue their planned itinerary.
fallacies 05-Dec-20 07:15 PM
When asked why it is that he doesn't want to meet Raikou, he gives that something's been off about her since the inception of the Tenran Grail War.
She's been holed up at the back of her mansion the entire time.
Privately, he thinks that perhaps she was selected as one amongst the Tenran Musha.
Here, the conversation is interrupted by the activation of the communicator.
It's Mashu and Kotarou. (edited)
Initially thinking that it's an evil spirit of some sort, Kintoki quickly corrects himself, surmising that this is a manner of youjutsu or onmyoudou alike to something he's seen before. (edited)
Danzou is shocked, asking if visual communications technology exists in the Heian Period. However, suppressing her curiosity, she gives that just now, she successfully established communications with Novum Chaldea. (edited)
fallacies 05-Dec-20 07:41 PM
Guda asks Mashu and Kotarou if their rayshift ended up failing.
Asked by Danzou if there was interference in their rayshift, Kotarou answers in the affirmative, giving that per Sion's calculations, there's a high probability that that's the case.
Mashu and Kotarou never departed from Novum Chaldea. Kotarou gives that when they attempted a rayshift the second time around, it likewise failed.
Mashu gives that as all established countermeasures were nullified, the interference this time around was likely of a higher order. A solution has yet to be devised.
Guda: "O no re, Li m bo"
6
da Vinci gives that to the party that interfered, Guda and Danzou are presumably as special existences — "invited guests," perhaps. Danzou turns the logic around, giving instead that perhaps all other Heroic Spirits or personages are deemed as uninvited.
Danzou wonders as to the party responsible, but quickly realizes that it's a foolish question; Guda answers that it's presumably Alter-Ego Limbo.
Kintoki asks to confirm that Mashu and Kotarou would be the two individuals that Guda intended to search for; and that they're safely at home.
When Guda answers in the affirmative, he gives that he's relieved that it wasn't necessary to set out on a search, given the present state of the Miyako.
After it's settled that with that out of the way, Danzou concludes that their only remaining objective is to resolve the Singularity.
Introductions are made to Kintoki. Initially, he wonders if da Vinci is a sage or a tengu, but after a bit of explanation, he concludes that she's something like a gifted child; a child genius. Also, he feels that Holmes gives of a presence alike to Abe-no-Seimei. (edited)
After some discussion, Holmes concludes that Limbo's objective was to begin with not a matter of "achieving victory," or anything of the sort. He targeted Guda and Danzo in essence so as to corner them on his home turf, and to thereon harass them — depriving them of backup.
Holmes gives that this isn't so much a strategy as a pursuit of hobby.
He suspected that there could've been a collaborator lurking behind the scenes, but at present he's willing to posit that Limbo was indeed working alone. (edited)
Noting that Holmes is moving forward to posit a hypothesis, Guda wonders if he isn't still recovering from Zeus' lightning.
5
da Vinci gives that when perusing Mashu's rayshift observation log, she was surprised to find a string of text inexplicably mixed into the data. (edited)
Danzou asks what the text was. To this, Mashu replies, "D O M A N." (edited)
5
fallacies 05-Dec-20 08:25 PM
After the circumstances of the Tenran Grail War are explained, da Vinci surmises on hearing that only Casters are summonable that this is a further downsizing of the War for the Holy Grail, which itself is derivative of the Combat Ritual — the Summoning of the Heroic Spirits.
Such a thing is in her opinion not even worth the use of an omnipotent Holy Grail. (edited)
Holmes poses that perhaps it isn't the case that a Wish-Granting Engine is being employed. But if so, he gives, isn't it possible that whatever it is that anchors the Grail War is intended only to serve a single function? (edited)
Holmes pushes the hypothesis that the utility of this device might be as to change the World.
Guda asks Holmes if he has the evidence to support such a conclusion.
In response, Holmes asks that Guda recall the circumstances of Shimousa.
By the sacrifice of multiple Heroic Spirits and a vast number of humans, a Grand Ritual rendered that the country of Shimousa would become as a Subspecies Adjacent Reality (亜種並行世界, ashu heikou sekai) — or rather, a Subspecies Lostbelt (亜種の異聞帯, ashu no ibuntai). (edited)
da Vinci poses that as of Shimousa, the Castle of Onri Edo (厭離穢土城, onri edo jyou) was an existence analogous to the Trees of Fantasy that exist as of the Lostbelts. (edited)
Or, to rephrase, the Castle itself could perhaps be taken as a Subspecies Tree of Fantasy (亜種空想樹, ashu kuusou ki). (edited)
da Vinci believes that by way of the ritual of the Tenran Grail War, Limbo intends to replicate such a thing — to thereby instantiate a Lostbelt. However, she isn't certain as to his motive.
Holmes wonders if it isn't to the end of bringing about the descent of the Alien God to Heian Era Japan.
Here, Guda points out that the Alien God is already descended.
Holmes gives that as Guda says, being that the Alien God has already attained manifestation, a vessel for the purpose of descent should no longer be necessary.
He starts saying, "but if there is a vessel held in reserve ..." — but cuts himself off, giving that an existence of such transcendental scake shouldn't require any such thing.
fallacies 05-Dec-20 08:57 PM
da Vinci gives that even if the ritual in question serves only a single function, stabilizing the mana source for such a large-scale spell protocol is difficult. That being the case, utilizing only Caster-Class Saint Graphs in the capacity of an energy supply would to her thinking unduly bias / destabilize things — potentially to such an extent that failures crop up within the spell protocol. (edited)
She can't help but wonder if this isn't all just some manner of harassment. (edited)
As she muses on this, static manifests in the display.
Holmes wonders if this is on account that their communication has been detected — or if, perhaps, pursuing this chain of logic would lead to some conclusion inconvenient to the culprit. (edited)
Before communications cut out, Holmes gives that Guda has to halt the ritual. If all manifested Servants are eliminated, a Subspecies Tree of Fantasy may be instantiated.
If such a thing comes to pass, Heian-Kyo will become as simultaneously a Singularity and a Lostbelt.
Chapter 4:
Somewhere, Sei is discussing Genji Monogatari with an unseen figure, whose speech is accompanied by a hissing noise. (edited)
She gives that Genji Monogatari is as yet incomplete. Kaoruko is still in the midst of her journey.
That being the case, she doesn't want it to end just yet. She hopes to see it unto its conclusion.
The unknown voice gives that there's nothing to worry about. (edited)
The telling of tales is alike to the conquest of a journey of dreams — something akin to the continuous fabrication of one's own world. (edited)
The speaker believes that Murasaki will pursue this unto completion.
Sei gives that the speaker seems quite familiar with such things.
To this, the speaker gives that that's a matter of course, for they count amongst their friends a number of great poets. (edited)
Heian-Kyo during the daytime.
The narration gives that amongst the aberrations manifest as of the streets of the Miyako, there exists a monster of steel, which under the moonlight wanders the deserted streets. (edited)
The people of the Miyako regard it as man-eating monstrosity.
It's said that of the people consumed, not even a shred is ever again seen.
The above account is given as an excerpt from a diary.
At Murasaki's home, Guda and Danzou are discussing rumors of this monsters.
Danzou gives that she's yet to find anyone who has actually seen the monster, but finds the rumors of such notable, as it seems that the tales of such a thing only began to spread several days earlier. (edited)
Guda gives that this would match up with the inception of the Tenran Grail War.
Kintoki remarks that if it's the case that the rumors refer to an armor of steel, that would really be something. He gives that the use of steel in the forging of weapons is a convention established as of distant antiquity — observed even in the Age of Gods, by Susanoo-no-Mikoto (素戔嗚尊). (edited)
The blade that cut down the Orochi — now consecrated in a shrine somewhere — is likewise said to be forged of steel. (edited)
fallacies 05-Dec-20 09:57 PM
Giving that he's never heard of an armor of steel even from the people of Hakuta (博多, a port city in Kyuushu), it's likely that such a thing doesn't exist upon the continent — much less as of the Hi no Moto (日の本, lit. "the origin of the Sun"; ergo, Japan). (edited)
He wonders if it isn't the Settsu no Oo-gusoku.
Guda asks if Kintoki is referring to the Golden Huge Bear-Go.
After a bit of confusion, Kintoki gives that Oo-gusoku would be a secret amongst secrets for the Genji; and so, he requests that Guda doesn't inquire about it.
Danzou comments that an armor of steel sounds impossible. Even centuries later, in her own time, steel armors were exceedingly rare, and she' doesn't know that such a thing was ever created in Japan.
If one exists, it was likely imported by ship.
Kintoki asks if it would be from the continent. To this, Danzou replies that it would come by way of the Nanban (南蛮, lit. "southern barbarians," in reference to European traders).
Kintoki tries to piece together what she means, and guesses that it's in reference to barbarians from the south. To this, Danzou gives that whereas that would be the literal meaning of the name, it actually refers to people from nations in the distant west.
Guda jokes that it could be called as "the Reverse of the World," but notes that that probably makes it more difficult to comprehend.
fallacies 05-Dec-20 10:19 PM
As Guda begins her meal. Kintoki asks her about the Tenran Grail War, giving that based on what he heard of Chaldea's discussion last night, he agrees that there's definitely something wrong with the ritual.
He asks if he grasped it correctly that the important people at Guda's organization ordered that she halt the ritual.
When Guda answers in the affirmative, he gives that he concurs. There isn't, he thinks, any proper meaning in setting up the defenders of the nation to battle one another. (edited)
fallacies 05-Dec-20 10:29 PM
There's a brief interlude in which it turns out that Kintoki intentionally averts his gaze from Danzou on account of the way she dresses. However, misapprehending the reason for his behavior, Danzou physically approaches him, giving that if there's some issue with her performance, she wishes for him to inform her.
As Guda finishes eating, Kintoki asks again of the culprit behind the Tenran Grail War. (edited)
Guda gives that his name is Ashiya Douman, but that he isn't necessarily the Ashiya Douman of the current era.
Kintoki gives that Ashiya Douman would be the onmyouji that's taken over the Ministry of Onmyou in Abe-no-Seimei's absence.
Further, there are rumors that the Minister of the Left had the intention of switching out Abe-no-Seimei for Ashiya Douman.
Addressing Danzou, Kintoki asks if she would recognize Limbo if she met him.
Danzou affirms this, giving that she indeed bears a tie of En with Limbo. (edited)
If she were to gaze upon him, she believes she can determine whether or not the Ashiya Douman of the current era is the same existence as Alter-Ego Limbo.
To this, Guda gives that their first order of business would therefore be to determine whether or not Ashiya Douman and Limbo are one and the same.
Kintoki gives that being as the man presently leads the onmyouji of the Ministry of Onmyou in prosecuting a Grand Ritual to the end of preserving the nation, there's no mistake that he would be somewhere within the Miyako.
Certainly, he would situate himself in the most secure location. (edited)
Ergo, Kintoki believes that Ashiya Douman is presently within the Imperial Palace. (edited)
Danzou gives that at the far end of the Avenue of Suzaku (朱雀), she glimpsed a facility partially rebuilt, presumably per the aftermath of a fire. The Bounded Field deployed over the site far exceeds that used to protect the atelier of a first rate magus — perhaps on par with a Temple. (edited)
Guda gives that it doesn't seem as if infiltrating the site is possible.
In that case, how about launching a head-on assault?
At this point, Murasaki enters the room, asking the party if they would like more rice.
Kintoki makes a request of her, asking if there isn't some way that she can get them into the Imperial Palace. (edited)
Getting on his knees, he performs a dogeza, giving that no matter what, he desires to get a glimpse of Ashiya Douman.
After some convincing, Murasaki agrees to see if she can't convince the Minister of the Left to permit such a thing. (edited)
In the middle of the night, Murasaki visits Guda's quarters, giving that the Minister of the Left has given permission for a visitation. (edited)
It'll only be for a brief while at dawn, but Kintoki and company will be permitted to enter the Imperial Palace. (edited)
By ox carriage, the party departs to the Palace in Murasaki's company. However, along the way, they're attacked by kai'i.
fallacies 06-Dec-20 12:32 AM
https://forums.spacebattles.com/threads/general-type-moon-discussion-thread-2-unlimited-titles-works-please-read-the-threadmarks.795493/post-72411623
General Type-Moon Discussion Thread 2: Unlimited Titles Works! (PLE...
It's like Moriarty getting worried that Holmes might be evil. People who set themselves up to be The Villain to The Hero get worried when their hero doesn't show up, it's just logical. As a great man once said “To pull off the greatest crime of the century one would want the greatest challenge...
fallacies 06-Dec-20 12:31 PM
Arrow 2:
It's now daylight. Murasaki praises the party for helping to fend off attacks on the ox carriage.
There were quite a number of kai'i, and Guda asks Murasaki if there's usually this many.
Murasaki gives that per her knowledge, keshou (化生, another term for youkai and 怪異, kai'i, per Monogatari) appear more frequently between dusk and dawn, in the hours when the sun is absent.
Kintoki affirms this, giving that under the sun, there's no need to worry.
Danzou remarks her surprise that Heian-Kyo would be such a City of Aberrations (魔都, mato); so deeply into the midst of the Sphere of Aberrations (魔圏, maken). (edited)
Murasaki replies that even so, the Miyako is the city that most flourishes in all the Hi no Moto. There isn't another city that its exceeds it in scale — not even Hakata Otsu, which serves as a port to the continent.
Even so, gives Kintoki, kai'i proliferate.
Since the time of the great Shogun, Sakanoue-no-Tamuramaro (坂上田村麻呂), it's been by the efforts of countless warriors — by the bloodshed of many, both of allies and enemies — that Heian-Kyo has arrived at its present state of glory.
And if there are victors, so too are there the defeated. (edited)
Those who lost; who escaped in defeat; who died; who withdrew to the country.
Those who unto the last generation of their bloodline carried within them a singular desire for vengeance; who in death rendered curses. (edited)
It isn't miraculous that such would even while still alive transform into oni or tsuchigumo.
As Kintoki is contemplative, Murasaki speaks out in concern. However, his mood seems to change, and he elaborates that the era in which defeat in battle births forth kai'i is long over.
He gives that it's hard to say that the generalization above necessarily applies to all oni and tsuchigumo, even that it isn't so spoken.
For example, would this apply to Ootakemaru (大嶽丸), who was once defeated by Tamuramaro?
Or to Suzuka-no-Gozen, who became as Tamuramaro's bride — said to be an oni, even as she was the daughter of a Tenma (天魔, a demon lord of the heavens).
Even that they bore horns and breathed fire, were they not merely humans borne of power?
Though, Kintoki says, there is of course no way to determine what the truth is at present.
He presumes that the grudges of the fallen account for some of what lurks amidst the darkness of the Miyako.
The ox carriage arrives at the Imperial Palace.
Here, Danzou spiritualizes.
Murasaki is confused that she suddenly vanished.
To this, Guda gives the excuses that she might've left the carriage at some point during the journey.
Murasaki replies that she could've sworn that she just now heard her voice.
However, she chalks it up to not having had enough sleep.
She gives that she needs to get a grip of herself — though, this applies not only to herself, but the party as well. Here on out, they're within the bounds of the Imperial Palace, and they should be careful not to exhibit the slightest bit of ill manner or disrespect.
Surprisingly, Kintoki is able to assume the behavior of a perfect gentleman?
6
Inside the Palace, Murasaki brings the party before the onmyouji, Ashiya Douman — or at least the location where he's supposed to be. (edited)
A little ways in, however, Kintoki takes note of the approach of a certain noblewoman.
5
The noblewoman identifies Murasaki as a courtier in the service of Fujiwara-no-Shoushi (藤原彰子). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Empress_Sh%C5%8Dshi
Murasaki, in turn, identifies the noblewoman as Takako. (edited)
Takako recognizes Murasaki as the author of Genji Monogatari, and gives that she's a fan of Murasaki's work.
At her appearance, Guda is surprised that Tamamo would be somehow present.
Takako doesn't recognize Guda, and wonders who she would be. Before this can result in a scene, Kintoki introduces himself.
However, Takako asks him if this is the first time he's seen her in her present appearance.
At Kintoki's confusion, Takako gives that she encountered him before in the mountains at Sagami (相模).
She gives that perhaps it was before he was capable of distinguishing a kitsune from a tanuki.
She apologizes, and Kintoki accepts it — though it appears that he isn't certain what to make of her words at the moment?
Moving on, Takako assesses Guda, giving that she appears to be gazing at her with familiarity.
Takako wonders if they've met before, and apologizes that she doesn't quite remember making Guda's acquaintance.
She introduces herself as Takako — one amongst the concubines of the Emperor.
Guda expresses shock at her face; her ears; her tail.
At this, Takako seems confused as to what Guda might be referring to.
Kintoki covers for Guda, asking that Takako please forgive the disrespect of his protogee.
Takako seems to pay no mind — but, approaching Guda, she whispers, asking if Guda is somebody capable of "seeing."
She gives that she's quite incredulous, as outside the particular circumstance with Abe-no-Seimei, she believed that her genjutsu was perfect.
There shouldn't be any reason that Guda can see her ears and tails.
However, she doesn't seem to regard Guda with enmity, asking instead where it is that they've met each other before.
She supposes that perhaps they bear a tie of En.
To this, Guda replies that she isn't certain whether to call this as their first encounter or not. She doesn't quite know how to explain it. (edited)
Takako observes that it would see that they do indeed bear a tie of En.
Giving that it would seem that Guda has no business with her, she asks if Guda indeed seeks audience with Ashiya Douman.
In that case, she won't further interrupt — but she asks in exchange that Guda keeps quiet about her nature.
To this, Guda assents.
Backing away, Takako gives that the party should stay on their toes, as she's heard that even within the grounds of the Imperial Palace, oni and grudge spirits have recently been sighted. (edited)
Kintoki wonders at the fact that even he — once called as the Kaidoumaru of Ashigara (足柄の怪童丸) — would come to a cold sweat in Takako's presence.
He wonders if that woman just now could be stronger that the bears he encountered in youth in the mountains at Ashigara. This, he says, is why he doesn't understand women. (edited)
Murasaki is concerned at the private conversation that Takako engaged Guda in, and asks if everything's alright.
Guda gives that everything should be fine.
At this point, somebody interrupts their conversation, approaching from behind Guda. Kintoki is shocked, as he sensed nothing of their presence. (edited)
Ashiya Douman is there. He gives that there are some residual impurities on Guda's person, and asks her to hold still. So saying, he performs a purification of evil spirits.
Kintoki gives that he's quite skilled as an onmyouji, as he was able to do such a thing absent of even lighting incense.
Douman asks if Guda has recently encountered monstrosities in the dead of night, giving that bringing impurities into the Imperial Palace isn't permitted. (edited)
However, he says that there's nothing more to worry about, as he's already conducted a purification.
Murasaki apologizes to Douman, giving that she's ashamed. Despite having received instruction from Abe-no-Seimei, she didn't notice such a thing.
Guda uneasily thanks Douman for conducting a purification.
Giving that it seems to be the first that he's met Kintoki, Ashiya Douman introduces himself.
Guda introduces herself, as if to test if Douman will recognize her. However, showing no response in this capacity, he instead comments that it appears he isn't comfortable with him, maybe on account that he abruptly approached and conducted a purification.
However, he gives that he doesn't very much mind that you ill regard him, being that he's well aware that Abe-to-Seimei is far better regarded than him amongst the citizens of the Miyako. (edited)
Guda gives that it's not a matter what's spoken of him in the streets. (edited)
Whispering, Kintoki asks Danzou to assess Douman.
Remaining astralized, Danzou somehow communicates that though indeed Douman's appearance is a match with Limbo, she can sense from him nothing in the way of malevolence or youki.
Even the quality of his mana is fundamentally distinct from Limbo's.
Noticing that Kintoki is studying him, Douman asks if there's something on his face.
Kintoki replies in the negative, giving that it's merely that he wanted to meet him as to confirm a certain matter.
Now that he has, he no longer has any business with Douman.
Approaching, Fujiwara-no-Michinaga asks what the ruckus is.
Next arrow:
There's an excerpt from a diary — perhaps the same one that discussed the steel monstrosity that wandered the streets at night.
Here, a recap of the events of the previous segment is given, ending with a comment from the narrator that their heart nearly stopped on account of shock when Fujiwara-no-Michinaga — the father-in-law of the Emperor — suddenly made an appearance. (edited)
From this, maybe we're to take it that the writer of the diary is Murasaki?
In the present:
Kintoki apologizes for the intrusion, taking responsibility for Guda's presence within the Palace.
Murasaki tries to get in a word, giving that she mentioned the previous night that Kintoki and his party would be present on Palace grounds this morning.
In response, Michinaga tells Murasaki to shut up, as he's speaking with Kaidoumaru. (edited)
Murasaki apologizes for her insolence, and backs away. (edited)
Michinaga asks to see Guda's face.
From her dogeza, Guda raises her face to look at Michinaga. In response, the man comments that it's rare that one would show no fear before the Minister of the Left. (edited)
He asks if Guda would be an up-and-coming warrior of the Genji; but immediately corrects himself, recalling that Kintoki didn't claim such a thing.
Michinaga finds Guda's courage amusing, giving that perhaps she's encountered evil spirits of considerable strength before. Those capable of enduring such encounters are perhaps alike to Raikou — something akin to a kaidou (怪童, a child of monstrous strength) or an onigo (鬼子, a child of an oni).
He asks Kintoki if that's the case. Kintoki answers in the affirmative.
