Michinaga comments that the blood of heteromorphs (異形, ikei, lit. "of alien form") is of no use to the nobility; but may be of use in the capacity of a warrior.
2
He comments that he'll render no punishment for this, and gives that Kintoki may raise his head from dogeza.
Michinaga asks for the reason behind the visitation. At this, Kintoki isn't certain as to how to respond.
After a bit of silence while Kintoki considers his response, Michinaga again pushes for a reply.
Kintoki gives here that it's related to the Tenran Grail War.
Kintoki gives that whereas it was claimed that the Tenran Grail War was a ritual as to bring forth to the Miyako and millennium of peace, this is false.
Its true nature is as an existence that will bring forth a calamity — a plot by those who would think to plunge the Miyako into a state of chaos.
He begs that Michinaga reconsiders the prosecution of the Grail War.
Douman asks what Kintoki means in describing the Grail War as a treacherous plot. Douman gives that he's certain that the documentation of the ritual was penned by the hand of Abe-no-Seimei himself.
Michinaga affirms this, asking what evidence Kintoki bears that this is indeed some manner of treachery.
Kintoki gives that it's suspicious that Abe-no-Seimei wouldn't leave behind documentation, and fail to present it in person.
He asks if it's certain that the documentation of the ritual was indeed penned by Abe-no-Seimei himself.
Being as Kintoki's all but forgotten to act like a gentleman, Murasaki begs for him not to offend Michinaga. (edited)
Hearing this, Kintoki apologizes for his insolence.
He gives however that his concern about the Grail War is legitimate.
Michinaga asks for Kintoki to elaborate on the matter of the party responsible for this supposed treachery.
At this, Guda speaks up, giving that the one behind the Grail War is an individual called as Alter-Ego Limbo.
After some explanation, Michinaga sums up what he heard of Guda's testimony — that the Grail War may be a plot perpetrated by a villain from a distant land or an otherworld.
He acknowledges that there may indeed be parties from foreign lands that refuse to abide by orders. He poses however that, nevertheless, the handwriting as of the documentation for the Tenran Grail War is indeed that of Abe-no-Seimei.
He asks Douman if this is not the case.
Douman affirms his words.
Privately, Kintoki thinks that though this "Douman" is quite suspicious, he has it on Danzou's word that he isn't the same individual as Limbo.
It wouldn't be smart to abruptly claim that Douman and Limbo are one and the same.
Douman notices that Guda is gazing at him, and asks her what's the matter.
Guda replies that it's nothing.
Michinaga gives that there isn't sufficient evidence to support Kintoki's suspicion.
Rather, it's only on the testimony of Kintoki's party that this supposed plot is of concern.
Therefore, he will not halt the Tenran Grail War.
Pondering on Michinaga's words, Kintoki thinks that indeed, there's nothing to back up the claim aside from Chaldea's word. Even that he trusts in them, Michinaga isn't the sort to put stock in instinct.
That said, Michinaga gives that if Kintoki and company can provide evidence to their claims, he's willing to hear them out.
Alternatively, if all of the Tenran Musha that yet participate — or alternatively, if the Genji engaged in protecting the Miyako agree as one that the Tenran Grail War is of no benefit, the ritual obviously wouldn't proceed. Ergo, if that's indeed the case, he gives that Kintoki should inform him. (edited)
Here, however, Tsuna arrives.
Having overheard the conversation, he gives that being as he isn't in favor of cancelling the ritual, the condition proposed by Michinaga won't be fulfilled.
Tsuna gives that at their previous encounter, he stated that he would claim Kintoki's left arm.
If this were not the Palace, he would make good on that promise.
But so saying, he implies that he wouldn't mind proceeding.
Guda calls for the two of them to halt.
Douman gives the same, stating that the Palace isn't the place for such a thing.
Next arrow:
On an avenue out in the city, Kintoki gives that though Limbo's location is as yet unknown, at the very least, it's confirmed that he isn't the same person as Ashiya Douman.
Furthermore, if he can obtain the agreement of the Tenran Musha or the Genji, the Grail War can be brought to a halt.
Danzou recommends seeking out the three other Tenran Musha still participating, as this would be far easier than obtaining the consent of the Genji as a whole. (edited)
Kintoki agrees, and Guda gives that for the time being, they should ask around the Miyako to see if they can't collect some intel.
Kintoki observes that Guda's capable of quickly switching gears. He praises her, giving that it's almost as if she were a police inspector; asking if she's adapted to finding her way in unknown territory.
Guda gives that it isn't that she's used it it. Rather, at the moment, the party cannot proceed without more information.
Danzou is appreciative of the atmosphere of the city in daytime, giving that perhaps this is the true form of Heian-Kyo.
At her word, Kintoki realizes that this is the first that Danzou and Guda have seen the Miyako by day.
As they speak, Kintoki is greeted by the people upon the street.
After speaking a bit with the residents on the matter of recent rumors, a small girl mentions the matter of the monster of steel.
It's given that the monster is apparently capable of ignoring the blessings of a certain shrine of O-Inari; that it manifested roughly around the Hour of the Rat (子の刻, ne no koku, approximately midnight). (edited)
Kintoki asks if these are recent rumors.
The citizens seem to be in agreement that the monster of steel was sighted just recently. (edited)
Arrow 5:
Nightfall.
The party's arrived at the shrine to Inari, where the monster of steel was supposedly sighted.
Guda comments to Kintoki that he seems to be familiar with the work of conducting a stakeout. To this, Kintoki replies that he isn't quite as used to it as a legitimate police inspector deployed to capture criminals, or to search for missing persons. (edited)
His work generally entails suppression of the oni that invade the Miyako; the culling of the nests of the tsuchigumo and other kai'i; the extermination of spirits that come to haunt the residences of the nobility; the hunting down of stragglers from the Rebellion of Bandou (坂東の乱, bandou no ran).
But indeed, occasionally, he does indeed do work akin to the business of the police — staking places out while suppressing the sound of his breath. (edited)
Guda asks if he has difficulty with people.
To this, Kintoki replies that that isn't really it. He asks if he's told Guda that he was raised in the mountains.
Far in the east, in the Country of Sagami — deep in the mountains of Ashigara. It was a place largely absent of humans. (edited)
In the mountains, there were nothing but beasts — or, occasionally, maybe an oni or something of the like.
Therefore, children running about; mothers preparing meals; fathers working — he never saw that sort of thing, growing up in the mountains. It was only after coming into civilization that he got a good look at the livelihoods of men. (edited)
And he came to like them. Even that he'll never get used to the bustle of the city, and crowds of people put him ill at ease, he likes people.
He likes the beasts of the mountains as well, but that's a different matter — different, but similar.
Guda gives that she can somewhat understand what he means.
Danzou returns, giving that she informed Murasaki that the three of them would be returning late.
Giving also that she surveyed the grounds of the shrine before returning, she discovered that in the thicket, there's a small shrine — behind which there lies the entrance of a natural cave.
Guda gives that they should investigate for signs of the steel monstrosity.
Advancing, the party finds a cavern that extends beneath the shrine.
Though indeed it looks to be a natural cavern, Kintoki gives that per the movement of the air, there should be an exit at some location not too distant.
Danzou observes that per the readings of her sensors, this cavern should be situated directly above a leyline high in mana density.
Kintoki isn't certain what "maryoku" is, but gives that the thickness of the "odor" is something alike to youki.
It's a place where kai'i could easily construct a nest; where the onmyouji could easily light their incense.
Danzou gives that if Mashu were present, she'd be able to establish a summoning circle.
But setting that aside for now, she gives that this would be territory of advantage to a participant of the Tenran Grail War.
A Master or a Heroic Spirit could make use of such a location as to secure an mana supply. In the context of the Tenran Grail War, it would be as a site of strategic important to any summoned Casters.
As they discuss the matter, there's a sound in the distance, and Danzou confirms the approach of a mana signature.
However, it isn't comparable to that of a Servant.
The figure that steps into view is a Helter Skelter, alike to that which Guda encountered in London. (edited)
Kintoki is amused that it's indeed a block of steel, remarking that its form both alike and unalike to that of the Oo-gusoku.
He gives that being as it hasn't named itself, he doubts that it's a Tenran Musha. That being the case, he wonders if it's not a jutsusha / Caster from an otherworld.
Danzou replies that it isn't the jutsusha / Caster themselves, but rather something akin to a familiar or a bunshin.
fallacies 06-Dec-20 04:52 PM
After combat: Defeating the Helter Skelter, Kintoki gives that the resistance it put up felt quite thin. (edited)
He wonders if it isn't something alike to an illusion.
Danzou answers in the negative, reiterating that it's more akin to a familiar or a bunshin.
Kintoki understands her to be referring to shikigami.
Even that this isn't as a junction (交差点, kousaten) to all the leylines that underly the Miyako, Danzou gives that she detects from it a rich, high-density mana. Again, to the Heroic Spirits that are as jutsusha, this would necessarily be a site of strategic importance.
She believes that it was on account that such a site would favorable to particular varieties of kai'i as a location for the construction of a nest, the Caster that discovered the cavern placed their familiars here as a ward against kai'i. (edited)
Kintoki remarks that Danzou's description fits. The Helter Skelters wouldn't be sufficient to bring down a Tenran Musha; but if the intention were to ward of small-scale kai'i, they'd be suitable. (edited)
Guda repeats again that they were Helter Skelter. Giving that he heard her say this earlier, Kintoki asks what the term refers to.
Guda replies that these were likely familiars of the Heroic Spirit Charles Babbage.
Kintoki asks who this Babbage would be. Based on the name, he supposes that it's a Caster from an otherworld; but per Guda's explanation, he wonders if this guy isn't somebody from Chaldea.
Danzou gives that she isn't certain how to phrase her answer, but that it would be sufficient for now that Kintoki treats Babbage as one amongst the Casters of the Grail War.
Elaborating, Danzou gives that even in the circumstance that it's all the same personage, a Heroic Spirit would per the era and locale of their summoning manifest as completely different individuals.
Kintoki is confused at the explanation. To simplify, then, Danzou gives that Charles Babbage is a Caster; a Heroic Spirit who was in the past — or rather, in the distant future relative to the Heian Era — engraved unto the Human Order.
Danzou gives that Chaldea is familiar with his name and form.
Guda gives that he was the genius mathematician who realized the creation of the Difference Engine.
This of course is terminology that again confuses Kintoki.
Elaborating, Guda gives that he was a Heroic Spirit who once dreamed of a different World.
The Difference Engine, and the Analytical Engine that would've succeeded it. Danzou gives that these were inventions that brought the possibility of rendering calculations in excess of the means of man. Therefore, they were regarded as inventions of great significance to the advancement of civilization. (edited)
By the use of these, she gives, Babbage hoped to bestow to man a new beacon of light. (edited)
However, these dreams were in the end unrealized.
By the mischief of fate, Babbage was incapable of bringing his plans to fruition.
Thereafter, the History of Man birthed forth devices that could render calculations on a similar scale, and considerable advances were since then made.
The Babbage that manifests to reality in the capacity of a Heroic Spirit, however, does in distinction from the History of Man implement to realization the Difference Engine in full.
Ergo, says Danzou, he is as a dreamlike existence from a World of 'what if?'
Alternatively, she gives, it could be that Babbage's eyes gaze upon an Item Designated For Elimination.
Kintoki gives that he recalls that Guda and Danzou mentioned something of the like before. Thinking on it a bit, he asks if it refers to 'a possible tomorrow?'
Guda nods her head, but Danzou clarifies that these would also be as tomorrows that shall never arrive so long as the History of Man remains as the History of Man.
Tomorrows that shall never become as Items Permissible to Revision are by the rule of the Human Order rendered to culling.
fallacies 06-Dec-20 06:24 PM
https://forums.spacebattles.com/threads/general-type-moon-discussion-thread-2-unlimited-titles-works-please-read-the-threadmarks.795493/post-72430964
General Type-Moon Discussion Thread 2: Unlimited Titles Works! (PLE...
I perfectly understand the reasons for hating her but I personally disagree on that opinion. Not that I want to debate, everyone has their tastes. I mean nobody here is really saying that we hate her. She is one of the more popular caster requests to get an event focus, maybe second after...
fallacies 06-Dec-20 06:35 PM
Chapter 5
fallacies 06-Dec-20 06:45 PM
The writer of the diary gives that after hearing the words spoken by Michinaga-sama, they weren't of a mood to be lively.
It isn't the first that they felt this way. It's a mood that regular overcomes them, though not precisely in a persistent manner.
The point at which their hand comes to cease. Their hand, which alike to a traveler who wanders hungry and thirsty; which guiding turns of phrase composes a text — weaving forth a tale ...
At times, it comes to cease. It was like the day prior as well.
Cruelly, upon their left hand — come to a halt, even as it grips a brush — there comes to surface a mark of proof.
That is, the three strokes of a Command Seal — that what ties the writer to the man of steel. (edited)
A member of Murasaki's household.
Kintoki apologizes for requesting a meal so late into the evening.
The woman gives that it's of no issue. She asks if the party intends to leave again early in the morning. To this, Kintoki gives that they haven't such an intention. Hearing this, the woman gives that she'll arrange to serve them breakfast, then.
Guda thanks the woman, and says good night. The woman nods, and gathering their bowls and utensils, she departs.
Danzou gives here that she'd like to review the information thus far acquired.
She gives that at present, two of the seven Tenran Musha have been defeated.
These would be Usui and Urabe of the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu.
Of the known Tenran Musha, the 3rd would be Tsuna, and the 4th would be Kintoki. (edited)
Charles Babbage would be as the Heroic Spirit contracted to the unknown 5th Tenran Musha. (edited)
Kintoki asks if Guda would therefore count as the 4th Heroic Spirit. (edited)
To this, Guda reiterates that she isn't a Servant.
Kintoki laughs, apologizing that he didn't intend to forget.
He wonders where his Heroic Spirit would be, given that Danzou appears not to be contracted with him either. (edited)
Danzou apologizes, giving that she's a Servant contracted to Guda.
Furthermore, she's an Assassin, and not a Caster.
Presuming the premise that all Heroic Spirits manifested per the Tenran Grail War are Saint Graphs of the Caster Class, Danzou gives that she wouldn't qualify for summoning. (edited)
Kintoki apologizes again, giving that being as he bears Command Seals, he was simply wondering where his own Heroic Spirit would be.
Moving on, Kintoki wonders as to the identity of Babbage's contracted Tenran Musha.
Danzou asks if Kintoki is aware of the conditions by which an individual would qualify as a Master of the Tenran Grail War.
She gives that as a matter of reference, there would in a standard Grail War exist a number of conditions that need to be met before a prospective participant would qualify as a Master. (edited)
For example, magi, or individuals of approximate capability; individuals borne of potent desires, and so forth.
Kintoki feels that the circumstances described seem contrary to that as of the Tenran Grail War.
Danzou remarks that it does seem to be the reverse of the War in Heian-Kyo.
Danzou gives that she was thinking that perhaps those titled as Tenran Musha would necessarily qualify as warriors? (edited)
Kintoki replies in the negative. (edited)
This rather shocks Danzou.
Kintoki apologizes for not clarifying on the matter of the qualifying conditions.
fallacies 06-Dec-20 08:08 PM
At the inception of the War, (edited)
Michinaga announced that those qualified to participate would be those borne of power, known to all within the Miyako; (edited)
that this would be a competition as to claim the heads of the jutsusha summoned forth from foreign lands and otherworlds. (edited)
Hearing this, Danzou gives that being as Heroic Spirits are existences beyond the domain of men, under normal circumstances, it wouldn't be specified that they would be the ones whose heads are targeted.
As Servants are easily capable of singlehandedly matching the might of an army, they would as of the utsushiyo (現世, in Shinto, "manifest world"; though in Nasu, typically "current world") of the Master be as weapon-class existence; Mysteries that reenact myths and legends as of the Surface.
Danzou gives that that the warriors of the Heian are indeed fearsome.
But hearing the wording that Michinaga used per Kintoki's recollection, Danzou gives that "those borne of power" would to her thinking certainly refer to the warriors of Heian.
Kintoki contradicts her opinion, asking if "power" would necessarily refer to the epitome of martial strength.
He gives that those capable of cooking are in his opinion potent in their strength. (edited)
5
Those capable of composing poetry are likewise; Kintoki gives that he himself is hopeless at such a thing.
Here, Danzou gives that Murasaki is approaching.
Arriving in the room, Murasaki welcomes them back, asking where it was that they went. (edited)
Kintoki replies that they went to exterminate a monster near the Avenue of Suzaku.
He asks if she's aware of recent rumors of a steel monstrosity wandering near the shrine dedicated to Inari.
He gives that he went over to offer a greeting, but only ended up running across an illusory bunshin of some variety.
The primary corpus wasn't present; so so, he plans on greeting him again another time.
Murasaki is shaken by the news.
Stuttering slightly, she voices wonder as to the existence of such a kai'i.
To this, Kintoki gives that she has nothing to worry about.
This time was a bust, but the next time he'll certainly bring it down. Thus, Murasaki can sleep easy. (edited)
Murasaki: "I, I see ..."
Murasaki gives that she doesn't feel well, and that she'll be turning in for the night.
4
Kintoki gives that she can trust him to take down the monstrosity of steel.
So, he asks that she don't think of frightening things, and go and have a bit of rest.
Murasaki says goodnight, but Guda, detecting something off, asks her if she's alright.
Sometime later, Danzou asks Guda if she's still awake. (edited)
When Guda gives that she is, Danzou reports that just now, Murasaki departed the house.
Kintoki awakens. After Danzou explains the situation, he asks if Murasaki departed by foot. Danzou replies that it was by way of ox carriage.
Kintoki gives that it's still dark out, and looks to be early morning. To this, Danzou reports that it's just before the 3rd quarter of the Hour of the Ox (between 2 to 2:30 AM).
Guda asks Danzou to tail Murasaki.
Out in the streets, Danzou reports to Guda and Kintoki that Murasaki's ox carriage is headed to the shrine of Inari.
Giving that it's faster if he carries Guda, Kintoki picks her up and starts running. (Wouldn't it be kind of awkward if Guda were a guy ... ?)
2
2
2
Running along, he remarks that it's strange; there aren't any kai'i on the larger streets.
However, shortly after saying so, Kintoki and Guda encounter Helter Skelters.
Next arrow:
Kintoki and Guda arrive at the shrine of Inari. (edited)
Danzou appears, reporting that Murasaki entered into the cavern they previously visited.
Once within, Danzou notices nothing different from their previous investigation. The mana density is the same, and there's nothing that stands out to her as enemy mana signature.
Though her senses don't extend to the deepest reaches of the cavern, she tentatively reports that there aren't any discernible familiars within the vicinity.
Kintoki gives that it's difficult to think that Murasaki would confront them with hostilities; but as the layout of the cavern easily permits for an ambush, he'll be taking the lead. He'll entrust Danzou with the rear guard.
He asks Guda to provide support as necessary. She answers in the affirmative.
Kintoki gives a taunt, saying that before he tosses his axe, whoever's out there better show themselves.
Danzou is quite shocked at this, and at her complaint, he replies that as whoever's ahead might be Murasaki, he wouldn't really toss his battleaxe. He does, after all, owe her for taking him in.
It's just a bluff, he says.
Surprisingly, somebody does appear, giving that she doesn't any business with his battle-axe.
It's Sei Shounagon.
She gives that unfortunately, she can't permit them to advance. She tells them to return to Murasaki's mansion.
Kintoki asks her why she would be here. Is she in fact a Tenran Musha? (edited)
She replies that unfortunately, she isn't. She's just plain old Seiko.
Apparently, she has nothing to do with the Grail War; but for Murasaki's sake, she won't permit anyone to advance past this point.
Kintoki asks her why that would be. Per his understanding, they aren't even acquainted with one another.
Sei gives that indeed, they have no relationship aside from the fact that they're both writers.
Further, Murasaki isn't aware that Sei is intervening on her behalf.
Because, this is just a matter of her own self-indulgence.
She gives that she's absolutely in love with Murasaki's writing.
Therefore, she won't permit anyone to pass.
Though apparently Sei dislikes onmyouji in general, she was somewhat acquainted with Abe-no-Seimei. It seems that prior his disappearance, he forced her to accept several ofuda, capable of iterating shikigami.
Sei gives that maybe Seimei foresaw that she'd end up in a situation like this. (edited)
So saying, she releases the ofuda, and shikigami manifest.
fallacies 06-Dec-20 09:47 PM
After combat:
Sei accepts defeat, but gives that no matter what, she wants to read Murasaki's story unto its completion.
Guda gives that she has no intention of rendering harm against Murasaki.
She asks Kintoki to confirm this. To her question, Kintoki gives that it's a matter of course; women and children are to be protected — no to be held as opponents in combat.
Just now, for example, he didn't lay a finger on Sei.
Deeper in the cavern, Murasaki speaks.
"I'd like to witness a dream as well — as you have."
"That steel. That armor."
"If I were to pass through to the other side of that thick shell ... would I be able to glimpse your world?"
Babbage gives that she's being unreasonable.
She should seek her own dream, he says. The embers of his dream — the terminus of his wishes — these are his alone.
They would be of no use to her.
The act of storytelling is the conquest of a dream; a seeking of the brilliance what lies at the apex of poetry — alike to the continuous fabrication of one's own world.
He gives that she has her own dream.
Murasaki asks him how he can say such a thing, being as he isn't —
He interrupts her, giving that while isn't him a poet, he's acquainted with many. Thus, he's listened well to the words of poets.
He comprehends the joys and sorrows of storytellers; what it is that she desires from the bottom of her heart.
So, saying, he turns his attention to Guda's party, whose observation he was aware of. (edited)
Danzou apologizes for interrupting his discussion.
Murasaki is shocked that she was followed, and apologizes to Babbage.
Observing that Guda and her party appear to be aware of his True Name, Babbage reasons that they must be related in some manner to the Tenran Grail War.
Here, Kintoki gives that Babbage shouldn't jump to conclusions; they came only to talk.
He explains to Babbage and Murasaki that the Tenran Grail War is suspect.
Rather than dancing to the tune of the party plotting behind the scenes, he'd like to form an alliance.
However, before he can finish speaking, Babbage attacks. Kintoki blocks him with his axe, giving that it seems that this time they're up against the real monstrosity of steel — observing that his warhammer is quite heavy.
Babbage seems offended, giving that it's a cane.
Complaining that Babbage seems to be quite an obstinate old man, Kintoki repeats himself — shouting that the Tenran Grail War is a suspicious plot, maybe hatched by a villain.
He gives that they'll be wrapped up in it if things proceed.
Babbage tells Murasaki not to listen. What summoned him was undoubtedly the power of the Holy Grail. That being the case, he will become as steel so as to render his Master's wish.
Kintoki replies that it isn't certain that a wish can even be granted.
He asks if Babbage is willing to risk his life for a Grail uncertain in function.
Babbage is unwilling to listen. He gives that humans are beings that dream, and that life is as a fragile thing. Therefore, even the slightest opportunity as to attain one's wish must be taken advantage of — even that everything is consumed in the process.
He gives that if Kintoki can't comprehend that, he should back away.
Kintoki refuses.
After combat:
Kintoki defeats Babbage with a sumo throw. The attack damages Babbage's systems sufficiently that he can't immediately mount another offense.
Here, Guda addresses Murasaki, giving that she'd like to talk for a bit.
Addressing her as Fujiwara-no-Kaoruko, daughter of Fujiwara-no-Tametoki (藤原為時), Kintoki asks if she is indeed one amongst the Tenran Musha participating in this War.
Murasaki gives that she isn't a Musha (武者, "warrior").
Kintoki gives that indeed, she isn't a warrior. He furthermore hasn't heard that she's skilled in the use of shikigami.
However, she is indeed an individual borne of power. (edited)
Skilled in the weaving of words, she bears a strength that he cannot attain.
Thus, he addresses her as the 5th Tenran Musha, Murasaki Shikibu.
Murasaki gives that her status as a Tenran Musha is known neither to Michinaga, the Minister of the Left; nor Ashiya Douman.
The fact that Command Seals have surfaced upon her left hand is known to the heavens alone.
But she intends to cross blade with nobody.
She refuses to fight.
Guda gives that however, it would seem that deep down, there truly is something that Murasaki wishes for.
Danzou here gives that the Holy Grail chooses those borne of wishes. This is the sort of Grail War that she's familiar with.
She presumes that this may likewise apply to the Tenran Grail War.
Hearing this, Murasaki admits that she does indeed have a wish.
Babbage speaks her name as if to warn her, but addressing him as ojisama, she gives that as Guda and company don't appear to seek his head, she trusts in their word. (edited)
She apologizes for so long concealing truth. (edited)
Her wish is as to complete her tale in the best possible way.
This is all that she seeks.
Hearing this, Kintoki gives that she should simply proceed as is. It's her story. That being the case, she should write it to completion. (edited)
Murasaki gives that composition is alike to walking in the summer heat, absent of water.
Sometimes, it becomes difficult to advance. So as a traveler's feet grow weary, so too do the fingers that hold the brush grow heavy.
It isn't a matter such a thing has once or twice occurred. Many a time, she's stumbled. (edited)
This time as well, she wasn't able to carry that weight. How should she advance the Genji Monogatari to completion?
As she so struggled, Command Seals surfaced upon her hand.
At Babbage's manifestation — hearing his explanation of the Tenran Grail War — she couldn't bring herself to risk Babbage's life for the sake of her wish. Further, she didn't want anyone to be injured or killed on her behalf. (edited)
Understanding her position, Babbage gave then that he would protect her unto the end of the War.
However, he was surprised. The knowledge supplied to him by the Grail gave that the Tenran Grail War was a War within which the lives of Servants were to be defended. However, Murasaki was a Master of insufficient strength to match a Servant. Rather, she was a Master whose life had to be defended by a Servant.
Babbage opined that their relation was as per that of a Master and a Servant in a proper Grail War.
Hearing of Babbage and Murasaki's circumstances, Danzou concludes that Babbage's strategy entailed directly defending Murasaki only at night.
Being as during the daytime, Murasaki would be at her posting upon the Palace grounds, where the other Tenran Musha are forbidden to act, it was necessary only to defend her at night.
After some discussion, it comes out that the "bunshin" that Kintoki previously engaged was in fact Babbage himself.
Rather than deploying familiars as to conduct patrols, Babbage went out himself — absent of astralization. This confuses Kintoki, and he points out that if Servants are capable of such, it doesn't make sense that Babbage wouldn't employ astralization to his benefit.
To this, Babbage gives that he did, at first. However, as the War couldn't advance if the Casters summoned were to simply remain astralized, Murasaki explains that three days into the War, the Minister of the Left ordered that the Ministry of Onmyou adjust the Bounded Fields deployed across the Miyako.
Consequently, a penalty was implemented. If a Servant of the War remains astralized for over half a day, the Bounded Fields would forcibly render them to materialization.
This is as a potent Curse that shall persist unto the end of the War.
A Curse as to restrict Astralization.
Babbage gives that the Curses of the Orient are quite adroit. Even that he'd concealed his form, the Curse was communicated to him by way of the leylines.
Ergo, Kintoki observes, Babbage had no choice but to walk along the streets. He was incapable of astralization.
The night that Kintoki and Guda requested to stay at Murasaki's home, Babbage engaged his astralization as a temporary measure. Subsequently, he's been observing her home from afar using his heat detection faculty.
Kintoki gives that Babbage did well to conceal himself until now. However, there's been rumors amongst the populace — (edited)
As he says this, Tsuna shows himself, giving that as a matter of course, the rumors reached his ears as well.
Danzou is surprised at his arrival. Even that she'd engaged her sensors to act at full capacity as to investigate the cavern, she wasn't able to detect his approach.
Tsuna gives that he thought to deal with the Heroic Spirit who would be so bold as to walk the grand avenues on a nightly basis — but it seems that his tie of En with Kintoki is quite potent. (edited)
So saying, he draws his blade.
Next arrow:
Kintoki warns Tsuna, giving that it isn't a good look to be stealing the prey of another.
Kintoki claims the monstrosity of steel — the Heroic Spirit Babbage —as his guest, giving that he won't permit that another seizes him.
Babbage, apparently somewhat recovered from his engagement against Kintoki, rouses himself. Addressing Tsuna, he gives that his nightly walks through the city were not without strategy. Being as he's established a foothold on spiritual ground, he has access to his Noble Phantasm.
True Name Releasing the Dimension of Steam, the cavern proliferates with Helter Skelters.
Seeing that Tsuna's being held off by the army of Helter Skelters, Kintoki tells Babbage that they have the opportunity to escape.
However, Babbage refuses.
Giving that the present opportunity won't arise again, he addresses Kintoki — asking to fight.
Murasaki is confused, giving that she won't permit it; that as Kintoki and Guda advise, they should escape to somewhere far away — without the bounds of the Miyako, to a country in the east or west. She doesn't want to see Babbage injured or dead.
In reply, Babbage speaks:
"Kaoruko. Nay, Murasaki Shikibu. O storytelling princess."
"The Difference Engine that is as mine dream does everything render to calculation. Even that it is in the end nothing more than a delusion at the tip of my fingers — without the realm of omnipotence — it is equal to the task of informing mine of mine own end; that I shall not advance beyond this point."
"Tsuna Watanabe is a brilliant hunting dog — or perhaps a wolf. I know not how long my trap will hold."
"— therefore, I entrust [Murasaki to your care]."
"Forgive me for going against my word, O storytelling princess."
6
Murasaki objects. Even that he's skilled in divination, she asks if he intends to choose his own end.
Kintoki gives that he's already defeated Babbage once. He asks if he's serious about going at it again. Babbage answers in the affirmative. (edited)
Kintoki gives that Murasaki is in tears. Again, he asks if Babbage intends to go at this. Babbage answers in the affirmative.
Once more, Kintoki asks if he intends to go at this, having heard their explanation of the Grail War. Babbage answers in the affirmative.
Guda asks Kintoki what he intends to do.
In response, Kintoki gives that there's no stopping a man who's made up his mind.
Babbage speaks:
"Mine soul. Mine life. Mine dreams. I entrust these all to your care. Allow me to witness that you might shatter the steel that armors mine heart."
"And if you cannot, I'll have you pay with your lives."
"O you who are borne of strength. Who for the sake of thy dream do thirst; do strive; do claw against the soil."
"Therefore, conquer. Therefore, kill."
"If you seek to realize your wish, there is aside from forcing your way through by the strength that you bear no other path."
Kintoki asks Babbage one final time if he's certain about this. Babbage answers in the affirmative.
However, before the battle can begin, Kintoki abruptly finds himself in a hellscape.
Danzou reports that this is a Reality Marble.
Guda recognizes it.
This is a stage for a battle unto death.
This was the stage of the Blademaster confrontations in Shimousa.
Babbage speaks:
"This would be as the battlefield of blood; the Limbo (辺獄, hengoku) what consumes Heroic Spirits succumbed to defeat."
"— that what over the black sun presides, called as the Tenran Shiai Butai (天覧死合舞台, "the stage of the deathmatch presided over by the Skies")."
"Mine true name be as Charles Babbage! Mine dreams; mine delusions — these shall hereby bring thy path to closure."
"Laugh, O Kijin (鬼神, lit. "oni god"). Shine, O Daystar."
5
"Come — for the sake of thy own wish."
"— let that I here witness thy strength."
1
1
fallacies 07-Dec-20 01:20 AM
Babbage is defeated.
Outside the Tenran Shiai Butai, the Helter Skelters engaging Tsuna deactivate and vanish away.
Medea reports to Tsuna that it appears that the enemy Servant's Spiritual Core has shattered.
Ergo, he should soon pass from the present World. (edited)
Tsuna wonders if this was suicide on Babbage's part, but quickly dismisses the hypothesis — concluding instead that the Caster placed his bets on Kintoki, who is weaker than he.
Indeed, says Tsuna, his blade is unrestrained. In consequence, Urabe and Usui of the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu sustained that weren't slight in their engagements against him.
Ergo, being as Murasaki Shikibu is untrained in the martial disciplines, Tsuna supposes that Babbage intended to protect his Tenran Musha. (edited)
Tsuna calls for Medea, giving that they no longer have business here. So saying, he departs.
Elsewhere in the cavern, Babbage collapses, laughing.
Giving that there's no reason to be taken aback.
A profound acceptance pervades him, he says. Even that he acted in accordance to the solution supplied to him by the Difference Engine, he bet his chances upon the glistening of his own soul.
Addressing 'the red haired girl,' he gives that for some reason, it doesn't feel as if they're strangers. (edited)
Indeed, she feels to him like an old friend, who walked alongside him somewhere distant.
He wonders if it's his imagination. (edited)
Nay, he says; that shouldn't be the case.
Therefore, he entrusts his obligations to Guda without regret.
Even that he betrayed his promise to protect Kaoruko, he desires that she be safe. By the sacrifice of his life does he entrust her to Guda's care.
Kintoki gives that even if Babbage doesn't say it, he wouldn't permit anyone to harm Murasaki.
However, Kintoki points out that having lost her Servant, Murasaki is no longer qualified as a Tenran Musha.
Therefore, nobody should further target her. (edited)
Kintoki asks Babbage why he would in the knowledge of this nevertheless engage them in a deathmatch.
Addressing all of them, Babbage tells them not to forsake their dreams. There isn't at all a need for them to do so.
Even that within this World, dreams are as the most ephemeral of existences.
They aren't to be cast aside.
Guda: "Dreams ... ?"
Babbage gives that he himself is as a Heroic Spirit engraved unto the World following the collapse of his dreams. It's precisely on this account that he feels the need to say this.
He gives that they should ever persist in pushing themselves forth, irrelevant of difficulty or anguish. It's fine that they occasionally come to halt, or take a rest — but abandoning their dreams is alone impermissible. If they come to a halting, it's fine that they at some point resume their course.
Dreams, he says, are to be armored in the steel of one's ideals. If they can achieve this, they'll certainly persist in their advance.
Next arrow:
In her diary, Murasaki writes of the death of her Servant; that the Command Seals that marked her amongst the Tenran Musha vanished with his passing.
She gives that perhaps the people of the Miyako would be glad at the vanquishing of the monstrosity of steel.
It isn't false that indeed a strong warrior vanquished the crimson-eyed monstrosity.
However, she bears the secret knowledge that that man was no monstrosity.
He consumed nobody, and protected her.
In the present:
Murasaki gives her greetings to the party before departing to the Palace for work.
After she leaves, Guda comments that she's only just acting as if she's fine.
Danzou noticed that corners of her eyes were red from crying. She thinks it likely that Murasaki wasn't able to get much sleep last night.
Kintoki contradicts Danzou, giving that she'll be fine.
He says that being as she says so herself, they should take her at her word.
Pretending to be spirited is at times a manner of rousing oneself to action — an armor of words.
That being the case, he says, Murasaki is indeed clad in a splendid armor.
Thinking back on Babbage's words, Kintoki says:
"To armor one's dreams in the steel of one's ideals, hm?"
"That's cool. That's really cool."
"Someday, I'd like to say that to somebody, but —" (edited)
"... that sort of thing is beyond me."
"What are dreams? What is it that I want to do?"
"It's no good. I'm empty."
"It's my body alone that's gotten big."
"The important bits on the inside are hollow." (edited)
"Things now are different from the way they were back when I was in the mountains. Back then, everything was simple, and I could do as I pleased."
"Laugh; rage; eat; sleep. That was my entire life." (edited)
"What is it that's off? What's insufficient?"
"These months and years that I've been charged with protecting the Miyako as one among the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu ..."
"I don't get it!" (edited)
"If it's like this, I can't possibly —"
"I'm not worthy to qualify as a Tenran Musha."
"I'm empty. A purpose for me to fight is nowhere to be found."
"I want one. I truly do."
"A dream. Whatever's fine. I want one."
"'Seigi' — was it? Guda."
"That one's good. I'll say that that's the one ... but I ain't got a core." (edited)
4
"Old Man Babbage had it. I envy him."
"Dreams, delusions — a dream clad in steel!"
"I don't know the right or left of it. but that; that was brilliant in no small way —"
"Right, that was uh ... the feeling I got was, well, that. You know, that."
"That old guy was Golden!"
"Isn't that the case, Guda?"
Guda: "... I think so as well."
4
fallacies 07-Dec-20 03:10 AM

General Type-Moon Discussion Thread 2: Unlimited Titles Works! (PLE...
Oh that make sense Seiba and Sheba ,oh how stupid I was, it look like my question confusing Tyrant164 .Tks for telling him that. Easy mistake to make. Speaking of Artoria,can't wait for Lostbelt 6.
fallacies 07-Dec-20 12:38 PM
Chapter 6
Somewhere, Raikou tells somebody that being on the rooftop is dangerous.
She compares them to Kintoki.
The person she's speaking with laughs.
She tells Raikou that she won't fall, whether it be from a rooftop or atop a wall. Rather, it's the gentleman egg who would fall. (edited)
Raikou asks the girl if the gentleman egg fell from a rooftop.
To this, the girl gives that it wasn't from a rooftop, but from atop a wall.
And when he fell, he shattered, and couldn't be put back together again.
Addressing Raikou by name, the girl tells Raikou not to be afraid.
She isn't the gentleman egg. Rather, there isn't here a gentleman egg at all.
Thus, nobody will be injured.
Raikou gives that if she says so, it must be true.
Mother believes her, that nobody will be hurt.
Giving that it's mysterious, Raikou says that when speaking to her, she feels as if she's reverted to how she was long ago.
Innocent, absent of the knowledge of sin. (edited)
fallacies 07-Dec-20 02:00 PM
Not carrying a blade, she says; not seeking martial prowess.
Back when she was merely Monjyumaru (文殊丸, Raikou's childhood name), who was nobody at all.
The girl tells Raikou that she is herself, and Monjyumaru remains within her.
Raikou asks the girl if that's the case, and laughs, giving that she shouldn't be teasing mother. (edited)
However, the girl tells her that what she says is certainly the case. She knows it.
Raikou gives that if Kintoki were about, he would probably get along with the girl. She thinks that at present, he's probably wandering about somewhere.
The girl asks if she's referring to Sakata Kintoki, (Kaidoumaru) of the mountains of Ashigara. (edited)
Raikou gives that the girl seems quite familiar with him. Indeed, both names refer to him.
In childhood, he was called as the Kaidoumaru of Ashigara, in the Country of Sagami.
The divine child of the Crimson Dragon (赤龍, sekiryuu) upon the mountains; an onigo (鬼子, "oni child") of mighty strength. (edited)
But these days, she gives, he's Kintoki.
Shumenosuke-Sakata-no-Kintoki (主馬佑坂田金時).
Her child.
The girl says she can't be certain of it, but that child hasn't any need for "us."
She tells Raikou that she is herself — the her that exists for Raikou alone.
She gives that she's Raikou's friend — a friend to the lonely Raikou; to Monjyumaru-san.
Raikou seems confused at her words.
The girl gives that there's nothing to worry about.
She gives that Raikou's Kintoki is already a grown man; that her child is a man who fights.
Though once upon a time, Kintoki would certainly have been close to "us," the Kintoki of the present has forgotten such a thing.
Therefore, she says, it's fine that she's Raikou's friend alone.
Next arrow:
At the 3rd quarter of the Hour of the Ox, oni manifest in the southern districts of Heian-Kyo.
The muddied gushing forth of power strikes fear into the hearts of nobles, warriors, and peasants alike.
Circumventing even the great Bounded Field laid forth by the onmyouji Abe-no-Seimei, the run wild beneath the moonlight, in the Miyako of night.
Destroying. Pillaging. Trampling.
The monstrosities that cry at the Moon! It would indeed be these what are called as the kings of the youmono mamono (妖物魔物); what stand at the apex of monstrosities.
That what laughs; that what dominates the darkness.
Oni —
The fangs of hedonism what threaten the Miyako; what laugh and pillage any and all.
Would they be as keshou or the supernatural, or merely creatures of fiction?
They boast of monstrous strength that can easily crush walls, and a hide that repels even blades of steel.
There are those of massive form, and those what are small.
Ugly and frightening; noble and beautiful.
What comes to pillage this time is as a hideous gigant of swelling flesh, but it acts in the service of —
— two beautiful oni, what laugh at the bloodsplatter.
fallacies 07-Dec-20 03:16 PM
In a certain street, there's a splatter of blood.
Ibaraki laughs at how weak and fragile her victim was.
She gives that even were the people of Miyako were to gather a hundred blades, not a single one would penetrate unto the oni of her clan.
The police forces she's fighting call a withdraw, giving that they aren't a match for the oni. (edited)
They intend to call the warriors of the Genji, as the raiding band this time around isn't of the typical strength.
They suppose that these must be the oni of Ooe.
Ibaraki calls for her subordinate Toraguma (虎熊, lit. "tiger bear") to scatter the police forces with a kick. (edited)
Shuten gives that Ibaraki appears to be in a good mood. To this, Ibaraki answers that it's all thanks to the arm that Shuten prepared for her.
Ibaraki praises Shuten as the leader of the oni of Ooe.
Shuten gives that she hasn't any interest in leading the oni, as it's a bother. She'll leave that sort of thing to Ibaraki.
Shuten: "Chieftain of the Ooe, Ibaraki-Douji! Aah, that sounds good. That being the case, I leave it to you."
Ibaraki is doubtful, but before she further comments, Shuten changes the topic.
She gives that ordering Toraguma and Hoshiguma (星熊, lit. "star bear") is fine and all, but it's a bit of a waste to destroy everything and not to consume.
It's fine to destroy walls and buildings, but it'd be good to consume arms and legs as one wishes.
However, Shuten reiterates, be it as in regards to men or beasts or keshou (化生, lit. "incarnations"; another term for youkai) or kai'i, to merely kill and not at all to consume is forbidden.
Shuten gives that Ibaraki should recall the consequences of violating this taboo.
At her word, Ibaraki is uneasy, and doesn't properly answer. Shuten calls for her to clearly respond.
Reluctantly, Ibaraki gives that that what are killed shall certainly be consumed.
She gives that if there isn't an intention to consume, killing shan't be prosecuted.
Ibaraki: "S- See, Shuten? This time I haven't yet slaughtered at all! I've merely destroyed!"
fallacies 07-Dec-20 03:52 PM
"Flesh that suits my tastes isn't so easy to come by! Truly, the stench of men ever disgusts me!" (edited)
fallacies 07-Dec-20 04:32 PM
She gives that earlier at the bridge — the Ichijyo Modoribashi (一条戻橋), she thought she came across meat to her liking, but —
She apologizes, giving that she won't further speak of it. (edited)
Shuten gives that Ibaraki is cute. When Ibaraki appears confused by her words, Shuten gives that she's quite the hard worker; that tonight, she intends to get a glimpse of Ibaraki's good points. (edited)
She gives that she herself occasionally likes the taste of human flesh, but she'll wait on the matter without expectation. She might not have the time to spare tonight, in any case.
Ibaraki asks her what she means.
Tonight, says Shuten, they'll be playing a bit of a different game than the usual.
They won't be seeking out pretty clothes, kidnapping beautiful children, or stealing treasures. They likewise won't be stealing the best wine in the Miyako.
Also, they won't be playing with the blond, blue-eyed brat.
This is the first that Ibaraki's heard of this.
She asks Shuten what she intended to do tonight, if not any of the above.
Shuten asks if Ibaraki wasn't listening when she explained it. However, rather than waiting for an answer, she gives that it's fine that Ibaraki isn't aware of it.
Ibaraki doesn't like to be left out, and asks Shuten to tell her — wondering if it has anything to do with their "guest."
Shuten gives that that's indeed the case; their "guest" has business in the Miyako.
Addressing their "guest," she asks if that isn't the case.
Paracelsus appears, giving that that is indeed the case.
Shuten: "Ah, so you were over there, I see. This astralization of yours is quite convenient, but somewhat troublesome."
Ibaraki is gleeful that Shuten referred to Paracelsus is "troublesome," thinking that he'll certainly die. Privately, though, she wishes his death from the bottom of her heart.
She dislikes that he suddenly appeared; that he's constantly in Shuten's company, bearing an expression as if such a thing were a matter of course. She thinks his behavior quite insolent.
3
At Shuten's reiteration that it's troublesome, Paracelsus apologizes, giving that he'll be more attentive in the future. (edited)
Privately, Ibaraki thinks that he won't have any 'future' to speak of. She fantasizes that Shuten will slaughter him instantly.
However, Shuten gives that she doesn't really mind.
Ibaraki is surprised and disappointed.
She doesn't understand why Shuten isn't slaughtering Paracelsus for his insolence.
Shuten gives that Paracelsus can do as he pleases. Addressing Ibaraki, she asks her, "Isn't that right?"
Shuten gives that it's on account of Paracelsus that they were so easily able to circumvent the Bounded Field of the Miyako — even that the Moon wasn't yet in the correct phase. (edited)
Under normal circumstances, she gives, they can only really infiltrate the Miyako once a month.
The opportunity this month was expended by Ibaraki in her encounter on the Ichijyo Modoribashi.
And it's about once every half year or so that larger oni like Toraguma and Hoshiguma can be brought along.
Isn't that troublesome, she asks.
Ergo, it's all thanks to their guest that they could ignore the usual strictures.
She gives that their guest is quite skilled.
Paracelsus gives that he's glad to be of service — addressing Shuten as his Master. (edited)
Elsewhere in the city, in the midst of evacuations, Kintoki, Guda, and Danzou have encountered one among the large-scale oni. (edited)
Kintoki gives that it's quite strange that such a large oni would be able to venture so deep into the Miyako.
The Bounded Field deployed by Abe-no-Seimei over the four sides of the Miyako are substantially difficult for larger oni to breach.
Only by considerably suppressing their power can infiltrators enter the Miyako — perhaps once or twice a month, under normal circumstances. (edited)
Here, the party encounters the ringleaders; Ibaraki catches sight of Kintoki. (edited)
Danzou warns that Guda shouldn't take this lightly, as the Shuten and Ibaraki of the Heian Era should alike to Kintoki possess no recollections of Chaldea.
Furthermore, she gives, per her measurements, their mana capacity far exceeds that as of the Saint Graphs registered at Chaldea.
Giving again that the oni are normally restricted to sneaking about, Kintoki gives that they seem to be doing better than usual tonight. He asks Shuten what her intentions are.
Asked about her intentions, Shuten reveals the Command Seals on her left hand, giving that it should be obvious.
At this, Guda asks aloud if Shuten would be the 6th Tenran Musha.
fallacies 07-Dec-20 05:50 PM
Danzou gives that, thinking on it, Shuten-Douji would indeed be as one amongst the notable figures borne of power as of the Heian Era.
Assessing Kintoki and party, Shuten gives that she imagined the boy might be in the company of a Jutsusha / Caster; but that it seems that reality may somewhat differ.
That said, 'the red-haired girl over there' has to Shuten the look of a Caster. (edited)
She requests to have a better glimpse of Guda's eyes, as she senses something strange from her.
Shuten exudes a violet haze of energy, and gradually approaches Guda.
Guda feels herself overcome by a heavy weight. Noticing this, Kintoki gives that she shouldn't directly gaze at Shuten; it isn't safe for humans to set eyes upon oni. He apologizes for not mentioning it earlier.
Rather, this isn't applicable to all oni. Shuten happens to be particularly dangerous.
Guda gives that it's fine. This isn't the first that something like this has happened to her.
Arriving before Guda, Danzou tells her to get behind her.
Guda gives that versus the encounter with Aphrodite, whatever it is that Shuten's doing is just within the bounds of her resistance.
Danzou gives that though she's heard that the Mystic Code that Guda is clad in is something that's gone through quite a number iterations as to improve its defensive capabilities, it's from from perfect in the capacity of entirely defending against thaumaturgical effects.
She asks for Guda to fall back.
Shuten gives that that's no fun. However, noticing that Danzou is a Servant — if not necessarily of the Caster / Jutsusha Class — she asks if Kintoki's perhaps been left out in the cold. (edited)
Laughing, Ibaraki gives that she was originally angered that Shuten would be selected by some ritual that the humans devised. However, finding that one amongst the Four Heaven Kings would fail to be selected as a participant amuses her to no end.
Now in a good mood, Ibaraki decides to have a go at Kintoki, and tells Shuten not to interfere.
She calls for Toraguma to attack.
As Toraguma approaches, Guda gives that it doesn't feel as if Ibaraki's willing to listen to reason.
Kintoki remarks that though she's a bit more decent than the other oni, at the end of the day, oni are oni. Her mischief is on a completely different scale from that of a human brat.
He gives that he'll halt the oni here. Even that he doesn't capture them, he'll at the least drive them off.
fallacies 07-Dec-20 06:49 PM
After combat:
Ibaraki still seems to want to go at it, but Shuten calls for her to stop — asking her how long she intends on playing. (edited)
Privately, Kintoki observes that there isn't any sign of Shuten's Caster, and wonder if she's without a Servant like him. (edited)
Ibaraki backs down at Shuten's word, but gives that if there's anyone 'playing,' it's 'those over there.' (edited)
Danzou wonders if Ibaraki is referring to her. To this, Ibaraki gives that the marionette absent of any of blood is still decent, as she properly engaged in the fight.
However, Ibaraki asks what's up with Kintoki and 'the girl.' She gives that it's as they weren't taking her seriously at all; as if they didn't have any intention to claim her head.
Guda calls Ibaraki by name, but this angers her. She tells Guda not to so lightly invoke her name. (edited)
Kintoki replies that he could say the same of Ibaraki — asking her if she's eaten anyone tonight.
Ibaraki tells Kintoki to mind his own business.
Kintoki gives that if it's acting in moderation, it's the on both sides.
Kintoki: "Ain't that the case, Shuten!?"
Kintoki gives that Shuten quite favors the introduction of 'new games.' Noting again that her Command Seals mark her as one amongst the Tenran Musha, Kintoki asks her what happened to her Jutsusha / Caster. (edited)
Perhaps she doesn't have one?
Shuten laughs.
She asks him if he's implying that she isn't the sort to go the full length.
Unfortunately, she says, that isn't the case. She calls for Paracelsus to manifest.
Guda identifies him on sight. At this, Paracelsus asks if they've encountered one another before. (edited)
Seeing Paracelsus, Kintoki remarks:
"So you've got a Heroic Spirit as well, huh? I just want to say that I'm absolutely not envious of you!"
With some taunting on Shuten's side, things advance toward yet another engagement. Kintoki declares that he'll end the Tenran Grail War here and now. Ibaraki thinks that she'll be able to have another go at Kintoki and company, but Shuten gives that she and Toraguma should be good and stay at the sidelines. This time around, it's her and Caster's turn. (edited)

Danzou gives that numerous hostile signatures have instantiated. She believes them to be homunculi.
fallacies 07-Dec-20 08:22 PM
After combat:
Shuten calls for Paracelsus to prepare a withdraw.
At this, Paracelsus gives that if a mass alike to that of Toraguma is accounted for, he won't be able to specify the destination. He asks Shuten if she's alright with that. She answers in the affirmative.
Paracelsus: "— O Earth. Form a pathway."
Shuten's party vanishes. Danzou gives that their mana signatures are lost.
She remarks that this would be something alike but distinct from the high-speed movement permitted via Command Seal in a normal Grail War.
She hypothesizes that it may be composite of a spell protocol for high-speed movement, and another as to obstruct a target's vision — a movement of multiple individuals tailored for withdraw from a zone of combat. (edited)
fallacies 07-Dec-20 08:37 PM
It's reminiscent of the Doton no Jutsu (土遁の術) employed upon the Continent in ancient times (the Shang Dynasty) by the great tactician, Tàigōng Wàng (太公望). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jiang_Ziya (edited)
As a reference not included in the game script, note that outside the context of Naruto, Ton-Jutsu (遁術) generally refers to techniques that make use of assorted elements and environmental factors as to escape pursuit, or to obstruct pursuers. By default, they involve concealing the figure in some manner. Ton-Jutsu are often said to be utilized by ninja, but in fact have their origins in Chinese folklore. https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/%E9%81%81%E8%A1%93 (edited)
Hearing Danzou's explanation, Kintoki is surprised that Paracelsus was even able to transport something as large as Toraguma-Douji (虎熊童子). (edited)
Guda requests that Danzou scout about in the vicinity, giving that they shouldn't lose sight of Shuten and company.
Danzou gives that she'll attempt to do so via astralization.
However, on account that if she remains in astralization for an extended period, she might be imposed with a penalty as well, she'll only attempt to pursue for a limited duration — roughly surveying the interior of the Palace as well. (edited)
Kintoki is unhappy with the outcome of the match, giving that this was his loss. However, he says that the next time, he's certainly going to win. (edited)
Next arrow:
In the morning, the member of Murasaki's household that provides meals to Guda and party notices that Danzou is missing.
Kintoki informs her that Danzou is out camping — thinking that if he were to inform her that Danzou is out on an independent reconnaissance mission, she might be worried.
Kintoki tells the woman that Danzou should be back soon. However, he warns that it's best that nobody goes out after sunset — giving that there may be oni afoot. (edited)
Thinking aloud, he notes that should be a Bounded Field deployed over the house, though. To this, the woman gives that since the time of the previous head of house — Fujiwara-no-Tametoki (藤原為時), Murasaki's father — the mansion's Bounded Field hasn't once failed. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fujiwara_no_Tametoki
Kintoki remarks that it must be multi-layered.
He asks the woman if Murasaki is in.
Momentarily, the woman's expression changes to worry, but replies that Murasaki has been off at the Palace since dawn. (edited)
Murasaki apparently gave that it isn't permissible that she worries the Empress.
Kintoki praises Murasaki's loyalty. However, still worried, he asks the woman if she departed to the Palace by ox carriage. When the woman answers in the affirmative, Kintoki gives that in that case, the ofuda furnished to the ox carriage by Abe-no-Seimei should serve as an obstruction.
Further, he has faith that if Murasaki safely arrives at the Palace, the Bounded Field deployed there should be sufficient even to ward off Casters. (edited)
So saying, Kintoki gives that all that remains to await Danzou's report.
Once the woman leaves, Kintoki gives that he's surprised Shuten-Douji was selected as one amongst the Tenran Musha. However, being as Murasaki was likewise selected, he supposes it isn't a surprise that anyone borne of power could be selected.
Guda comments that it doesn't seem to be the first time that Kintoki encountered the oni. She asks if he's acquainted with them.
Kintoki briefly provides an explanation of the oni of Ooe, giving that though the clan isn't at present large, it might at some point grow to become an army.
He gives that even Abe-no-Seimei once declared Ibaraki and Shuten the greatest threats to the Miyako.
On the matter of consuming humans — he gives that he doesn't know the circumstance with Ibaraki, but at the very least, Shuten formerly did so.
For whatever reason, she isn't consuming humans at present, but Kintoki feels that this is some manner of mischief.
Guda asks if in that case, Shuten is no longer killing humans?
Kintoki gives that that seems to be the case for the time being.
She's considerably suppressed her exercise of strength.
Kintoki gives that just half a year ago, Shuten tore his left arm to shreds. It's only by the efforts of Abe-no-Seimei that he was able to reattach it.
He gives that whether it be man or beast, to Shuten-Douji, all the lives that exist as of Utsushiyo (現世) are as alike to her toys.
Shuten is called as the leader of the oni — the oni most proximate to Makoku (魔国, "the country of aberrations").
Kintoki believes that she'll inevitably unleash her slaughter upon the Miyako.
Kintoki is for a moment contemplative. When Guda asks him what's wrong, he gives that perhaps it's proper form for a warrior of the Genji not to retreat from battle until they claim the head of their opponent.
However, Kintoki feels that there's something that doesn't sit right with him about that.
Even that many a time, he's engaged Shuten with axe in hand, as Ibaraki stated, it wasn't to the intention of claiming her head.
Rhetorically, he asks, if he were to behead an oni who refrained from eating humans, and merely laughed, would he be able to breakfast the following morning as if nothing were wrong? (edited)
Answering his own question, he gives that he wouldn't.
Or to put it a different way, he says — that wouldn't be Golden.
-
Sometime after Guda and Kintoki finish eating, Danzou returns.
She gives that she was able to track the oni, but that they seemed to arbitrarily pop up, wreak havoc, and just as arbitrarily vanish away.
Kintoki isn't certain what to make of her report. If the oni have a clear objective in mind, he gives, why wouldn't they head directly to their target?
Danzou gives that though the Genji and other warrior clans are presently deployed across the Miyako, no special security measures have been implemented as of the Palace.
Furthermore, Murasaki didn't encounter any oni on her way to the Palace.
At the news that the Palace hasn't enacted any special measures, Kintoki wonders if it can be taken that the Minister of the Left acknowledges Shuten-Douji as one amongst the Tenran Musha.
fallacies 07-Dec-20 10:04 PM
Plotting out the locations where the oni have manifested on a map of the Miyako, and then drawing lines between their appearances, the party discovers that the lines intersect at a particular location. (edited)
Danzou poses that their strategy is perhaps to act upon the distribution of the security forces — rendering that the warriors won't gather in a particular location. (edited)
Ergo, it wasn't as to obscure their target that they appeared to pop up at random.
Kintoki seems to recognize the site at the intersection of the lines. Noting this, Guda asks him whose mansion is situated there. (edited)
Kintoki answers that it's the home of Abe-no-Seimei.
1
Next arrow:
The narration gives that the mansion of Abe-no-Seimei is also immediately besides the mansion of Minamoto-no-Yorimitsu (源頼光). (edited)
At the designated location, Kintoki apologizes for failing to mention this — though it wasn't entirely a dishonesty on his part. (edited)
Given that at present, Abe-no-Seimei is missing, it seems unlikely that the oni would be targeting an empty mansion.
That being the case, the more likely target is the home of Raikou.
Guda recalls that there's a good chance that Raikou is herself a Tenran Musha.
Danzou gives that prior the arrival of the oni, perhaps they should attempt to negotiate with Raikou; to encourage her to retire from the Tenran Grail War.
Alternatively, Danzou poses, perhaps she could be convinced to back the cancellation of the ritual in her capacity as a leader of the Genji. (edited)
Kintoki is oddly unresponsive. Privately, he's attempting to work up the courage to step into Raikou's home.
However, before he can knock on the gates, they open.
A small girl steps forth, welcoming him back home.
Kintoki is a bit shocked, asking where this kid popped out from.
At his question, Danzou answers that she emerged just now from Raikou's home.
3
The small girl gives that it's good that Kintoki's home.
Addressing him as Kintoki, the girl asks him why he's just standing there — giving that he should enter, as his mother's waiting.
Guda asks Kintoki if he knows this girl. Kintoki answers in the negative.
He's never met her before.
Stepping toward Danzou, he whispers, asking her whether this kid is perhaps actually a Caster.
Danzou gives that the girl's signature seems not to be that of a Heroic Spirit.
Guda (whispering): "You don't sense anything at all, right ... ?"
Danzou gives that she's likewise unable to discern the presence of mana. She asks if there's any reason to be suspicious about this child. To her question, Kintoki gives that it's nothing. (edited)
The girl beckons for them to enter, and they follow after her.
As she calls for them to follow after her and runs along, Kintoki calls for her not to run inside the building, as Raikou's going to get mad.
Danzou remarks that even though the mansion of Genji is fortified to such an extent that it seems alike to a fortress, somehow the fact that a child can run about that dulls the sharpness of the atmosphere.
Even so, there are a number of fully armored guards situated behind the gates; and even within the building, there are a number of warriors in light armor.
She asks if the mansion isn't for some reason at combat readiness.
Or perhaps, she gives, the guards are situated not to engage on the offensive, but rather as to protect.
Guda offers that perhaps this is a countermeasure against Shuten's party; or otherwise something to do with the Tenran Grail War. (edited)
Privately, Kintoki observes that the amount of security seems to have significantly increased since Raikou began to seclude herself.
So thinking, Kintoki calls out to the girl, asking when it was that she started to live here.
However, it's only after speaking that he realizes he's lost sight of her.
He apologizes, giving that he isn't is the best shape at the moment.
He tells himself to get a grip; that he's well acquainted to the mansion.
Here, however, Raikou approaches, apparently angry.
She asks him if he still isn't used to her home.
Kintoki is for a moment at a loss for words, and attempts to explain that Raikou's misunderstanding things.
The presence exuded by Raikou is cold enough to seemingly freeze the air. (edited)
Danzou whispers to Guda that it isn't the same as killing intent (殺気, sakki, lit. "killing ki") or kenki (剣気, lit. "sword air"; the presence / ki exuded from a sword), but all the same, it's making it difficult to move — even that Danzou is a karakuri marionette. She asks that Guda pay mind to regulate her breathing.
Raikou welcomes Kintoki home. She gives that she's happy that he's safely returned. Further, she won't pursue the matter that he stayed elsewhere without her permission.
Kintoki tries to make excuses, but Raikou gets him to shut up.
Moving on, she asks 'the two women over there' who they are.
Or rather, what they are.
Guda thinks that Raikou's gaze is like ice.
Whispering, Danzou notes that she can't discern any of the motherly nature embodied in the Saint Graph she's familiar with. (edited)
Rather, she feels that if their answers are in the slightest bit unsatisfactory, their bodies will be instantly cut to pieces. (edited)
3
Raikou asks Kintoki to tell her who these two young women are.
She'll decide how to act based on his response.
Kintoki addresses her initially as Raikou-san — but changes his mind, referring to her instead as Haha-ue (母上, formal term for "mother"). (edited)
Raikou is silent for a moment, but then blushes.
Stuttering, she asks him what he intends by suddenly referring to her as Haha-ue after so long a time — in front of strangers. (edited)
Kintoki gives that these two are new friends of his. Setting that aside, though, he'd like to know who the small girl who greeted him at the door was.
Raikou is suddenly in a good mood.
Switching over to smothering Kintoki with love, she begins to talk a lot of nonsense about how he's gotten more muscular since departing and therefore needs a new set of clothing (even though he's only been away for a couple of days).
However, after yet again noticing Guda and Danzou, she reiterates the question as to who they are. When Kintoki again gives that they're his friends, Raikou's mood shifts once more. (edited)
Raikou: "Friends, did you say?"
Kintoki: "Yeah."
Raikou: "And both are girls?"
2
3
2
Guda: "It's not like that, Raikou-san. W- We're just friends."
Raikou smiles, giving that in that case, she's relieved. (edited)
But here, her expression changes, and she asks Kintoki if this doesn't happen to be the first time that he's brought friends home.
Apparently extremely happy, she presses Guda and Danzou into sharing dinner with her.
