General Type-Moon Discussion Thread 2: Unlimited Titles Works! (PLE...
Guys , Who is more dangerous? Kama or kiara? They are equals in strength as they are halves of the same beast. It basically depends on which one wakes up firsthand what the situation is. Kiara can be quite dangerous even without being the beast, while Kama is divinity
fallacies 08-Dec-20 12:52 PM
Chapter 7
Early evening. Raikou invites the party to dig into the dinner prepared for them.
Assessing Guda and Danzou, she gives that their attire is quite unconventional as of the Miyako. She supposes that the style may be something of the vicinity Hakata.
Presuming that they may be visitors from a western nation, she gives that she hopes the meal is suited to their tastes.
Guda gives that the meal is rather different from what they were treated to at Murasaki's — giving that there are quite a number of meat dishes.
Danzou comments that the meals at Murasaki's mansion were primarily centered around rice, provided with soup, dried fish, seaweed, and so forth.
Guessing that maybe it's to do with Murasaki being of the Buddhist faith or something, Danzou observes that there was very little in the way of meat.
Kintoki comments that the warriors of the Genji are from their roots fundamentally different from the nobility.
Danzou gives that being as the meal provided was of quite a bit of volume — befitting a young woman like Guda.
Being as Guda would be exhausted from the combat that she engages in on a day-to-day basis, Danzou gives that it's necessary for Guda to replenish herself on protein. (edited)
Seeing that Guda is eating quite a bit, Raikou gives that sitting besides Kintoki, Guda seems almost alike to a younger sister to him. (edited)
Raikou gives that if Guda is fine with it, she doesn't mind taking her into her household.
7
Changing the subject, Kintoki asks about the young girl the party encountered earlier.
Here, the girl enters the room with sake, saying that she's heard that Kintoki quite favors the drink, and so brought some from the kitchens. (edited)
Kintoki thanks her for it.
He asks her where she's been until now.
Raikou answers that the girl favors playing on her own.
The girl gives that as she knows a lot of games, playing on her own isn't any trouble. However, she'd like to play with somebody, and asks if Kintoki would be alright playing with her.
Kintoki gives that as thanks for leading them into the mansion, he'll do so.
The girl asks Danzou: "What about you?"
Danzou replies that if she has a moment to spare between her duties.
The girl seems happy to hear this. Turning to Guda, she asks: "And what about you?"
Guda gives that she'd be happy to play.
However, says Guda, at the moment, there's something that she needs to do.
The girl is disappointed.
Here, Kintoki again asks of Raikou who among the men of the household this girl is the daughter of. He gives that even though he's never seen her before, it seems that she's quite familiar with the mansion and grounds.
Alternatively, he asks, is the girl perhaps another child that Raikou's taken in?
Raikou initially gives that that isn't the case, but stops herself, giving instead that it is indeed something along those lines.
Kintoki asks then if the girl is a relative of Minamoto-no-Mitsunaka (源満仲) — Raikou's father. To this, Raikou replies that her father knows nothing of this child.
It was of her own judgment that she brought the child into this household.
Guda gives that if she recalls correctly, Minamoto-no-Mitsunaka would be the patriarch of the Genji of the Country of Settsu.
Kintoki wonders privately if the girl is indeed Raikou's Caster.
He resolves to broach the topic aloud, as to turn the discussion toward the Tenran Grail War and the matter of Shuten's incursion.
For whatever reason, the girl seems slightly scared, and grabs on to Raikou's clothing. At this, Raikou gives that there's nobody here that will hurt her, as this is Raikou's home.
She asserts that neither Kintoki nor his friends will render harm to her.
She asks Kintoki to confirm this.
Kintoki gives that he absolutely intends no harm.
Raikou is happy to hear this. However, here, her expression changes. To Guda and Danzou, she gives that for the time being she entrusts the girl to their care.
Thus, Danzou asks the girl to come to her side. Here, Raikou gives her thanks, and turns to a location elsewhere in the room — giving to an unknown observer that it's rude of them to conceal their form in silence.
Naming Tsuna, she asks for him to reveal himself.
2
fallacies 08-Dec-20 02:02 PM
Hearing this, Danzou asks Guda to get behind her as well.
Tsuna shows himself, giving that Raikou discerned his presence as expected. He apologizes for the intrusion.
He's surprised, as Raikou was able to detect him, even as he'd effected his invisibility (隠形, ongyou) in conjunction with the jutsu of a foreign land or otherworld.
Raikou gives that she'd heard of his exploits as of the ritual of the Tenran Grail War.
Tsuna apologizes for carelessly injuring Usui and Urabe.
Raikou gives that their injuries aren't a matter of Tsuna's carelessness. Rather, it was on account of their own inexperience that they were defeated.
Raikou gives that being as the ritual of the Tenran Grail War was a matter ordered by the Minister of the Left, Fujiwara-no-Michinaga, it's an honor that those of the Genji might qualify and thereby participate.
Thus, Tsuna has nothing to apologize for, and as an acting leader of the household, Raikou hasn't any intention as to punish him.
Acknowledging her position, Tsuna changes the topic, commenting that it seems as if Kintoki has once again permitted oni to escape.
As usual, he gives, Kintoki went lightly against the oni.
Tsuna gives that Kintoki should listen well; speaking not as a Tenran Musha, but rather as one amongst the Four Heavenly Kings, he offers that as protectors of the Miyako, their blades must not waver.
He gives that Kintoki's made a shameful showing, and that he should ask himself what it is that the warriors of the Genji are.
Kintoki: "What is it that the warriors of the Genji are, huh? How proper of you. In that case, have you asked yourself the same, Aniki?"
Tsuna observes that Kintoki still has quite the nerve, if he's willing to turn Tsuna's words around on him like that.
In reply to Kintoki's question, Tsuna gives that at the very least, he comprehends the nature of the warriors of the Genji a bit better than Kintoki does.
Addressing Raikou, Tsuna gives that he discerns here "something of a scent."
He asks that if this be the scent of a keshou (化生, lit. "incarnation"; again, another term for a youkai), how is it that Raikou has all this time failed to discern it?
Kintoki gives that there certainly is a noticeable scent.
However, Kintoki is surprised that Tsuna isn't aware of it.
This here, says Kintoki, isn't something unique to Keshou. Apparently, in the future, it'll be referred to as maryoku / mana.
Kintoki: "Isn't that right — Shuten!"
Shuten appears from the shadows, giving that things are moving a bit ahead of schedule.
Next arrow:
Danzou gives that she's confirmed a mana signature and the origin of the voice; it's in the western court.
Hearing Danzou's words, Kintoki leaps into the western court. Here, seeing Kintoki, Shuten gives that she hasn't at present any intention to play with him. Rather, she calls for Raikou to come out.
Ibaraki gives that there's no point in talking. Calling for Toraguma, she decides to move ahead and engage the Genji in combat.
Kintoki asks for Guda to support him with her spells, and for Danzou to protect the small girl.
Following Shuten to the rooftop, Kintoki gives that he'll leave Ibaraki and Toraguma to Tsuna and Raikou. Here, he'll be subduing Shuten himself.
fallacies 08-Dec-20 03:11 PM
After combat:
Danzou gives to Raikou that she'll protect the child; she asks that Raikou go out and help the other warriors.
The child says to Raikou that she'll be fine — that Raikou should go and help Kintoki, as she wouldn't be alright with losing her son.
Raikou replies that the girl is 'a dear friend' of hers as well. Danzou is confused at Raikou's wording.
Here, Medea manifests.
Danzou addresses her by name. To this, Medea asks if they're acquainted by the En of having participated together in a Grail War somewhere.
Setting that aside, Medea addresses the small child, giving that it seems that she's received a kindly Master. However, she warns, if the girl remains as she is, she won't be winning any battles. She asks rhetorically if the girl isn't already aware of that.
The girl answers in the affirmative. Here, Raikou places herself before the child, asking Medea who she is — giving that she won't permit Medea to more closely approach.
If Medea dares, Raikou gives that she'll cut her down.
Medea responds that the oni are already aware (of the girl's identity?) — whether it be by the observation of familiars, or per some clairvoyant ritual.
It's on this account that they circumvented the Bounded Field of the Miyako, and launched their current incursion.
Medea gives that Kintoki should be aware as well — that the child behind Raikou is her Caster.
Elsewhere in the mansion:
Tsuna and Ibaraki have engaged in combat.
To Ibaraki, Tsuna gives that it's meaningless for him to exchange blows with one who isn't even a Tenran Musha.
He orders her to return to the mountains.
At Ibaraki's confusion, he sheathes his sword, giving that she isn't his prey. (edited)
Ibaraki thinks that Tsuna is mocking her.
Ibaraki: "Am I an opponent insufficient for you to draw your blade against? To what extent will you insult me? I won't forgive it!"
She threatens to eat him to the bone; but changes her mind, giving that she'll discard her bones, leaving them along the Avenue of Suzaku for everyone to see.
At this, Tsuna asks her the number of humans she's consumed since taking residence in the mountains at Ooe.
Or, he asks, is it the case that she hasn't since tasted a single drop of human blood?
Ibaraki tells him to shut up.
In reply, he asks if she doesn't yet remember who she is — how she was born; how she was raised.
He asks her if she doesn't recall what occurred at "that mansion."
What it is that she did to "that person."
5
Repeatedly, she tells him to shut up.
Ibaraki gives that she'll repay Tsuna for what he did to her arm. Her target this time isn't him.
Hearing this, Danzou calls Raikou's name.
Ibaraki appears behind Raikou, cutting at her neck. There's a spurt of blood — but after briefly gloating, Ibaraki realizes that it isn't Raikou who's collapsed before her, but some small girl she's never seen before.
Raikou is in tears, asking the small girl why she would protect her. (edited)
The child answers that long before being engraved in the capacity of a Heroic Spirit, "we" were acquainted with you (あなたたち, "you," addressing multiple individuals). (edited)
"Isn't it a matter of course that we would protect our friend ... ?"
Danzou apologizes that she wasn't able to protect the girl. (edited)
Nevertheless, the girl thanks Danzou, giving that this is fine; it's fine that she comes here to her end — because it isn't the case that "we" will come to vanish. (edited)
Raikou gives that the blood won't stop flowing. She believes that the injury has communicated to the girl's spiritual core.
Addressing the girl as Caster, Raikou asks her why she would do this.
Ibaraki is shaking. She doesn't understand why it is that the bleeding is a girl she's never seen before. She's certain that she swung her claw at Raikou.
She gives that she was only doing this for Shuten's sake — for the sake of all of the oni.
She seems traumatized at the sight of the bleeding child. When Tsuna prods her, she shrieks.
4
1
Here, Paracelsus manifests, giving that Ibaraki should return to the mountains with Toraguma.
He gives that she's worked hard. Rather, all of this was in accordance to the plan that he and Shuten laid out.
He tells her that she hasn't committed any error.
Paracelsus anticipated that Raikou's Caster would attempt to protect her. He apologizes to Ibaraki for not informing her in advance.
This was a plan established on the understanding that Ibaraki doesn't attack anyone who isn't amongst the security forces or the warriors of the Miyako.
1
He asks her to leave the rest to him.
Ibaraki is freaking out that she made a mistake. She isn't certain how she'll explain this to Shuten.
Paracelsus gives that Shuten will be happy with this outcome. He asks that Ibaraki rests easy.
Enacting a spell, he transports Ibaraki away.
Tsuna remarks that Shuten-Douji's Caster seems quite skilled.
To this, Paracelsus gives that he isn't a match for the childlike Heroic Spirit who harbored Fujiwara-no-Yorimitsu.
He finds it incredible that she could regulate her mana to such an extent as to minimize her signature as a Heroic Spirit.
Or perhaps, he gives, it might've been rendered by the use of her Noble Phantasm.
Paracelsus: "I see. If amongst the Heroic Spirits that express a childlike form, it were 'her,' such a thing could be rendered as possible." (edited)
"That what expresses numerous forms ..."
"And, that what doesn't bear a singular form."
"— if it were her, who is as an otogi-banashi (御伽話, "fairy tale) of infinite variation / a Nursery Rhyme." (edited)
3
Next arrow:
On the rooftop, Guda is shocked that the girl was in fact Nursery Rhyme.
She wants to descend into the mansion, but Shuten isn't yet suppressed.
Shuten asks Kintoki if he's noticed that the small girl at Raikou's side was in fact a Servant.
Kintoki gives that he had his suspicions.
However, he gives that as Raikou desires above all else to be as a mother, she would protect that girl, and never think to use her in the capacity of weapon.
It was thus that she secluded herself within her mansion; that she was so on guard against Guda and Danzou.
The increased security around the mansion was as to ward against a potential attack from a Tenran Musha.
Kintoki blames himself for introducing an opening in the defense that Raikou had erected.
Guda gives she likewise wasn't able to do anything, even as she was present.
Seeing Kintoki's anger at his negligence, Shuten taunts him for a bit, before asking him if he's finally resigned himself to the act of killing her. (edited)
She compares him to Ibaraki.
This isn't to do with the Tenran Grail War, but as 'friendly advice,' she gives in essence that he shouldn't be so restrained. (edited)
Or to elaborate, Shuten gives that she said something of the same to Ibaraki a little while ago.
She remarks that it seems that the stronger Kintoki grows, the further he gets from the savage Kaidoumaru of his youth.
But since long ago, she's known that he hasn't the resignation to kill or be killed.
Kintoki tells her shut up.
Here, the screen briefly flashes red with the sound of a heartbeat.
Guda senses something, and tells Kintoki that she has a bad feeling.
Kintoki: "You felt it as well, huh?"
Wondering for a moment what this cold presence is, he realizes that it's the Divine power of "that person."
He asks Shuten the extent to which she was aware of the circumstances.
Rather than replying, Shuten gives that it seems that it's time for her to depart.
Kintoki grabs ahold of Guda. At Guda's confusion, he apologizes, giving that Guda has to go down below. If she doesn't stop Raikou, Raikou's going to annihilate the Miyako. (edited)
He tells Guda to leave Shuten to him, and tosses Guda over the side of the roof.
Falling, Guda wonders why it seems as if it's taking longer than expected to reach the ground. (edited)
Curling up into a ball to protect her head, she safely drops into the rock garden, remarking that the drop wasn't as far as she imagined. (edited)
So saying, she runs off to where Raikou is.
Back on the rooftop, Shuten asks Kintoki if he's curious as to the extent to which she's aware of Raikou's circumstances.
She says that she knows everything about that cow. (edited)
Fujiwara-no-Yorimitsu, the strongest warrior in all the generations of the Genji.
The number of oni, tsuchigumo, and kai'i she's exterminated are countless.
However, says Shuten, it isn't Raikou who is capable of freely wielding that power within her. (edited)
Rather, it's 'the other personality' who slumbers in the depths of her heart.
"Within her blood, there sleeps the power of the God who preserveth the Monastery of Jetavana (祇園精舎, gion shoujya), whose name in Sanskrit is as Goma Grivaya Deva Raja (瞿摩掲唎婆耶提婆囉惹) — the Gozu Tennou (牛頭天王, "heavenly king of the ox head")!"
"Per the scriptures, it's said that his form is as alike to that of Taishaku-Ten (帝釈天) —" (edited)
"She is in other words as a demi-goddess inherited of the power of the God of Thunder who is as the Heavenly Emperor (天帝, tentei) / Indra. It is indeed this that would be as 'the other personality' of that cow." (edited)
"Her name is as Ushi-Gozen (丑御前)."
"Though normally, she slumbers ... if something were to happen — well, she would wake, would she not?"
Kintoki gives that "that person" is no longer; he himself vanquished her in their deployment to the eastern countries.
Or rather, he gives, she slumbers.
Shuten asks if that's indeed so. But so saying, Shuten challenges Kintoki to a proper duel.
If she's to win, she gives, she'll be launching a proper festival.
Grinning, she wonders at the destruction that'll be wrought by the power of Raijin (雷神) unrestrained, if it were here released.
She asks Kintoki to consider the death that would so descend — the indiscriminate slaughter of the nobility; the warriors; the peasants.
The lower classes; even the oni and the tsuchigumo. (edited)
The young and the old; the strong and the sickly.
Hundreds; thousands; tens of thousands — everyone would die.
Inside the mansion:
Raikou arms herself. Imbued with her mana, the atmosphere is electrified.
Forced to back away, Danzou gives that it's impossible to approach.
Paracelsus: "Wonderful. A Saint Graph Ascension (霊基再臨, reiki sairin; incidentally, 再臨, sairin, is lit. "another coming," as in "the second coming of Christ") — or perhaps I should call it as a Saint Graph Recarnation (霊基変生, reiki hensei; 変生, henjou, lit. "altered birth" — a Buddhist term that refers to a metamorphosis rendered by reincarnation)?" (edited)
"However, it would seem that the process is presently stalled as of an alteration of the flesh." (edited)
"As to maximize her capabilities and mana capacity, a complete metamorphosis of her psyche is necessary. That being the case —"
"It's presumptuous of me, but by the use of spell protocols, I'll be stimulating your psyche."
"Certainly, a vast amount of destruction shall be rendered, but —"
"But being as I've resolved never again to betray my Master ..." (edited)
Guda arrives, calling for Paracelsus not to enact the spell.
Danzou explains that after the young girl was critically injured while attempting to protect Raikou, Raikou began to iterate mana at an extremely high density — undergoing an alteration of her Saint Graph.
On Tsuna's orders, Medea attempted to heal the girl, but her condition doesn't look good.
Guda gives that she'll attempt to heal the girl with her Mystic Code as well.
Medea is confused that Guda's spell was able to render restoration, even that spell protocols of the class of the Age of Gods seemed not to be of much effect.
However, holding off on her curiosity, Medea asks Guda to pour her mana into the spell.
After several attempts, Danzou confirms that she's detected a vital response.
Or rather, she says, the girl's been restored to the extent that her vital response is strong enough to be discerned.
Medea gives, however, that her Spiritual Core has been critically damaged. Restorative magecraft would only be sufficient as to render a last exchange of words.
Guda gives that if it isn't sufficient, she'll activate her Mystic Code again.
The little girl gives her thanks.
Somehow, she's able to climb to her feet. Medea is surprised that she's even capable of such a thing, given that her Saint Graph is shattered.
The girl tells Guda that that's enough. She doesn't need Guda to provide her with further mana. Rather, if Guda is to continue, she'll be putting her own life at risk. (edited)
She tells Guda to use the rest of her mana to repair Danzou, as her spell should be able to do so.
She shifts in form, becoming as the Nursery Rhyme whose appearance Guda is familiar with.
Nursery Rhyme: "... Raikou. Monjyumaru."
"Can you hear me?" (edited)
"Don't be angry. It's fine that you don't get angry."
"Because, even that I here come to vanish, 'we' shall forever be within you." (edited)
"We are as otogibanashi (御伽話) / nursery rhymes, and will always exist as of the tales that you remember."
"Raikou, Raikou."
"I beg you, please listen to my voice."
"I'm your friend ..."
"However ..."
"I am not your child."
"Therefore, it's fine that you don't get angry on my behalf."
"Because, we've always been together."
Raikou seems to calm.
Raikou: "That, form of yours ... it's as you were when we first met ... the form of the otogibanashi ..." (edited)
Nursery Rhyme apologizes.
Raikou gives that it's she who should apologize, that Nursery Rhyme had to quietly accept her wish to be a mother — even that they've always been friends.
Shuten arrives within the mansion, disappointed that Ushi-Gozen didn't surface. She gives that she didn't imagine Raikou to be so uninteresting.
Kintoki arrives after her, forcing her back with his axe.
Paracelsus welcomes Shuten. At his word, Shuten asks him what happened here.
Paracelsus apologizes, giving that Raikou's Heroic Spirit was able to discern the nature of their strategy.
He gives that perhaps the plan was destined for failure from the start, on account that their opponent's identity was Nursery Rhyme.
Paracelsus: "Though in the capacity of a Heroic Spirit, she is as a manifestation of that of England, otogibanashi are as a matter that exists as of a diverse variation, both in the past and present — in the east or west."
"Naturally, they would exist as of this nation as well."
"Even that they aren't that from which is derived her existence in the capacity of a Heroic Spirit ... There's no mistake that they are as A Tale For Somebody's Sake / Nursery Rhyme."
"The ties between these two are profound — between her and Raikou-sama."
"The plan as to annihilate Heian-Kyo by way resurrecting Ushi-Gozen does here come to failure." (edited)
Shuten gives that she'd thought to make use of Tenran something-or-other to shatter the Miyako; but that it appears that things won't be as easy as imagined.
In any case, she gives, she might as well get rid of two Heroic Spirits here present.
Calling for Medea to support him, Tsuna prepares to eliminate Shuten.
However, before he can act, Kintoki calls for him to halt.
This entire situation came about on account of Kintoki's oversight. Therefore, he asks that Tsuna leaves the protection of Raikou and the child to him.
Hearing Kintoki's words, Tsuna sheathes his blade, giving that he'll observe as Kintoki makes good on his resolution.
Bored of the conversation, Shuten calls for Paracelsus to support her.
Paracelsus: "O you who are borne of strength. Who for the sake of thy dream do thirst; do strive; do claw against the soil."​ "Therefore, conquer. Therefore, kill."​ "If you seek to realize your wish, there is aside from forcing your way through by the strength that you bear no other path."​
"This would be as the battlefield of blood; the Limbo (辺獄, hengoku) what consumes Heroic Spirits succumbed to defeat."​ "— that what over the black sun presides, called as the Tenran Shiai Butai (天覧死合舞台, "the stage of the deathmatch presided over by the Skies")."​
"Mine true name be as Van Hohenheim Paracelsus! Mine sins; mine regrets — these shall hereby bring thy path to closure."​
"Laugh, O Kijin (鬼神, lit. "oni god"). Shine, O Daystar."​ "Come — for the sake of thy own wish."​ "— let that I here witness thy strength."​
fallacies 08-Dec-20 06:59 PM
After combat:
Rather than striking at Shuten with his last blow, Kintoki attacks Paracelsus.
Injured by the attack, Paracelsus gives that the lightning shattered his Spiritual Core.
Paracelsus gives that he's been completely defeated.
Addressing Paracelsus, Kintoki gives that he didn't mention it at their previous encounter, but the warriors of the Genji don't lose twice. This is especially true of the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu.
Paracelsus: "... I see."
Guda: "... we didn't have the chance to properly exchange words, but I'm aware of your truth, Paracelsus."
Paracelsus: "Ah, it can't be that —"
"I don't know if it was as of some other Grail War, but could it be that you're acquainted with another me ... ?"
Paracelsus gives that he won't ask about the details. So saying, he gives that he looks forward to when they next meet.
Addressing Shuten, he gives that at the very least, he'd like to apologize.
He enacts a spell on her. To this, Shuten gives that it seems he has a strong sense of duty.
Paracelsus asks Shuten to give his regards to Ibaraki and Toraguma, who returned home before her.
Further, he gives that he'd like to convey his apologies to Ibaraki.
Just before Shuten is transported away, he bids farewell to she who dances as of the Grail War by the fires of hedonism alone.
When she's gone, Paracelsus wishes all those present luck in combat — and not to be consumed by the aberration of the Grail. (edited)
When he vanishes, Nursery Rhyme gives that it's her turn now. She asks Raikou to hold her hand.
As her body begins to disintegrate, she gives that it's come — a sensation both familiar and unfamiliar. She wonders how many times she's experienced this.
She gives it's mysterious, being a Heroic Spirit. Even that she doesn't clearly recall her previous iterations, she has a feeling that the memories are ingrained within her to such an extent that she can't forget. (edited)
She wonders how many times she's repeated this process of meeting and parting.
Though, at the end of all ends, she's fine with reaching a conclusion (おしまい, oshimai, "the end").
Nursery Rhyme: "And if it's possible, a happily ever after ..." (edited)
1
The screen turns white, but Nursery Rhyme doesn't vanish.
She's confused.
2
Danzou observes that with the destruction of her core, her corpus of ether was in the process of entirely collapsing, and (per the normal circumstance) it should've resulted in a Heroic Spirit's departure from the manifest World. However, inexplicably, the process halted.
Medea assesses Nursery Rhyme's Saint Graph.
To her analysis, it would seem as if the damage to Nursery Rhyme's Spiritual Core has been restored.
Nursery Rhyme thought that she'd been damaged to the point that death was unavoidable — but somehow, it was circumvented.
Guda gives that she isn't certain what's going on, but that at the very least it's good that her injuries are healed.
Nursery Rhyme gives that perhaps it was on account of the mana that Guda supplied to her. She poses that perhaps they're tied by some manner of En.
She wonders if perhaps this situation has something to do with Kintoki.
Kintoki is confused.
She gives that perhaps it was on account that he was here present — a Hero of the children of the Orient.
Though it isn't as an otogibanashi of the Western Isle / a Nursery Rhyme, it is as a fragment of an otogibanashi / us.
Perhaps not as a tale for little girls — but nevertheless, Kintoki is as a brilliant light.
Perhaps by his light; by the lightning that he wielded — the breakages in her Spiritual Core were filled.
She isn't certain as to what happened, but asks him if he senses anything — addressing him as Ashigara-yama-no-Kintarou (足柄山の金太郎). (edited)
4
Kintoki isn't certain who this "Kintarou" person is supposed to be.
End Chapter.
fallacies 08-Dec-20 08:39 PM
https://forums.spacebattles.com/threads/general-type-moon-discussion-thread-2-unlimited-titles-works-please-read-the-threadmarks.795493/post-72481292
General Type-Moon Discussion Thread 2: Unlimited Titles Works! (PLE...
Hanafuda game is merely a game of memorization more than anything. Play enough and you'll remember every yaku you need to win against the AI to win without using Koi-Koi and NPs. You can win perfectly without losing any lives with Shinji even if you know what you're doing. I always stop at the...
fallacies 09-Dec-20 12:33 PM
Chapter 8
Daytime, at the mansion of the Genji.
By Raikou's leave, a meeting is called amongst the warriors of the Genji as to discuss the present standing of the Tenran Grail War. (edited)
A representative of the Genji gives that of the jutsusha / Casters summoned of foreign lands and otherworlds, three remain.
Medea Lily, for whom Watanabe-no-Tsuna — head of the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu — acts as a Tenran Musha / Master.
Nursery Rhyme, who whom Minamoto-no-Yorimitsu (Raikou) — acting leader of the Genji — acts as a Tenran Musha / Master.
At the announcement of Nursery Rhyme's name, Kintoki whispers that she's reverted to her appearance as a small Japanese girl. (edited)
Guda whispers that her original appearance should be as her other form, but Danzou gives that she's heard that Nursery Rhyme is a Heroic Spirit who hasn't a particular default appearance.
Her usual form as of Chaldea is merely one of the forms she acquired subsequent to becoming as a Heroic Spirit.
Kintoki gives that it's difficult for him to comprehend a Heroic Spirit's manner of existence.
One amongst the warriors of the Genji gives that Kintoki and his party should refrain from privately speaking during the meeting.
He gives that under normal circumstances, such insolence would be punishable by beheading, and so he asks Kintoki and party to observe discipline.
Kintoku: "Hehe, sorry, sorry. You could hear us since everyone else was silent, huh?"
Raikou: "Kintoki. That isn't permitted. Please don't make it so that Mother has to behead you."
Kintoki: "Heei."
Raikou: "Could you please reply in a more proper manner ... ?"
Kintoki: "Yes, I assent!"
Privately, Guda thinks that the warriors of the Genji are incredible.
Nursery Rhyme giggles, giving that she'd thought him already mature. Addressing him as Kintarou-san, she asks if he's perhaps eternally a child.
Kintoki: "N? N. Nnnn. Nnnnnn~!" (edited)
Guda is surprised, wondering if Kintoki isn't able to contradict Nursery Rhyme's words. However, she whispers to him that he shouldn't be so bothered, as he's already a reliable adult.
Nursery Rhyme is reminded that she should be whispering also. That said, she asks Guda if that's indeed the case — if Kintoki is in fact reliable.
She observes that it was indeed the case that he saved her, but —
Danzou gives that Kintoki is indeed quite reliable.
She gives that Kotarou often gives that he wishes he were as reliable a man as Kintoki.
Guda notes that that should be in reference to the Kintoki summoned to Chaldea. She asks if Danzou is saying this on account that Chaldea's Kintoki can be regarded as the same person as the Kintoki before them.
Nursery Rhyme smiles, whispering that it seems that everyone likes Kintoki. (edited)
A bit more loudly, she gives that he's quite admirable.
At her praise, Kintoki wonders if Nursery Rhyme is treating him as if he were a younger brother.
Here, Tsuna shifts the topic to the matter of Nursery Rhyme's recovery. (edited)
"Heroic Spirits die with the loss of their Spiritual Core. I believe you stated something of the sort, Caster."
Medea replies that that's indeed the case. In her opinion, the circumstance whereby Nursery Rhyme was able to recover from her injuries can be described as nothing short of a miracle.
fallacies 09-Dec-20 01:53 PM
Medea gives that for example, per the legend of Orpheus, (similar) tales that take as their motif the resurrection of the dead are commonly retold (再話, saiwa) in every locale, all around the world. (edited)
fallacies 09-Dec-20 02:01 PM
Whether this be a consequence of the communication of information, or purely a coincidence, it's the case that Heroic Spirits that have their basis in legends of the same system or motif do as of coming into contact with one another —
Or, to rephrase, if Mysteries of the same root, or of some other manner of close resemblance come into direct contact with one another, potential for the enactment of some phenomena similar to that experienced by Nursery Rhyme cannot be dismissed.
In this instance, however, there do exist some differences between the natures of that which came into contact. (edited)
The collective of occidental tales that are as Nursery Rhyme, and the singular tale that is as Kintarou.
It isn't the case that there exist any clear points of similarity or commonality.
Medea gives that for she who isn't as a God, rendering an outcome whereby Nursery Rhyme's Spiritual Core could be mended would be extremely difficult.
Therefore, says Medea, this circumstance would be as a —
Tsuna: "A miracle, hm?"
Medea: "... indeed."
Guda (whispering): "Speaking of which, why doesn't Kintoki know of Ashigara-Yama-no-Kintarou?"
Danzou replies that she's heard that the otogibanashi of Ashigara-Yama-no-Kintarou was something created as of the Edo period.
Therefore, it's a matter of course that the Kintoki of the Heian Era wouldn't have heard of it. (edited)
Comparatively, the Sakata-no-Kintoki that is as a Heroic Spirit would be borne of a self-recognition of his existence in the capacity of Ashigara-Yama-no-Kintarou.
fallacies 09-Dec-20 02:29 PM
After a brief interlude in which Danzou tries to recall whether she and Kotarou once discussed the matter of Kintarou and Momotarou, the representative of the Genji calls order to the meeting.
Again, he reiterates that of the remaining Casters, the first would be Medea Lily, and the second would be Nursery Rhyme.
The third, for whom Sakata-no-Kintoki — one amongst the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu — acts as Tenran Musha / Master —
The representative presumes that this would be Guda — naming her as the 3rd and final jutsusha / Caster.
He asks if his understanding of the circumstances are correct.
Guda objects, giving that she isn't in fact a Heroic Spirit of the Caster Class.
Kintoki laughs, giving that it seems as if he isn't alone in that this misapprehension.
But he replies to the representative that as Guda herself states, she isn't a jutsusha / Caster summoned forth from a foreign land or otherworld.
She and Danzou are guests from the tomorrow of tomorrow, he says. (edited)
Tsuna comments that there isn't any evidence as to back this claim.
He states that though indeed the one called Guda isn't as a jutsusha / Caster summoned forth from a foreign land or otherworld, but whether she's been truthful in her statements or on the matter of her nature requires further assessment.
The representatives of the Genji calls for order.
He gives that the veracity of Guda's claim that "the Tenran Grail War is a treacherous plot" is a matter for the acting head of house alone to decide. (edited)
The representative asks for Raikou's opinion on the matter.
Raikou gives that though under normal circumstances, this would indeed be the case. However, this is a matter that concerns the Minister of the Left, Fujiwara-no-Michinaga and the Imperial Palace itself — a matter that potential affects the entirety of the Hi no Moto.
Therefore, she gives, as of the Hour of the Horse (午の刻. uma no koku; approximately noon) this day, she will be calling a Genji Kaigi (源氏会議, "debate assembly of the Genji"). (edited)
fallacies 09-Dec-20 03:27 PM
As the assembly formally opens, Raikou asks Guda the grounds for her claim that the Tenran Grail War is a plot of treachery. (edited)
Raikou gives that on account that her friend, the Otogibanashi of Afar (彼方の御伽話) Nursery Rhyme, owes Guda her life, she would personally like to trust in Guda's word.
However, so far, there isn't sufficient evidence to prove her claim.
Guda gives that though there isn't positive proof —
Kintoki completes her sentence, giving that there are grounds for a reasonable suspicion. Therefore, shouldn't that be sufficient to call a halt to the deathmatch?
Raikou gives that there's a certain logic to his position. Here, she asks Tsuna for his opinion on the matter.
Tsuna gives that the Grail War is being held on the orders of the Minister of the Left.
Therefore, unless the Minister of the Left issues a revocation of the order, the Grail War should proceed.
Raikou gives that there's a logic to his position as well.
Here, she gives that being as the Genji are as the strongest gathering of warriors, in the circumstance that there's an irreconcilable difference of opinion, the disagreeing parties should be aware of the manner in which their difference is to be settled.
She gives that said parties should settle the matter by the blade.
At Guda and Danzou's confusion, Raikou gives that as the Genji are a house of warriors, they shouldn't regard it as strange that this would be as a custom the members observe.
To assert one's position per the blade. To defend one's position per the blade.
Though the way in which things are done somewhat differs from that which was observed unto the generation of the previous head of house, this, gives Raikou, is what is presently called as the Genji Kaigi.
Observing that Raikou is dead serious, Guda gives to Danzou that though she would like to call things to a halt, she doesn't think it's possible.
Kintoki assents to the match, but gives that as on his side, there's a lack of a Caster, he'd like for Guda to assist him.
As both Kintoki and Tsuna have agreed to the match, Raikou calls for both to draw their blades, and settle their differences beneath the gaze of Hachiman-Shin (八幡神).
Tsuna: "Caster. ... come. It's battle to the death."
Medea: "O you who are borne of strength. Who for the sake of thy dream do thirst; do strive; do claw against the soil."​ "Therefore, conquer. Therefore, kill."​ "If you seek to realize your wish, there is aside from forcing your way through by the strength that you bear no other path."​ "This would be as the battlefield of blood; the Limbo (辺獄, hengoku) what consumes Heroic Spirits succumbed to defeat."​ "— that what over the black sun presides, called as the Tenran Shiai Butai (天覧死合舞台, "the stage of the deathmatch presided over by the Skies")."​ "Mine true name be as Medea Lily! Mine love; mine ideals — these shall hereby bring thy path to closure."​ "Laugh, O Kijin (鬼神, lit. "oni god"). Shine, O Daystar."​ "Come — for the sake of thy own wish."​ "— let that I here witness thy strength."​ (edited)
Guda calls Kintoki's name. At her word, he gives that he understands. Their objective here is to secure allies. Being as his objective is halt the Tenran Grail War, he hasn't any intention to claim Medea's head.
fallacies 09-Dec-20 04:41 PM
After battle:
A black screen. "— I shall protect. I will never again endure loss."
"Indeed, I have so decided."
"Ever since that day."
There are sounds of combat. (edited)
"A deathmatch observed by the heavens (天覧, tenran), purposed to the objective of rendering protection."
"A Grand Ritual to the end of bringing eternal peace to the Miyako."
"To the Genji and its men, an honor; and to the Fujiwara-no-Michinaga, the Minister of the Left, an earnest wish to be realized."
"Preservation of the country. A thousand years of peace."
"I know nothing of that."
"I seek to clear away my regrets from that day."
"I seek to hereby dispel my own contrition."
"O Hachiman-Shin, do smile upon my unsightliness." (edited)
"The tragedy come by my own powerlessness, I do reject."
"Those lives dispersed as of blood-splatter ..." (edited)
"Those lives that should've been preserved ..."
"It is precisely as never again to endure loss that I wield this Higekiri (髭切, lit. "beard-cutter")."
In the Tenran Shiai Butai, Kintoki and Tsuna cross weapons.
Tsuna is injured, but at Caster's concern, he yells for her not to come before him.
Standing unsteadily, he gives that he's vowed that he would again endure loss.
Tsuna: "That I would never again lose the ones that I should protect! Caster Medea!"
Medea gives that he doesn't need to worry after her, as hers is only as a life temporarily instantiated.
Her flesh at present is butter a silhouette (影法師, kageboushi) cast upon the World. The her who once lived is no longer.
Furthermore, she gives, she isn't the one who dwells within his heart.
She gives that there isn't any meaning in expending his life to her defense.
He himself should know this best, she says.
Kintoki asks Tsuna what he intends to do, observing that he's bent his knee (片膝突いた, katahiza tsuita; a circumstance in which a non-lethal match would normally be called). Personally, he doesn't mind going at it again, but he says that he'll leave the decision to Tsuna.
Tsuna: "... O Caster of a foreign land; an otherworld."
"Nay — O sorrowful, ephemeral princess of a country far away."
"There are none so beautiful and clever as you. However — indeed. Even so, I ..."
"Even as I now protect you, it is verily the profile of that person that I think of."
"Perhaps, if it's the Holy Grail ..."
"The life of that person, now lost ..."
"I could again ..."
Since early childhood, he was acquainted with somebody — the daughter of a noble. (edited)
Even that he was of a different class from her, she regarded him with a smile.
She was of such beauty that he wouldn't have thought it strange if she were wed one day to the Emperor.
However, she was never wed to anyone.
Quietly, she was by her father isolated in a certain mansion.
Rumors circulated. It was for example given that she'd succumbed to a disfiguring disease, or that she'd been confined on account of having committed some grave sin. That having succumbed to madness, she could no longer speak.
It was also rumored that she'd become pregnant with the child of some noble.
fallacies 09-Dec-20 05:47 PM
Tsuna came into adolescence, and into comprehension of the taboo that existed as of relationships across the boundaries of the social classes.
Around then, he decided to become a warrior, dedicating himself to the blade. (edited)
By the time he noticed it, he'd exterminated hundreds; thousands of kai'i, and thereby acquired the attentions of Minamoto-no-Yorimitsu. It was thus that he was bestowed with his treasured sword. (edited)
To the end of better preserving the safety of the Miyako, he suborned himself to the Ministry of Police, and earned their trade — coming eventually to be seated as of a position of equivalent standing to the police inspectors.
He came to oversee a corner of the eastern half of the Miyako (左京, sakyou, lit. "the left of the capital"). (edited)
There, he witnessed — (edited)
— a tragedy come by the hand of oni.
Everyone was dead. (edited)
The head of house; the members of the family. That person as well.
The corpse of that person, whose throat was torn, was alike to a great flower in bloom, in the midst of a pool of blood. (edited)
A set of small footprints led away from her.
All about the house, it traveled, and where it went, Tsuna found the bodies of the members of the household.
The one who had left the footprints spared no lives.
None of the corpses were consumed, but death had been rendered via fangs. (edited)
Was it simply that they weren't eaten? Or that the perpetrator wouldn't eat them? (edited)
The Ministry of Police concluded that the killings were perpetrated by a ko-oni (小鬼, "small oni") who had circumvented the Bounded Field laid down by Abe-no-Seimei. (edited)
For Tsuna however —
It was only after witnessing the corpse of that person that he realized ...
He'd always loved her.
In the present, back in the courtyard at the mansion of the Genji, Tsuna gives that he has difficulty comprehending people's thoughts or emotions.
By the time he'd noticed his own feelings, everything was over.
It isn't so much a tragic or unrequited love as a residue within his heart, which never amounted to anything.
Merely, a miserable emptiness within his breast.
Raikou says his name. To this, Tsuna gives that he understands it even if she doesn't speak it aloud.
Or perhaps, it was by way of Kintoki's lightning that he's awakened from the Curse (呪詛, jyuso) of the Grail.
The dead cannot return. They shouldn't be let to return.
Irrelevant of the reason, the laws of nature should not be overturned.
Addressing Raikou, Tsuna gives that he understands.
Tsuna: "But, briefly, I dreamt a dream."
"This time, I would protect somebody — and at the end of it all, I would reclaim that person's smile. It was as such ..."
"The bright and dazzling dream called as the Tenran Seihai Sensou (天覧聖杯戦) —" (edited)
"But dreams are dreams. They cannot truly exist as of the Utsushiyo (現世, "manifest world"), hm?"
He sheathes his sword, giving to Kintoki that it's his loss.
Raikou gives that though the Genji Kaigi normal persists until one party claims the head of the other, she hereby declares the match concluded, with Kintoki as the victor. (edited)
Therefore, per the unanimous agreement of the Genji, she will pose to the Minister of the Left the suspicion that the Tenran Grail War is a plot of treachery.
Addressing Guda, Tsuna gives that she did well in supporting Kintoki in battle, overcoming the Dragon Bone Soldiers deployed by Medea.
He believed that they would've been difficult for Kintoki to overcome, but he praises that Guda skillfully manipulated the shadows that she brought forth.
Guda gives it isn't she who is praiseworthy, but rather her companions.
To this, Tsuna gives that he heard her say that she was from the future — from the Hi no Moto of a thousand years hence.
He gives that by the looks of it, based on what he sees of her, the Hi no Moto of that age seems an age of peace (平安, heian).
Thus, he thinks it strange that she commits herself to battle. He asks her what it is that she's striving to obtain.
Guda: "The reclamation of the World."
For a moment, Tsuna seems taken aback by her answer, but he gives that she was able to answer his question without hesitation.
Next arrow:
Hearing the unanimous position of the Genji, the Minister of the Left, Fujiwara-no-Michinaga, finds it amusing that "that Kaidoumaru" was able to surprisingly meet the unreasonable conditions that he laid forth. Giving that the Tenran Grail War would be reassessed upon the return of Abe-no-Seimei.
So saying, he orders Ashiya Douman to halt the ritual.
Douman: "N, nnn, nnnn nnnn."
He starts laughing.
When Michinaga asks him why he's laughing, his attire abruptly changes.
He gives that it's incredibly vexing — that he was only a step away from manipulating the Genji into destroying themselves. Once again, he gives, Chaldea has gotten into his way.
He observes that perhaps it's on account that Chaldea is by ties of En bound to the Genji. The Casters summoned forth were all similarly borne of En with Chaldea.
So saying, he corrects himself, giving that the Caster of Urabe was an exception. (edited)
Said Caster was one against whom fierceness and discretion wouldn't have been of use — in Douman's opinion, a Heroic Spirit truly suited to a Grail War.
However, against Douman's calculations, they were defeated.
Michinaga wonders if Douman has gone mad.
However, he corrects himself — concluding that this man before him isn't in fact Ashiya Douman.
Michinaga asks, then, if he would be the villain called as Limbo — wondering if the claim put before him by Kaidoumaru's party was in fact true. (edited)
To this, Limbo gives that that would indeed be the case.
He gives that Ashiya Douman was as a matter of course a pitiful onmyouji who properly lived as if this era.
Douman: "However, as of the instant of his encounter with Limbo, he succumbed to insanity. At the terminus of his cries; his screams; his madness — we attained unification!" (edited)
Michinaga calls for the guards — giving that there's been an insurrection. The man before him — Douman-Boushi (道満法師, "the priest, Douman") — is a traitor succumbed to madness. (edited)
He gives that as expected, it wasn't wise to employ him as Abe-no-Seimei's substitute.
The onmyouji that rush forth tell Douman to resign himself, as in preparation for circumstance, the Minister of the Left readied them in advance to suppress him.
Douman is amused, giving that as expected of the Minister of Left, actions were taken in advance on the premise that Kintoki's suspicions were valid.
Douman: "Purification of the Six Roots (六根清浄, Rokkon Shoujou); Express For Wicked Karma a Retribution (悪業罰示, akugyou basshi)."
"— Quickly Accord to Rule (急々如律令, kyuukyuu nyo ritsuryou)!"
There's a splatter of blood. Michinaga observes that more than ten onymouji were eliminated via a single Curse.
Douman: "Nnnnn? Where was I? Oh yes, oh yes, oh yes, oh yes — the matter of the monk called as Ashiya Douman, was it?"
"The called as Limbo spoke to him, you know? In the instant of their encounter — he uttered beside his ear."
"What of it? It was just a single utterance."
"If things remain as they are, you'll never once surpass Seimei — or so he said."
"And merely by such a murmuring, in sorrow did Douman's heart crumble ..."
"At the end of that was he to this humble monk rendered to unification! Thus, as such! This Douman is Douman, but Douman he is not!"
"It is we who devised and implemented the Heroic Spirit Blademasters — Caster Limbo."
"It is we who art as of the Tenran Seihai Sensou the 7th and most potent of Casters."
"Further."
"It is we art one amongst the Hachishou-Shin (八将神, "eight god-generals") who comprise the Jigoku-Kai Mandara (地獄界曼荼羅, "hell-world mandala")."
"— Ouban-Shin (黄幡神, "god of the yellow flag"), Ashiya Douman."
He asks for everyone to come and enjoy the Tenran Grail War.
Unfortunately, he gives, the Grail that he bears holds only the souls of four Servants.
As such, he cannot yet render his objective.
Addressing all of those who grounded as of the History of Man, he gives that he bore witness to their exploits, and was quite overcome with shock. (edited)
The wishes of men, he says; the fight that they've put up.
These have entirely exceeded his plans.
— or rather, laughing, he gives that that was a lie.
Addressing Michinaga, he tells him to sit tight and bear witness as the Ouban-Shin Ashiya Douman completes a marvelous undertaking never before witnessed.
Indeed — the completion of the Jigoku-Kai Mandara.
3
"— the skies changed."
"The crimson Moon." (edited)
"The blood-stained Moon, perhaps?" (edited)
"The cursed Moon was adrift."
"The night skies that covered the Heian-Kyo were as if with blood stained in crimson."
From a hole that manifests in the sky, a black mist rapidly descends over the Imperial Castle.
Once the mist clears, a Tree of Fantasy is there manifested.
"— the World was torn asunder."
"— unto the Gate of Suzaku (朱雀門, suzaku mon) in Heian-Kyo, a Root of Fantasy is descended."
5
"A great Youki (妖樹, a tree natured of "you," as per "youkai") that shatters the Human Order."
"Writhing, pulsating, as to render in perpetuity an impossible apocrypha (異聞, ibun) / if."
"By the breakage of the sky, in the night what should have been day, the crimson Moon did surface."
"And beneath that crimson Moon, as if laughing, a great tree —"
"Its name was as the Tree of Fantasy."
"However, it was somewhat distinct from that which had descended unto the seven Apocryphal Belts (異聞帯, ibun-tai) / Lostbelts."
"If it need be described, it was as a Subspecies Tree of Fantasy."
"A Root of Fantasy come as of the terminus of the distortions rendered by the innumerable Curses (多重超過呪詛, tajuu chouka jyuso) of the evil monk who had departed the side of the God of a Foreign Star, who was as Satan Becometh Lucifero (ルチフェロなりしサタン, luchifero narishi satan)." (edited)
"The former name that it once bore was as Onri Edo-Jou (厭離穢土城)!" (edited)
"And this would be its name anew —" (edited)
"— the Root of Fantasy come at the terminus of distortion, Jigoku-Kai Mandara!" (edited)
fallacies 09-Dec-20 08:42 PM
"Everyone looked to the skies."
"There were those acquainted with things without normality."
"There were those acquainted with the youmono mamono that ran rampant in every corner of the Miyako."
"There were those who should've already known fear."
"But what came was —" (edited)
"— a loss of self." "They merely screamed as they looked unto what had come of the terminus of distortion, which towered in the sky." (edited)
"There were as well those who quaked as they hugged their children." "There were as well those who were overcome with madness." (edited)
"There were as well those who did nothing, petrified in their fear."
"Even that oni might assail them, the people who had forgotten escape did — of all things, sink into a stupor at the terminus of their fear."
"Dreadful is the Subspecies Tree of Fantasy; dreadful is the Jigoku-Kai Mandara!"
Amidst the screams of the crowds in the street, Sei Shounagon gazes at the Tree of Fantasy.
Seiko: "What ... is that ... ?"
"W- Why ... Why can't ... I tear my eyes away ... why ... ?"
"Even though it's frightful just to look upon; even though I feel like I'm going insane with fear,. my eyes, my eyes, my eyes,"
"My eyes —"
Something strikes her.
Takako: "Ara, my apologies."
Seiko: "Eh, ah, eh, etto ... you would be ... !" (edited)
Takako gives that as Seiko was standing in the middle of the street with her mouth wide open, she struck her. She apologizes.
Takako gives that she wondered it was, and didn't think that it would be a courtier once in the service of Empress Teishi (藤原定子, Fujiwara-no-Teishi).
Giving that it's been a time since she departed the court, Takako wonders why it is that she would still be clad in mokaraginu. She asks if it's on account of lingering attachment to the court life.
Seiko is flustered, giving that it's fine, as she's accustomed to the weight.
Takako: "Well, whatever is fine, but. You."
"I think it'd be better if you snap out of your daze, and escape. That thing is ..."
"... indeed, it seems a bit out of control."
Beneath the tree, Douman laughs.
"Come, my servants! My sacrifices!" "The corpses what I command by way of the corpse of mine beloved Youjutsushi-dono (妖術師殿)." (edited)
By the use of the seven strokes of the Command Seal he bears in his capacity as the Administrator of the Grail War, he plants within the Shou-Shin (将神) their Gou (業, "karma").
Thus, he commands them to here gather.
fallacies 09-Dec-20 10:37 PM
https://forums.spacebattles.com/threads/general-type-moon-discussion-thread-2-unlimited-titles-works-please-read-the-threadmarks.795493/post-72505788
General Type-Moon Discussion Thread 2: Unlimited Titles Works! (PLE...
How about that one time the entire kingdom fought over a single stray hair on top of the head of their beardless king?
fallacies 10-Dec-20 01:49 PM
Chapter 9
In the southern districts of Heian-Kyo, lightning strikes near the Rajoumon (羅城門; also known as 羅生門, "Rashoumon"). Nobody is directly injured.
However, immediately afterwards, where the lightning had struck, there stood a pair of aberrations (魔, ma).
They were not humans. Rather, they were authentically (正真正銘, shoushin shoumei, lit. "true and as per designation") aberrations.
They were of a standing entirely distinct from the category of the keshou (化生) that every night wandered the streets. Proof of this lay in the circumstance that with every step they took, evil spirits (悪霊, akuryou) would in agony come to disperse; and keshou would, driven to madness, instantly bring themselves to termination.
Aberrations of such an extent were as existences entirely overwhelming.
An unknown speaker announces themselves as a Saisetsujin (歳殺神).
Another announces themselves as the Hyoubijin (豹尾神).
fallacies 10-Dec-20 02:16 PM
They stood without issue as of the streets of the Miyako — an inconceivable circumstance whereby the vast Bounded Field implemented by Abe-no-Seimei was by some means circumvented, even that youmono mamono were in general incapable of doing so.
The police forces that arrive to combat them are shocked that Abe-no-Seimei's Bounded Field could be directly overcome.
Here, Saisetsujin gives that being that "we the Hasshou" (八将, "eight generals") are become as corpses, conversation is meaningless; that they shall here be proceeding unto the Gate of Suzaku, and that nobody shall impede them. (edited)
Ordering that the police should withdraw, Saisetsujin gives that though "we" are become as corpses, they are as invincible — as fearsome blades.
When the police persist in resisting, Hyoubijin observes that they just don't listen — commenting that "you humans" have since long ago been quick to violence. On the other hand, she gives, the her of this time around is of such a disposition as well. (edited)
Manipulating her floating sword, she instantly slaughters three of the police officers.
Seeing this, one of the officers calls for the warriors in the area to be summoned here.
Saisetsujin gives that the Gates of Suzaku are presently the Gates of Hell (地獄門, jigoku-mon); that if "we" arrive as of the Hell-Realm Mandala, the World (世, yo, and not 世界, sekai) shall come to an end.
He gives therefore that perhaps it would be as a mercy to behead these humans here and now.
He comments that Hyoubijin is profound in her mercy.
Hyoubijin contradicts him, giving that no matter how she looks at it, it's of a mercilessness that she's acting.
The narration gives that in a mere instant, all of the police forces and warriors gathered to protect the Rajoumon were annihilated.
It's a level of violence entirely unalike to the mischief of the oni that the security forces had to contend with just a little earlier.
Aside from the two aberrations, there were no longer any movement in the vicinity — no longer anyone else still borne of a head.
fallacies 10-Dec-20 03:11 PM
Next arrow:
At the mansion of the Genji, warriors report the ongoings that have occurred around the city.
Kintoki is aware of the manifestation of the youki at the Gates of Suzaku, and when the warriors report that there's been a disturbance on the Avenue of Suzaku, he presumes that that's what they're referring to. However, the warriors contradict him, giving that they're speaking of a massacre that's just now occurred at the Rajoumon. Aberrations assuming the names of Saisetsujin and Hyoubijin have appeared there. (edited)
After slaughtering the security forces posted there, the warriors report, they've advanced northward by foot — in the direction of the youki that's appeared as of the Gates of Suzaku. (edited)
fallacies 10-Dec-20 03:30 PM
Danzou notes that Saisetsujin (歳殺神, lit. "the year-killing god") and Hyoubijin (豹尾神, lit. "the panther-tailed god") are as Divinities (神格, shinkaku) in the context of Onmyoudou (陰陽道).
Though, she hasn't heard of them being summoned forth before.
Tsuna asks Medea if she knows what's going on.
To this, Medea replies in the negative.
She comprehends only that the tree manifested at the Gates of Suzaku is an existence borne of a massive quantity of mana.
Guda gives that though she feels as if something is slightly off, the tree is what is known as a Tree of Fantasy.
Kintoki recalls her explaining before that subsequent to the World becoming as a blank slate, the Trees of Fantasy are as monstrous trees that thereafter descended.
Kintoki doesn't quite comprehend the implications, but when voices his question, and unknown voice (for some reason rendered in green font) replies:
"In short, the Heian-Kyo will be reborn as an Otherworld."
"And thereafter, a new Tree of Fantasy will have taken root as of the skies of the Greater History. What comes of this is the loss of our tomorrows."
"Indeed, to Guda, the implication is that the place to which she should turn is further displaced unto the far distance."
Nursery Rhyme is surprised, giving that there are words floating in the air.
Kintoki: "What manner of spell is this? Who's responsible!?"
Medea gives that it isn't her or Nursery Rhyme. She poses that it's a spell protocol as to render remote communication in a manner distinct from telepathy — possibly enacted in conjunction to a translation spell.
Tsuna wonders if perhaps it's something enacted by Murasaki.
Kintoki gives that indeed he senses her presence.
Murasaki arrives in the room, panting and out of breath. She apologizes for the intrusion. (edited)
Guda notes that the Genji were able to instantly detect her presence.
Danzou notes that the senses of the Genji seem far superior to the performance of her own sensors.
Raikou gives that she's seen Murasaki before at the mansion of Fujiwara-no-Michinaga. She welcomes Murasaki to her home, and calls for a servant to bring water for Murasaki to drink.
After getting a drink of water and catching her breath, Murasaki gives her thanks to Raikou.
At Raikou's prompting, Murasaki gives that she brings news from the Imperial Palace, having rushed here via ox carriage. (edited)
On the matter of her bringing news, Tsuna asks of the origin of the floating text, or whether it bears any relation to the spell protocol that just now manifested. (edited)
Murasaki gives that it's a text come of the hand of Abe-no-Seimei.
There's a silence in the room, until Nursery Rhyme gives that she was under the impression that Abe-no-Seimei wasn't presently here in Heian-Kyo.
The green text responds that indeed, Abe-no-Seimei is in location far distant.
It's on this account that he must by such a means communicate.
He gives his greetings to those present that he's acquainted with. To those he hasn't met before, he introduces himself as Abe-no-Seimei, the best and most talented individual to have served in the capacity of an onmyouji in all of history. (This guy talks pretty big ....) (edited)
4
Next arrow:
Abe-no-Seimei gives that he's heard everything.
As clarification, he gives that in this context, "everything" implies that he's literally aware of all relevant intelligence.
Ergo, as of the interior of the Grand Bounded Field of Heian-Kyo, he's able to grasp everything upwards of the janitorial cleanliness of a particular mansion — the circumstances of both the east and the west of the Miyako; of the assorted plots being undertaken as of the Imperial Palace.
He's heard "everything."
He gives that this would of course include the conversation with Chaldea that Guda and company had as of Murasaki's mansion.
Guda is shocked that Seimei's heard everything, commenting that he's of the Zeus Class.
Seimei laughs, giving that she praises him overmuch, and that he's embarrassed. However, he corrects himself, giving that he isn't actually embarassed, before laughing again.
Kintoki asks what this Zeus is. (edited)
To his question, Danzou answers that in this context, it would be best to call him as a vast surveillance system. (edited)
Kintoki gives that Seimei does indeed have something along those lines — eavesdropping and peeping by the use of his shikigami.
Apparently embarrassed, Raikoi and Tsuna give that indeed he has something along those lines.
Medea is about to say something (maybe relating to Zeus?), but Seimei interrupts, giving that it seems as if he's being rather poorly evaluated.
This is specifically expressed by way of the modern Japanese slang term, 株が下がる (kabu ga sagaru), which means something along the lines of "stock (prices) have declined." (edited)
Kintoki wonders what this phrase means.
At his comment, Guda asks if this would imply that Abe-no-Seimei is familiar with the modern Japanese language.
Seimei: "Well, who knows?"
"You're of course familiar with a particular variety of Mystic Eye that permits for sight of the future?"
"But of course, such information isn't all that relevant to circumstances presently afoot. Therefore, I won't go into particular detail."
He gives that perhaps as the individuals present have anticipated, the one who instantiated the Subspecies Tree of Fantasy before the Gates of Suzaku at the Imperial Palace is indeed the one known as Alter-Ego Limbo.
Guda takes note of the term "Subspecies Tree of Fantasy." At this, Seimei gives that he himself isn't presently certain of the meaning. However, this is the terminology that Limbo's employed in reference to the tree.
Seimei gives that the manifestation of that black Tree of Fantasy was the work of Ashiya Douman — or, more precisely, a result of the collaboration of Ashiya Douman and Limbo.
Ashiya Douman has by the Alter-Ego Limbo — summoned forth in the form in the form of malignant data — been compromised from within his own flesh. Plunged into sorrow by the evil whispered to his ear by Limbo, his soul was thereon consumed.
Kintoki wonders if he'd already been so consumed by the time that the party met him in the Palace.
To this, Seimei gives that that's indeed the case — though it can't be helped that they weren't able to discern it.
As of that point in time, the malignant data hadn't surfaced to expression, and Limbo's presence in the capacity of a Heroic Spirit couldn't be perceived.
Ergo, rather than it being some manner of negligence on the part of Guda and party, it was merely that Limbo was a step ahead of them.
It could be said that it's on account that Guda and company were able to halt the Tenran Grail War that Limbo was forced to surface. (edited)
Tsuna asks if Seimei is saying that the tree was originally intended to manifest subsequent the conclusion of the Ritual of Tenran. (edited)
Seimei replies that originally, it should've been by the gathering of the souls of seven Heroic Spirits that the Tree of Fantasy merged with the Grail would've truly reached completion. (edited)
He presumes that it would've come into bloom as of the final stage of the War.
Seimei doesn't know the extent to which the tree can operate in the capacity of a wish-granting engine, but there's no mistake that with the souls of seven Heroic Spirits, there would've been instantiated a vast enough quantity of mana as render possible the impossible.
Unfortunately, Seimei gives, he hasn't heard from Limbo's mouth the precise objective he intends to pursue with the Tree of Fantasy.
Tsuna concludes from this that the notion that a wish would be granted to the Tenran Musha that emerges victorious was nothing more than bait.
Medea speaks his name in concern, but Tsuna tells her not to worry; Kintoki's lightning properly roused him from his dream.
He won't again lose sight of that which he should cut down, and that which he should protect.
Seimei gives that the wish-granting engine that birthed forth the Tenran Grail War was to be used to realize the wish of Alter-Ego Limbo alone.
And on account of the halting of the Tenran Grail War, he's by other means reinitiated the Summoning of the Heroic Spirits.
Seimei comments that Alter-Ego Limbo is quite high-handed, as Ashiya Douman wasn't nearly so impatient.
Guda asks if Saisetsujin and Hyoubijin would therefore be as the Heroic Spirits that Limbo's summoned anew.
Seimei affirms this. He gives that the Hasshoushin (八将神, "eight god-generals") have adopted the names of the Divinities of Onmyoudou; but that setting this aside, they're collectively so-called apparently on account that there are eight of them in total. Being as Limbo is himself claiming the title of one of the gods, it should be the case that seven will be summoned forth. (edited)
At present, two have iterated, presently traveling northward from the southern edge of Heian-Kyo.
On crossing through the Gates of Suzaku to the interior of the Imperial Palace, the two of them presumably intend to offer up their souls to the Subspecies Tree of Fantasy.
And being as the Subspecies Tree of Fantasy has already acquired the souls of four Heroic Spirits, if any three of the eight arrive at the tree, Limbo will win.
Kintoki asks if the plan would be to drive them off before they arrive at the tree.
Seimei poses that it may be the case that the Hasshoushin have to be within a certain distance of the Subspecies Tree of Fantasy as to effectively offer up their souls — as, otherwise, they could simply commit suicide as of instantiation.
However, based on the happenings as of the country of Shimousa, Seimei believes it's entirely possible that on death, their souls would be automatically collected to the Grail.
Hearing this, Guda isn't certain how to proceed.
Tsuna gives that the Hasshoushin cannot be permitted to cross through the Gates of Suzaku; but that they likewise shouldn't be killed.
Kintoki gives that capturing without killing would be difficult even if they were opponents of strength comparable to himself.
In reply, Seimei gives that indeed, the Hasshoushin are without a doubt Heroic Spirits of potent strength.
They shouldn't be thought of as opponents against which one can hold back.
However, it isn't permissible that their Spiritual Core is shattered, as the Tree of Fantasy would thereafter consume their souls.
That being the case, gives Seimei, the only solution would be to seal them away, such that even that they're killed, their souls won't disperse. (edited)
Seimei asks Murasaki to bring out a set of ofuda.
Nursery Rhyme giggles, giving that the variety of patterns drawn upon them are quite cute.
fallacies 10-Dec-20 05:50 PM
Seimei gives that these would be as the Taizan no Fu (泰山符) — that is, the Fu of Mount Tai. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Tai https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fulu
As an explanation not in the game, Taishan Fu is as a variety Taoist talismans comprising of calligraphy on paper, comparable to Japanese ofuda. Their overall intent is to quell misfortune.
Seimei gives that having foreseen such circumstances, he prepared in advance eight such ofuda, which shall serve to seal away the souls of the Hasshoushin as of the shattering of the Spiritual Cores.
3
Thereby, the souls of the Hasshoushin won't be permitted to communicate unto the Subspecies Tree of Fantasy, and instead remain as of the Manifest World (現世, utsushiyo).
If thereafter the Holy Grail — or rather, the Subspecies Tree of Fantasy — is destroyed, this crisis will be resolved.
The souls of the Hasshoushin can then be safely released.
At Raikou's prompting, Tsuna and Kintoki give that they're ready to proceed with the plan.
Raikou asks that Medea and Nursery Rhyme remain at the mansion of the Genji, as their deaths will further Limbo's plans. For their own safety, she gives that Guda and Danzou should do so as well. (edited)
However, Medea gives that she won't stand by and do nothing. As of an engagement against these Heroic Spirits, she intends to make herself of use.
Nursery Rhymes that she as well will accompany, as it's so as to help her friends that she's come forth.
Guda gives that she likewise won't stay put, as she can't permit Limbo to do as he likes.
Hearing their conviction, Raikou relents, giving that hereforth, she'll count them amongst the warriors of the Genji.
On the Grand Avenue of Suzaku (朱雀大路, suzaku-ooji), Danzou reports that numerous kai'i have appeared.
She poses that perhaps they're shikigami manipulated by the hand of Limbo.
A warrior on site affirms that the kai'i should be as shikigami, reporting that they seem not to die whether they be cut down or set on fire. He gives that they're alike to corpses that just won't die.
Raikou gives that whether they be corpses or oni, these are to be crushed such that the Genji's forces can advance.
fallacies 10-Dec-20 06:26 PM
After combat:
Danzou observes that the enemy units have instantaneously regenerated as of sustaining damage.
To this, Guda gives that it's alike to the circumstance with the Heroic Spirit Blademasters of Shimousa.
Danzou affirms this, giving that on account that the enemies' Spiritual Cores are preserved in separation, they effectively possess a pseudo-immortality.
She heard that in Shimousa, it was by the joint effect of Musashi's techniques and Murasama's blade that the Blademasters were defeated.
However, being as Abe-no-Seimei provided only eight ofuda, she isn't certain as to how to proceed.
At this, Tsuna gives to the shikigami that they're a bother. Drawing his blade, he cuts at them — rendering that they instantly disintegrate.
Kintoki is and Raikou are able to do the same.
Witnessing the strength of the warriors of the Heian, Guda remarks that she's reminded of Onigashima (鬼ヶ島).
Medea gives that in conjunction with the offensive Reinforcement she's furnished them with, their baseline combat capabilities are boosted to such an extent that pseudo-immortality can be negated.
However, she corrects herself, giving perhaps even if absent her Reinforcement, they'd be able to perform to such a level irrelevant.
fallacies 10-Dec-20 07:01 PM
After combat:
Danzou reports that the shikigami thought to have been deployed by Limbo have all been eliminated.
Ahead, she detects two potent mana signatures.
She warns everyone to be careful, as these are without a doubt the new Heroic Spirits spoken of by Abe-no-Seimei — Saisetsujin and Hyoubijin. (edited)
Saisetsujin observes that he's been called by the name of his corpse.
He gives that the opponents before him seem to be of a higher standing than the ones they've so far eliminated.
Saisetsujin: "— the inami (忌名, lit. "taboo name") of mine corpse be as Saisetsujin (歳殺神), Tawara Touta." "— your death." (edited)
Hyoubijin: "— the inami of mine corpse be as Hyoubijin (豹尾神), Suzuka Gozen." "— if it is death that you desire, I shall grant it."
