fallacies 10-Dec-20 09:03 PM
Chapter 10
Suzuka counts before her 2 Casters, 1 Assassin, 3 warriors, and a brat.
Seeing the two Hasshoushin, Guda addresses them as Suzuka-Gozen and Tawara Touta.
Hearing this, Tsuna asks, "What?"
Raikou: "I see. So Heroic Spirits were something like this."
"We who were aware only of the Jutsusha of foreign lands and otherworlds hadn't a proper grasp of it, but ..."
"Those spoken in legend; the Furutsuwa-Mono (古強者, lit. "strong old ones"; generally in reference to "warriors of past eras") —" (edited)
"The slayer of the great kai'i that was as the Oo-Mugade (大百足, "great centipede"); who played a critical role in the suppression of the Rebellion of Bandou (坂東の乱, bandou no ran) — Fujiwara-no-Hidesato-dono (藤原秀郷殿). Also known as Tawara Touta." (edited)
"The daughter of the Demon King of the Heaven, who played a critical role in the suppression of numerous oni — Suzuka-Gozen-dono (鈴鹿御前殿). Also known as Tate-Eboshi (立烏帽子, lit. "upright eboshi")." (edited)
1
"... Heroic Spirits. Ergo, that what is as path that men have walked!" (edited)
"And such didn't merely walk ..."
"They are as the Heroes who accomplished vast undertakings; the very embodiment of great figures ... !"
Danzou: "The slayer of the Oo-Mugade, Tawara Touta! The Princess of the Tenma (天魔); wielder of the treasured sword, Suzuka-Gozen!"
"They would be of ... a potent combat potential! Accordingly, their measured mana capacity is vast!"
Danzou warns that even with the assembled combat potential of Tsuna, Raikou, and Kintoki, there's still a ways to go before the opponent's strength can be matched.
Raikou gives that she doesn't comprehend this talk of mana capacity. Thus, Danzou clarifies that the opponents' combat potential exceeds that of the party here gathered.
Raikou smiles, giving that she wonders if that's indeed the case.
She states that the battlefield here and now is the Miyako — the city that most flourishes in all the land; a keystone of the Realm of Men (人界, jinkai).
If the forces gathered here withdraw, it would render the fall of the Miyako; the annihilation of the Realm of Men. Fallen from their standing as warriors, they would be nothing more than gedou (外道, lit. "without the path"; generally "worthless wretches").
That being the case, there isn't any reason for hesitation. Even that the opponents are the heroes of old, the only path is to cut them down.
Raikou: "Wouldn't this be the grounds by which warriors stand as warriors?"
"To carry our blades; to wield our spears; to hone our martial technique. All of this; every bit of it ..."
"Is such that we might serve as necessary in extraordinary predicaments!" (edited)
"— Tsuna. Kintoki!"
Tsuna and Kintoki respond to her call.
To the Hasshoushin, Kintoki gives that they would do well to remember the names of those who stand before them.
To Danzou, Kintoki gives that while it's true that they're strong opponents, all that isn't necessarily meaningful — if they're merely as puppets of a villain like Limbo.
He gives that they'll here be brought to a halt.
Touta gives that he imagined that in this land; in this era in which the reputations of he and Suzuka are so renowned, their opponents would be disheartened at the prospect of an encounter.
However, that seems not to be the case for the warriors of the Genji arrayed before him.
fallacies 10-Dec-20 10:06 PM
After an opening engagement wherein Touta and Suzuka largely refrained from going all out, Raikou wonders how it is that legitimate Heroes would succumb to the manipulations of a villain who seeks to plunge the World into chaos.
She asks of the manipulations of Limbo are indeed so strong.
She doesn't believe that their wills would be so weak as to falter before evil.
Touta gives that he and Suzuka are merely as familiars — as silhouettes (影法師, kageboushi) engraved in the Human Order, irrelevant of the marks that they've left on history.
Furthermore, the both of them are as corpses.
Corpses do not think; do not wish.
Corpses are absent of heart.
Thus, they haven't any choice but to act in accordance to the path ordained for them.
Guda gives that their crimson eyes are as alike to the Heroic Spirit Blademasters.
Touta gives that that's enough chatter. He True Name releases his Noble Phantasm.
After a bombardment of projectiles, Suzuka attacks Tsuna, giving that as they're nothing more than corpses, speech is but a pretense. Their wills; their wishes; their hearts are rendered all but ephemeral dreams. (edited)
They're as karakuri (絡繰) committed to the slaughter and annihilation of everything that is.
1
After a release of her Noble Phantasm, Suzuka begins to cry tears of blood — giving that the forces arrayed against them are pathetic. (edited)
Suzuka:
"The Miyako! The place of all who live! The greatest Realm of Man (人界, jinkai) as of the Hi no Moto, once protected by that person / Tamuramaro (田村麻呂)!"
"You've inherited martial discipline, have you not?"
"You yet wield blades, do you not?"
"In that case, survive! If your legs be severed, plant your blades into the earth and stand upright!"
"Don't be falling behind mere corpses!"
2
"Can you even so claim yourself the successors of that person ... !?" (edited)
"... are you lot even warriors!?"
Touta is surprised, giving that Suzuka has done well to shed tears, even that she's already become as a corpse.
Touta: "This humble one feels pain as well."
"That a corpse absent of a heart could feel within his breast a pain. Haha, how bizarre."
Suzuka gives that being as she was originally possessed of Divinity (神性, shinsei), irrelevant that she's been forcibly merged with another imitation Divinity (神性もどき, shinsei-modoki), to some extent, she bears still the capacity to idly chatter.
Rather, she says, it's incredible that he would be able yet to speak; to laugh. Even that his eyes are rendered crimson, he's still a good man.
So praised, Touta gives that he hasn't a choice but to give a show of the sort of man he is.
He gives that he'll follow her lead. When Suzuka asks him what that means in practice, he gives that that would depend on the warriors of the Genji. He calls out, asking if they hear him. (edited)
Tsuna answers his call, giving that their words are quite piercing.
Medea has in the space of the discussion healed Tsuna of his wounds, and Reinforced the others.
The warriors of the Genji stand ready to resume battle. (edited)
fallacies 10-Dec-20 11:01 PM
Kintoki gives that the Hasshoushin are indeed strong. However, he asks why it is that their opposition still lives.
Being as their favored attacks are projectile bombardment, as to render certain death, they need only to properly launch an offensive from afar. (edited)
And yet, they haven't done so. Thus far, they've only engaged at melee range. (edited)
Rhetorically, Kintoki again asks why that is. (edited)
But here, he answers for them: It's because that wouldn't be Golden.
1
Touta: "You hear that, Suzuka?"
Suzuka: "I do. What should we do?"
Touta: "The stalemate comes here to a close."
"Even that we are become as corpses, we should at the very least put ourselves forth with all that we have as waymark unto tomorrow." (edited)
Addressing Suzuka, Touta gives that such was the nature of the World where once they lived.
Touta: "That which exceeds we who are as the past is the rule of the future!"
"If that be the case, it isn't a poor bet to gamble upon the strength of the future!"
Suzuka asks if by "putting forth all that we have," it isn't in the end the same thing as merely slaughtering the opposition. (edited)
However, she answers her own question, giving that perhaps it's something alike to a matter of sentiment.
But sentiment — emotion — is important.
Smiling, she gives that she assents.
Touta: "O you who are borne of strength. Who for the sake of thy dream do thirst; do strive; do claw against the soil."​
Suzuka: "Therefore, conquer."
Touta: "Therefore, kill."​
Suzuka: "If you seek to realize your wish, there is aside from forcing your way through by the strength that you bear no other path."​
Touta: "This would be as the battlefield of blood; the Limbo (辺獄, hengoku) what consumes Heroic Spirits succumbed to defeat."​
"— that what over the black sun presides, called as the Tenran Shiai Butai (天覧死合舞台, "the stage of the deathmatch presided over by the Skies")."​
"The inami of mine corpse be as Saisetsujin, Tawara Touta! Mine mighty bow; mine one arrow — these shall hereby bring thy path to closure."​
Suzuka: "The inami of mine corpse be as Hyoubijin, Suzuka-Gozen! Mine 250 blades of Daitou — these shall hereby bring thy path to closure."​ (edited)
Touta: "Laugh, O Kijin (鬼神, lit. "oni god"). Shine, O Daystar."​
"Come — for the sake of thy own wish."​ "— let that I here witness thy strength."​
Tsuna is shocked that the Tenran Shiai Butai is in use, even as the Grail War is discontinued.
However, Raikou prompts that conviction should be answered with conviction.
Thus, Tsuna readies himself to engage.
fallacies 11-Dec-20 12:06 AM
After combat:
Tsuna and Raikou timed their attacks as to interrupt the simultaneous True Name Releases of the Hasshoushin. (edited)
Comprehending this to be an element of the nature of Heroic Spirits, they adapted their strategy, waiting until the moment their opponents relaxed their defense as to release their Noble Phantasms.
On account that it's really just a brief moment in the midst of combat, Kintoki gives that the feat of exploiting such a thing is beyond him; that Tsuna and Raikou are quite amazing. (edited)
Tsuna gives that that brief moment — gone in the space of a twinkle of a star — was alone their opportunity for victory.
Raikou, on the other hand, gives that if Touta and Suzuka weren't Heroic Spirits — if they weren't merely become as silhouettes; if that tiny lapse didn't exist — the Genji would've here been necessarily vanquished.
Raikou gives that it was per the charity that Suzuka and Touta expressed in demonstrating the height of their techniques that the Genji were able to obtain victory. (edited)
Touta gives that it was a job well done.
Come to think of it it, he says, the him that once was hadn't the need to speak a True Name Release to perform that shot.
He gives that it's a matter that can't be helped, clad as of the flesh of a Heroic Spirit.
Or rather, the corpse of such.
As expected, he gives, he truly isn't himself.
If he were permitted a single extravagance, it would be as to once again cross blades with the Genji here before him.
At this, Raikou gives that she refuses, as she wouldn't have a chance of victory.
Perhaps, she says, when all is said and done, and all her obligations are fulfilled.
Danzou gives that Guda should make use of the ofuda provided by Seimei.
Guda does so, releasing two of them.
Danzou confirms the suppression of the targets; that the ofuda have properly activated, sealing the Spiritual Cores of Touta and Suzuka.

General Type-Moon Discussion Thread 2: Unlimited Titles Works! (PLE...
to have been forged for God Himself. Disgusting
fallacies 11-Dec-20 04:48 PM
Chapter 11
On the eastern side of Heian-Kyo — in the outskirts at the far end of Gojou-Ooji (五条大路), toward Kamogawa (鴨川). (edited)
A number of the warriors of the Genji have here gathered, encircling a single opponent.
Or rather, it was an aberration of human form, mounted atop a large tsuchigumo.
The woman observes that the warriors show no fear, even that they face a tsuchigumo 3 jou (丈, roughly equivalent to 3 meters; ergo, 3 jou = 9 meters) in height.
She observes that given their absence of reaction, and the fact that they bear arms, it would seem that they aren't men of innocence.
The warriors announce themselves as being of the Genji, under the command of Raikou.
To this, the woman says:
"Genji. Genji, hm?"
Addressing the tsuchigumo as Kugamimi-no-Mikasa (玖賀耳之御笠), she gives that it would seem as if there are Genji here as well. That being the case, they shall as of the Miyako finally realize their long-held desire.
The tsuchigumo roars.
The woman calls for the Genji to listen well.
"I (儂, washi; usually the pronoun of self-address used by old men) am as poison. I am as the blade. I would be that which slaughters the Genji. Mine flesh is as vengeance itself."
"This be the Saihajin (歳破神, lit. "year-breaking god"), the Oo-Tsuchigumo (大土蜘蛛), with which I here arrive in Heian-Kyo as the corpse of a Heroic Spirit rendered to the Manifest World —" (edited)
"— ku, ku."
"Nay. Even that I become a corpse, mine vengeance isn't yet quenched!"
"Saikyoujin (歳刑神, lit. "year-punishing god"), Taira-no-Kagekiyo (平景清), here arrives."
"Kagekiyo here initiates the eradication of the Genji."
"— Genji, here be thy death." (edited)
The warriors are surprised, shocked that there would here arrive a warrior of the Heishi (平氏, another term for 平家, heike; "the Taira family") — perhaps a straggler from the Rebellion of Bandou (坂東の乱, bandou no ran).
Rather than further conversing, Kagekiyo beheads a man.
"The eradication begins."
The narration gives that leading a swarm of tsuchigumo, the 3rd of the Hasshoushin — a greater kai'i— begins its incursion unto the Miyako, acting alongside the 4th of the Hasshoushin, Taira-no-Kagekiyo. (edited)
Next arrow:
At the mansion of the Genji, Murasaki gives that she hasn't any idea of the current circumstances within the Imperial Palace; not whether the Mikado or the Empress are safe, nor whether the Minister of the Left is still alive.
She departed the Imperial Palace via ox carriage before the Tree of Fantasy descended.
Seimei gives that it was at his command that she did so. Therefore, she doesn't need to feel any particular guilt regarding her possible disloyalty.
Seimei gives that Limbo is unlikely to harm them immediately, as he seems the sort to want as many witnesses as possible to be present as of the instant he completes his objective. (edited)
Seimei judges him to share a penchant of the ruler of the west called as Caesar, in that he favors being listened to if he opens his mouth to deliver oration.
Hearing this, Raikou gives that for the time being, they'll trust in Seimei's judgment and leave the reclamation of the Palace for last. (edited)
There's a bit of an interlude wherein Guda observes that Seimei's brief iterations of greentext are somewhat alike to the texting that exists as of a thousand years into the future.
Nursery Rhyme gives that it's as if he were somebody who could see through time; or perhaps something alike to a traveler of eternity.
"Tick-tock, tick-tock — I wonder what manner of clock he bears?"
Hearing the word "clock," Kintoki begins to ask if it's something to do with water, perhaps; but Tsuna interrupts him, giving that he'd presumably be referring to a water clock (漏刻, roukoku) — a manner of karakuri (絡繰) that measures time by the drainage of water.
There's a brief discussion where Tsuna and Kintoki in essence agree that Kintoki hasn't the patience to act as timekeeper per the use of something like a water clock. So saying, Kintoki gives that it's perhaps been half a koku (半刻, han-koku; approx. 1 hour) since Danzou departed to scout. He thinks it's about time for her to return.
Danzou arrives just as he says this, reporting that the 3rd and 4th of the Hasshoushin have manifested near Kamogawa.
Guda gives that it seems that this time as well, it was two that appeared. She wonders if there's some limitation that prevents Limbo from bringing forth 3 or more.
Seimei gives that there may indeed exist restriction to Limbo's summoning capabilities.
He observes that for Limbo, if it be that he requires the souls of at least 3 Heroic Spirits, the best case scenario would be for him to summon all three immediately before him, and sacrifice them unto the Grail incorporated as of the Subspecies Tree of Fantasy.
However, in practice, he's so far only ever summoned two at once, and all of them out beyond the boundaries of the Grand Bounded Field that Seimei's deployed across the Miyako.
Rhetorically, Seimei asks why that would be.
For example, if Limbo were to summon more than three, and iterate them at different locations before having them advance unto the Gates of Suzaku, it would achieve the strategic advantage of splitting up the combat potential of the Genji. (edited)
However, Limbo hasn't done that either.
Kintoki wonders if it's just that he doesn't feel like it.
Tsuna asks Danzou to elaborate on her report, giving that to his knowledge, Hase (羽瀬) and Gotou (梧桐) were headed in the direction of the site where the Hasshoushin manifested.
Danzou gives that the warriors under the lead of Hase and Gotou stood guard within the area alongside police forces. However, approximately 70% of their combat potential was annihilated when the enemy broke past their line of defense. (edited)
Hearing this, Raikou gives that it's time to deploy. She calls for Medea.
Medea arrives with onigiri for Tsuna and Kintoki.
Kintoki gives that Danzou and Guda should eat as well.
However, Danzou here gives that there's something she didn't mention.
One amongst the Hasshoushin appears to be a kai'i of appearance alike to an Oo-Tsuchigumo. Meanwhile, the other is —
"— one who claims the name of Saikyoujin, Taira-no-Kagekiyo; a slayer of the Genji (源氏殺し, genji-koroshi)!"
Flashback:
At Danzou's encounter with Kagekiyo, Kagekiyo sniffed her scent, and asked if she were somebody borne of a tie of En with the Genji.
Danzou, shocked that her appearance and voice were familiar, named herself, giving that she was a Servant of the Master of Chaldea; that she was a guest at the mansion of the Genji, under the care of Minamoto-no-Yorimitsu. (edited)
She inquired as to Kagekiyo's name. To this, Kagekiyo answered that corpses haven't a need for a name.
"Or, I would say so if I were a proper Shoushin — but that I am not. If I be Kagekiyo, then even that I become as a corpse, I am yet Kagekiyo."
"Indeed, I be Kagekiyo — who carries the black blade of vengeance."
"— Saikyoujin, Taira-no-Kagekiyo."
She gives that if Danzou be as a karekuri that so carries with her the scent of the Genji, then she's properly Kagekiyo's prey. (Yes, Kagekiyo speaks of herself in 3rd person.)
As this is a flashback, and Danzou was alone during her scouting mission, she here enters solo combat against Kagekiyo and her pet tsuchigumo.
After combat:
Hearing Danzou's account, Seimei notes that the Hasshoushin seem to be fairly confident in their capabilities, if they aren't bothering to conceal their True Names.
He asks how familiar those present are with the name Taira-no-Kagekiyo.
Raikou asks if she would be a warrior of the Kaimu Heishi (桓武平氏).
She gives she isn't familiar with that particular name, but the warriors of the house of Taira were once as the traitors suppressed by Fujiwara-no-Hidesato (Tawara Touta) in the Rebellion of Bandou.
Kintoki and Tsuna are likewise unfamiliar with the name.
Danzou gives that whereas Taira-no-Kagekiyo is an individual who bears a connection with the Kaimu Heishi, the personage in question isn't of the past, but several centuries into the future.
Roughly three centuries prior to Danzou's time (circa the 12th century), Kagekiyo was a survivor of the Genpei War (源平合戦, genpei kassen) — a bizarre individual who cursed the Genji.
Raikou:
"... a personage from the future, you say?"
Tsuna: "Being as Guda, who lives a thousand years hence, is here present, it isn't particularly strange. However."
"Heroic Spirits would be as ... I see. So perhaps they're something as such."
Guda: "Taira-no-Kagekiyo ..."
Danzou: "Akushichibyoue Kagekiyo (惡七兵衛景清), of Kazusa (上総). Also known as Taira-no-Kagekiyo." (edited)
"Escaping somewhere in the aftermath of the Genpei War, he subsequently appeared in various locations — targeting the Genji, who had in the absence of the Heike (平家) asserted peace to the realm. A legendary figure alike to an evil spirit, who conspired vengeance." (edited)
"Lord Minamoto-no-Yoritomo, founder of the Kamakura Shogunate, is said to sustained thirty-seven attempts upon his life by Taira-no-Kagekiyo."
"Legend gives that he was an undying kaijin (怪人) who wouldn't die even when beheaded."
"The individual that Danzou encountered was unmistakeably this kaijin."
"The true identity of Taira-no-Kagekiyo in the capacity of a Heroic Spirit is as alike to a weapon of annihilation that acts to the end of absolutely exterminating the Genji."
"The band of the warriors of Genji led by Hase-dono and Gotou-dono ..."
"Suffered extermination at the hands of Kagekiyo alone ..."
Tsuna: "Extermination. As in, they were killed to a man? Do I correctly grasp you?"
Danzou: "Correct. The 30% that survived were one and all members of the police force."
"The limbs of the warriors who entered unto the vicinity of Kagekiyo appeared to lose strength — losing grip of their blades."
"It was as if they merely held forth their necks ..."
"I fear that this be some manner of technique held by Kagekiyo in the capacity of a Heroic Spirit."
"The Kagekiyo that Danzou witnessed was as the title asserts a slayer of the Genji."
"Please regard her as something alike to your natural enemy. What is to the Genji a poison; or to rephrase, a poison unto the Genji —"
"Irrelevant your strength as warriors of the Genji, the instant that you approach Kagekiyo, it shall necessarily come to pass that you'll be beheaded!"
Raikou gives that alike to the first two of the Hasshoushin, this one doesn't appear to be an opponent to be taken lightly either.
She inquires as to the condition of the members of the police force on site.
Danzou gives that they were unable to overcome the tsuchigumo led by Kagekiyo, and withdrew into the Miyako, gathering at the bridge at Kamogawa.
Kagekiyo and the tsuchigumo approached as if with leisure; but on glimpsing Kamogawa, for whatever reason, she halted her advance.
Kintoki is confused at this behavior, as the objective of the Hasshoushin should be as to reach the Gates of Suzaku. He asks if Kagekiyo bears some manner of emotional attachment to Kamogawa.
Here, Danzou addresses Guda, giving that the one claiming the name of Taira-no-Kagekiyo bears an incredibly close resemblance to Ushiwakamaru. (edited)
Danzou wonders if she isn't another aspect of Ushiwakamaru, who has for some reason chosen to go by another name.
However, Danzou gives that it's difficult for her to imagine that Ushiwakamaru (牛若丸) — that Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune (源義経) — could be borne of an Anti-Genji capability. (edited)
Guda gives that even if this be an Alter of Ushiwakamaru, there might be something else going on.
Kintoki asks who this "Ushiwakamaru" is.
Guda answers that shes Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune, whose name in childhood was Ushiwakamaru — a Hero of the Seiwa Genji (清和源氏), several centuries hence.
Danzou elaborates that Ushiwakamaru adored her brother, the acting head of the Genji; that she fought in numerous harsh battles.
However, in the end, her brother — Minamoto-no-Yoritomo, mentioned above as the founder of the Kamakura Shogunate (鎌倉幕府, kamakura bakufu) — named her a traitor, and so eliminated her.
Danzou gives that perhaps she bears motive enough to claim vengeance against the Genji.
Raikou observes that alike to this Taira-no-Kagekiyo, Ushiwakamaru could've become as an embodiment of vengeance.
Assessing the information, Raikou gives that it can't be helped; against an enemy borne of capacity to render the Genji powerless, there isn't any meaning in keeping up appearances.
Raikou gives that it's time to mobilize the strongest combat potential in the vicinity of the Miyako that doesn't belong of the Genji.
Ergo, it's time to travel forth to the mountains of Ooe (大江の御山, ooe no oyama), to borrow the strength of the oni. (edited)
Nursery Rhyme asks if Raikou is alright with this, given how she dislikes the oni.
Here, Seimei comments that he approves of the plan.
If the combat potential of the Genji and the police forces are insufficient, then it's only reasonable to make use of the oni breed.
He comments that though in this era, the oni breed tend not to reside at a set location, the oni of Ooe are an exception to the rule.
Though Seimei himself is as yet in some distant location, he'll attempt to mend or reinforce the Bounded Field deployed over the bridge at Kamogawa.
As he isn't certain how long it'll be able to stall Kagekiyo, he addresses Kintoki, giving that he should hurry.
Privately, Raikou thinks that perhaps they should make use of the opportunity to eliminate the oni. However, Nursery Rhyme is able to guess her thoughts — giving that it's alright if she doesn't take such a stance. (edited)
Nursery Rhyme asks her if it isn't the case that she'd like to be a gentle mother. If so, she gives, she shouldn't be regarding her son's friends in such a light.
She'll certainly regret it.
Hearing Nursery Rhyme's words, Raikou relents, giving that she can't lose her way. There isn't any honor in turning against a party to whom one owes a debt of gratitude.
Raikou gives that she bears no personal hatred against the oni or the tsuchigumo. It's merely that in her capacity as a human — as a warrior charged with defending the Miyako — there isn't any path permissible to her aside from cutting down the keshou. (edited)
However, even that of her own initiative, she hasn't any desire to kill them, she cannot guarantee that she won't her blade against them. (edited)
And being as Tsuna has only recent cut off Ibaraki's arm, she believes that the only person suited to here act as an emissary of the Genji is Kintoki.
Kintoki gives that as he's prone to getting hot-headed with regard to Shuten, he'd like for Guda and Danzou to accompany him.
Medea gives that they should take along the onigiri she's prepared. Even though they're a simple thing, she's incorporated within them a spell as to restore stamina (体力, tairyoku).
Kintoki thanks her, and the party sets off to Ooe.
fallacies 11-Dec-20 09:45 PM
Next Arrow: Rushing toward Ooe with Guda in his arms, Kintoki comments that it's been night-time ever since the Tree of Fantasy manifested. (edited)
Kintoki gives that it's convenient that by leaping through the air, he can avoid kai'i.
Arriving on the mountain, Danzou confirms that Guda's semicircular canals seem to be fine. (edited)
She gives that the party is currently about a hundred kilometers northwest of Heian-Kyo.
Guda gives that though they should quickly advance, maybe it's best that they eat the onigiri Medea's prepared for them.
Danzou asks if Guda would also like a Fuuma ration pill (兵糧丸, hyourougan). She gives that these would be of a variety that she's personally improved.
Guda says maybe next time.
Kintoki: "Oh, onigiri, huh? Nice."
Danzou asks if he would like one, but Kintoki declines, giving that they've already set foot in the domain of the oni.
After a brief bit wherein Kintoki talks about needing to stay on his toes, Guda reminds Kintoki that they're here to request assistance. At this, Kintoki gives that he hasn't any intention to start a fight, but that Guda shouldn't forget that oni are fundamentally oni, and therefore dangerous.
So saying, he gives that it's strange that he would set foot in oni territory, as it's usually the other way around.
Guda gives that she's heard that Shuten assails the Miyako about once a month.
Kintoki gives an explanation of Shuten's usual behavior — stealing and kidnapping as she likes.
- Kintoki gives that Shuten is an oni whose true nature is unknown; who came at some point to reside in the mountains of Ooe. (edited)
He doesn't know where she came from — only that her strength is such as to markedly outstrip the other oni.
Kintoki gives that it was several years ago that he first encountered her.
He gives that she's rather talkative, perhaps because she's always drunk.
Kintoki can't determine whether or not her words are as nonsense uttered of her intoxication.
She stated at some point that she was the child of some important god.
At their very first encounter, she addressed him as the Kaidoumaru of Ashigara — expressing pity that he was captured by the warriors of the Miyako. (edited)
She asked if he remembered her — even that in Kintoki's impression, it was the first that they'd met. (edited)
It wasn't the first that Kintoki had ever encountered an oni. He'd met a couple in the eastern country of Sagami (相模), in the mountains of Ashigara (足柄), where he grew up.
However, the oni he recalls meeting were not Shuten-Douji.
Strangely, however, he gives that there was a familiar feeling to her.
He gives that Shuten took note of the color of his hair and eyes; that on account that his arms, flowed with the blood of the Sekiryuu (赤龍, "crimson dragon"), "they should be hard to break."
He gives that he was since then acquainted with her — though in truth, it hasn't been long.
Even so, he gives that it's "enough," as losing an arm isn't something he wants to endure more than a single time.
Kintoki gives that oni will necessarily Invert (反転, hanten).
One moment, they're smiling, and the next, they're tearing somebody apart.
They'll destroy a mansion that they've praised as well-built, and crush a jewel that they've taken favor to and stolen.
It's on this account that he's so on guard against kidnapping.
Because, if the victim isn't quickly recovered, they'll eventually turn up dead. Kintoki is certain of it.
This, he gives, is what oni are. They'll tear apart that which they love, and express feelings to that which they intend to kill.
However, as of recent, he hasn't heard that they've eaten the people of the Miyako.
Even that there's talk of their consuming humans before settling in Ooe, as of present, there's nothing of the sort.
Kintoki gives that whereas he and Usui (碓井) have come to shed blood, he hasn't heard that girls or boys were kidnapped and so dismembered. (edited)
He wonders if it's on account that by the efforts of the warriors of the Genji, kidnapping victims have been saved in time; or —
He gives that even that the oni and the Genji truly shouldn't be as of a relation whereby they're "familiar with" one another, that's presently the state of their association. (edited)
- The party arrives at an impressive-looking gatehouse.
Danzou identifies it as the Rajoumon, situated as of the southern boundary of the Avenue of Suzaku.
Or rather, she gives, a gatehouse created in the image of such.
Here, they encounter Ibaraki.
Ibaraki: "... what business do you have here, child of Man?"
Kintoki greets her, giving that he hasn't any intention to fight. Rather, he asks her to look upon the state of the moon.
He gives that his objective is to reclaim the moon and the skies, and to so reclaim the peace of the Miyako.
He asks for her to lend her strength to his cause, in exchange for treasures, wine, and rice.
When Ibaraki asks what it is they want precisely, Guda clarifies that there's come a slayer of the Genji, and that on this account, they'd like her to lend her strength.
Ibaraki asks if they haven't come to subdue the oni.
Kintoki gives that that isn't the case. At that, Ibaraki asks if Raikou is present.
Kintoki answers that she isn't here.
Ibaraki: "What about Tsuna?"
Kintoki: "Not here. The ones here are us."
After hearing Kintoki out, Ibaraki refuses to help; asking if they thought they could return alive, foolishly venturing unto the domain of the oni — especially as Raikou and Tsuna are absent. (edited)
She calls for Hoshiguma-Douji (星熊童子) to attend her.
Kintoki gives again that he isn't here to fight, but Ibaraki seems not to be listening.
fallacies 11-Dec-20 11:53 PM
After combat:
After defeat, Ibaraki intends to call forth Kanekuma-Douji (金熊童子) and continue the fight, but Shuten approaches from behind and bops her in the head.
Instantly, she falls unconscious.
Danzou confirms that bother Hoshiguma and Ibaraki are suppressed; it appears that on account of a sneak attack from behind, Ibaraki has been rendered unconscious.
Kintoki gives that it looked to him only like a light bop, but maybe he was mistaken.
If it were Guda, Kintoki remarks, her head might've split open like a pomegranate fallen to the ground.
Initially making to converse, Shuten abruptly acts as if to attack Guda. After a quick exchange of blows, Shuten gives that she was just joking; that Kintoki's rather unfriendly, despite their long acquaintance.
As an indication of goodwill, she gives that she'll return the arm she claimed. She tosses something at the party.
It takes Guda a moment to realize that it's Danzou's arm.
Angered, Kintoki calls Shuten's name. At this, she asks what's with that face of his; she just slightly miscalculated her strength.
That besides, she says, the arm was cleanly removed.
Danzou gives that Shuten is indeed speaking the truth. Her arm hasn't been damaged; and by reattaching it, it's as good as new — she says, unsteadily rising to her feet.
Guda sees that she's downplaying the injury, and tells Danzou not to move; that she'll be applying a healing spell.
Guda activates her Mystic Code, restoring the damage. At this, Danzou thanks her and apologizes.
Kintoki seems to calm. Giving that Shuten must've heard his conversation with Ibaraki, he asks her her response to his request.
Without hesitation, Shuten gives that she'd be willing to lend a hand.
Danzou is surprised that she would be so quick to answer.
Guda and Danzou are taken aback that with the dangerous atmosphere a moment earlier, Shuten would somehow just agree. (edited)
Kintoki gives that it's fine that Guda doesn't attempt to comprehend Shuten's behavior. There isn't any meaning in delving into the matter.
This is just the way that oni are.
Kintoki reconfirms with Shuten that she'd be willing to lend a hand.
At this, Shuten gives that as Paracelsus is gone, and the Tenran something-or-other seems to be over, she has time to spare.
She laughs, asking when it was that she and Kintoki last fought alongside one another.
Kintoki gives that this is a first.
Shuten: "Ara, is that so?"
Kintoki warns her that the opponents are legitimately strong. (edited)
He didn't feel like he could win against the two of the Hasshoushin he's so far encountered.
Or rather, he hasn't won against any of the Hasshoushin so far. The first two were defeated by Tsuna and Raikou.
Shuten gives that it's a rare occasion that Kintoki would be anxious about a strong opponent.
Addressing Guda, Shuten gives that relatively, she appears to have a lot of guts.
Shuten gives that she appears to her to be on the boundary of adulthood; still merely a chick — a small kitten.
Guda replies that she isn't a child; though whether she's legally permitted to drink would depend on whether or not the Occidental Calendar is a thing.
Shuten: "Fufu. How cute. But all the small children would claim such a thing."
"I haven't the intent to criticize you, though? It's the reverse; the reverse. You see, I hold you to be quite worthy of praise."
"Admirable, even that you're still just a small child —"
"You've got guts."
"Tell me, why is it that you would engage such strong, frightful opponents?"
Guda: "In order to go home."
"In order to reclaim the World."
Shuten gives that she doesn't quite understand, but that what Guda's said amuses her.
She gives again that Guda is quite admirable, despite being still a child.
She thinks Guda quite the delicious morsel.
Danzou positions herself before Guda, asking Shuten to please not joke.
Shuten asks if Kintoki feels the same; if he would attempt to cut off her arms if she made an attempt against Guda.
Kintoki gives that she should be thankful that he doesn't just behead her.
The one she's threatening, he gives, is his companion. Even that he came to ask her for her assistance, he's through with negotiations if she kills Guda.
Shuten asks him the manner of opponent that would have him at his wit's end.
At this, Kintoki remarks that based on what Danzou earlier explained, Chaldea seems familiar with the true identity of Saikyoujin.
That being the case, he asks if Guda can elaborate on the matter in greater detail.
fallacies 12-Dec-20 02:02 AM
https://forums.spacebattles.com/threads/general-type-moon-discussion-thread-2-unlimited-titles-works-please-read-the-threadmarks.795493/post-72556518
General Type-Moon Discussion Thread 2: Unlimited Titles Works! (PLE...
hmm, how about an attack from a a rank strenght servant?
fallacies 12-Dec-20 01:51 PM
Chapter 12
"— I am Kagekiyo."
"— I am as vengeance."
"I am as 'we.'"
"I am not as one, but as a collective."
"I was from the point that I was acquired of form in the capacity of myself as Taira-no-Kagekiyo."
"Kagekiyo is not as a singular individiual."
"At the very least, thirty-seven Kagekiyo were extant, and so targeted Yoritomo (頼朝)."
"Even that a single Kagekiyo dies, Kagekiyo shall not die."
"Certainly shall the next Kagekiyo manifest — Cursing the Genji; against the Genji prosecuting a vengeance."
"With the passage of time did Kagekiyo become as legend ..."
"To I who was before long become as a Heroic Spirit engraved to the Throne, somebody said —"
"Kagekiyo is as a Concept that renders death unto the Genji."
"And thereon did I here arrive."
"Heian-Kyo. The matter (事象, jijou, "phenomena") which was by the Subspecies Tree of Fantasy being rendered unto the limits of distortion."
"The Concept borne of vengeance against the Genji — the Taira-no-Kagekiyo who existed in the capacity of a legend — took as its yorishiro (依り代; in the context of Shinto, a spiritual anchor) the Concept borne of vengeance against the Genji — the Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune who existed in the capacity of a legend."
"The vengeance obscured as of the depths of the Heroic Spirit Yoshitsune!"
"Ergo, the hatred unto her elder brother, Minamoto-no-Yoritomo!"
"This corpus / Yoshitsune layered of vengeance does indeed befit Kagekiyo."
"I (儂, washi) am as Kagekiyo; as Yoshitsune." "I (私, watashi) am as Yoshitsune; as Kagekiyo."
"The Genji must die."
"I shall this evening eradicate them."
"This Utsushiyo (現世, "manifest world") encircled by the Root of Fantasy (空想の根, kuusou no ne) — entirely distorted — hasn't a need for the Genji."
"Come —"
Kagekiyo approaches the bridge at Kamogawa.
Addressing "that which is distinct from I (儂, washi)," Kagekiyo gives that too much time has been wasted gazing at this bridge that Kagekiyo doesn't recall ever seeing. (edited)
Addressing Yoshitsune / Kagekiyo, she calls for her (self) to advance and conquer, alongside the Oo-Tsuchigumo, Kugamimi-no-Mikasa.
She gives that she's kept him waiting; that the time to again initiate their eradication now begins.
Narration: She remembers this bridge, even that Kagekiyo doesn't recall ever seeing it at all. (edited)
The corpus that is as Yoshitusune remembers, for this is the place at which her battles were begun.
"I shall not easily permit you to pass."
"If you desire to pass ... yes, that's right; hand over that sword at your waist."
... Benkei (弁慶).
"Ushiwaka, Ushiwaka."
"You shall certainly clear away your father's regrets. Alongside your elder brother, you shall destroy the House of Taira." (edited)
... Mother.
"Haha. Ushiwakamaru — your beauty is alike to a tokiwa (常磐, lit. "a stone forever unchanging"; an ever-unchanging existence; also, "evergreen")."
"You shall not die."
"I shall protect you, for you shall become as proof that the Genji have been defeated before the House of Taira."
... Taira-no-Kiyomori (平清盛).
"Splendid, splendid!"
"Even that you're borne of the flesh of a human, you've trained well, Shana-Ou (遮那王)."
"However, I (僕, boku) shan't condone that you steal a glimpse of my Rikutou Sanryaku (六韜三略)." (edited)
... Master.
As an explanation not included in the game, Rikutou (六韜) refers to Liù Tāo, or The Six Secret Teachings, a Chinese treatise on strategy. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Six_Secret_Teachings
Sanryaku (三略) refers to Sān Lüè, or Three Strategies of Huang Shigong, another Chinese treatise on strategy. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Three_Strategies_of_Huang_Shigong
"Don't forget your dreams, Kurou Hougan (九郎判官, "Magistrate Kurou")."
"The battle comes to an end once I'm defeated? Nay. The enemies of Yoritomo-dono aren't restricted to merely I and the Taira alone, yes?" (edited)
"You're next."
... Yoshinaka-dono (義仲殿).
This would be Minamoto-no-Yoshinaka, Tomoe-Gozen's husband.
2
"I'll follow you anywhere, Yoshitsune-sama."
"Until the very end, please keep me at your side."
... Shizuka (静).
This would refer to Shizuka-Gozen (静御前), Yoshitsune's mistress. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shizuka_Gozen
"Please entrust the protection of Chitosemaru-dono (千歳丸殿) to this humble monk." (edited)
"Before anything else, let us survive this predicament, Yoshitsune-sama!"
... Hitachibou (常陸坊).
This would refer to Hitachibou Kaison (常陸坊海尊), the man who later acted as Musashibou Benkei (武蔵坊弁慶).
Chitosemaru (千歳丸) is Yoshitsune's son by his first wife, Sato-Gozen (郷御前).
"Forgive me, Yoshitsune."
"I didn't know of your circumstances."
... Brother.
-
At the bridge at Kamogawa, Kintoki is present — quoting the lines that Benkei once spoke to Ushiwakamaru, and blocking her way. (edited)
Kagekiyo asks what he intends by speaking such strange words to her.
Addressing him as a man of the Genji, she gives that she is as Kagekiyo; that all manner of conversation is meaningless to her.
Addressing her as Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune, Kintoki asks her what she felt about his impression of Benkei.
Kagekiyo replies that she is as a slayer of the Genji, and therefore as Kagekiyo. She says that he knows nothing — and that she won't permit him to further speak of Benkei.
She gives that she'll acknowledge him for having the courage to draw breath before her eyes, but that all that remains is for his limbs to grow weak; for him to die.
Addressing her as a warrior born of the tomorrow that "we the Genji" have wrought; as Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune, a "descendant" who has born and died as of tomorrow, Kintoki gives that he's heard of her exploits — of her tragedy. (edited)
However, he gives that there's something he doesn't understand, about which he'd like to inquire with her directly.
Before he can ask his question, Kagekiyo tells him to shut up.
She reiterates that she is as Kagekiyo; that there isn't any meaning in addressing her by the name of her corpse.
Calling for Kugamimi-no-Mikasa, Kagekiyo gives that the eradication is begun.
Danzou arrives, telling Kintoki that it seems that conversation is at its limit.
She calls for him to shift to combat.
Arriving, Shuten gives that having heard that she'd be encountering "a poison unto the Genji," she wondered what she would be dealing with.
Shuten: "Heeeh. So it was such a contrivance, hm?"
The party engages Kagekiyo.
fallacies 12-Dec-20 04:04 PM
After combat:
Shuten sends a wave of sake at the Oo-Tsuchigumo.
Danzou observes that Shuten is skilled in strategy — drawing the Oo-Tsuchigumo away from Kintoki, and using her sake to neutralize the poison in the atmosphere. (So it was literally an Anti-Genji poison ... ?)
Privately, Danzou thinks that the sake that Shuten wields is distinct from that which comes of her Noble Phantasm in her capacity as a Heroic Spirit; but she's surprised that Shuten can even in life utilize in the capacity of her own strength the spirits of wine (酒精, shusei).
She notes that this is as a technique not spoken of in legend or folklore — wondering if it was perhaps something that Shuten acquired as of her time upon the Continent, which largely aren't covered in legend. (edited)
Addressing Kugamimi-no-Mikasa as "ojii-han" (お爺はん, "grandfather"), she gives that it's about time that he takes his rest.
Shuten: " Long, long ago, there dwelt as of the mountains of Ooe a great kai'i. Its name would be as the Oo-Tsuchigumo, Kugamimi-no-Mikasa —"
She gives that it's said that he was suppressed long before she ever arrived.
Shuten: "But Heroic Spirits are indeed quite curious, no? That which is dead comes as if to revivification."
"However, the mountains now belong to I alone. Therefore, you would do well to return unto Yomi (黄泉)."
The tsuchigumo roars.
Shuten: "Maa, maa. Please don't be so angered! It scares me so."
"And on account that I'm scared —"
"— pardon me if I tear you to pieces."
In an instant, Shuten's attack eliminates Kugamimi-no-Mikasa.
Danzou reports that the enemy's mana signature is quickly dissipating. She asks that Guda quickly deploy Seimei's ofuda.
Guda does so, sealing the Spritual Core of Kugamimi-no-Mikasa,
Danzou gives in surprise that Shuten was able to execute an attack of such speed as to exceed the grasp of her sensors, simultaneous to the release of her wave of sake. (edited)
Shuten gives that she's grasped the true nature of the "poison unto the Genji." It was specifically the miasma (瘴気, shouki) released by Kugamimi-no-Mikasa, which incorporated within it some manner of youjutsu (妖術; per 妖怪, youkai, arts of "you").
Hereforth, the warriors of the Genji shouldn't be disabled merely by the inhalation of the air.
Shuten gives that she leaves Kintoki to do as he likes.
Kintoki yet again repeats the lines spoken to Yoshitsune by Musashibou Benkei.
Kagekiyo asks him if he's still going on with that.
As he speaks, she tells him to stop.
But as he reaches the end of his quotes, she shouts for him to stop — addressing him as Benkei.
As she so speaks, her body begins to release energy — culminating in a shift in her attire.
Danzou gives that per an escalation in Kagekiyo's mana, she's confirmed a Saint Graph Ascension. She warns everyone to be careful.
Kagekiyo: "I (儂, washi) am; I (私, watashi) am ... !"
"This Yoshitsune / I (私, watashi) art ... ! Kagekiyo ... nay, nay, nay ... ! Nay!"
" I (私, watashi) would be as Kurou-Hougan Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune!"
"It is this corpse that be as what was once called as Shana-Ou (遮那王); as Ushiwaka!"
"Pretender of Benkei! What would one such as you know ... !"
"I (私, watashi) did ... !" (edited)
"Fight; and fight; and fight; and fight; and fight ... —" (edited)
"And at the end of a war without end, all that I came by was the blade and the fire."
"Not one of mine thoughts were communicated unto Aniue (兄上, "older brother"). The words assembled were one and all consumed unto fire."
"This hatred shan't be forgotten."
"Can such hatred be lost, even that I be reduced to a fragment of a soul?"
"Mine thoughts were betrayed, and mine path defiled — rendered unto naught!" (edited)
"My steps advance no longer unto light, and no longer is there any tomorrow!"
"Onore ..." (edited)
"Onore Yoritomo. Onore Hi no Moto ..."
"Onore Genjiiii!!"
"I certainly shan't forgive that somebody like you would dare to act a pretender to Benkei!"
"Let that this flesh be consumed with vengeance!"
Kintoki: "Come on, then, Kurou-Hougan! The one speaking to us ain't no Kagekiyo something-or-other!"
"It's you! Yoshitsune!"
fallacies 12-Dec-20 05:07 PM
After combat:
Kagekiyo is as yet undefeated.
Shuten asks Kintoki whether he intends on continuing with the charade of being Benkei.
She gives that Kintoki should be well aware that Kagekiyo is unto the very tips of her fingers a solid mass of poison unto the Genji, even that Kugamimi-no-Mikasa's absence lets that breathing is no longer a risk.
If Kintoki is to press on a little further, says Shuten, he's likely to die.
Kintoki is injured, but gives that he won't die — for at present, he's Benkei.
Benkei was a great warrior who could stand steadfast, even that his flesh was pierced with a hundred arrows.
Therefore, says Kintoki, he won't die.
As to why that is — it's on account that he hasn't yet gotten an answer for his question. (edited)
He calls out to Kagekiyo, again addressing her as "descendent-dono"; as Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune.
Kagekiyo: "And what would the Genji have to say to this Yoshitsune?"
"No, that isn't right. This Yoshitsune / I (私, watashi) have nothing to say to you the Genji."
"Therefore ... offer forth thy head."
"I desire the head of Yoritomo. Merely, merely, merely, Yoshitsune / I (私, watashi) desires the head of Yoritomo alone."
"If that cannot be obtained, then offer forth thy head."
"Thy head. Thy head. Thy head, which flows of blood that shall one day connect unto Yoritomo."
"Give forth thy head —"
"And if you cannot — well, then."
"I shall slay you."
"I hereforth prosecute the eradication of the forebears to the Seiwa Minamoto."
Guda: "Taira-no-Kagekiyo!"
"It would seem that you do indeed closely resemble the Heroic Spirit that I'm acquainted with."
Kagekiyo: "... what?"
Shuten warns Guda not to approach Kagekiyo.
She gives that it's fine that Guda stands on the sidelines and support Kintoki with spells; but that if she approaches, she's likely to lose her head. (edited)
Kintoki: "A head, huh?"
"Yo, descendant-dono! Or rather, Kurou-Hougan Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune! Is it becoming of a warrior of the Eastern Countries to repeatedly demand heads?"
"In that case, you'll have one! Shumenosuke Sakata-no-Kintoki (主馬佑坂田金時) offers forth his own head to ask of you a question!"
Kagekiyo: "Hou?"
Kintoki: "Oh, you're looking over here. I see that you do desire my head quite a bit."
"Good, good. You can have my head when you've won — but before that, I'll have you answer my question."
"There's something that I'd like to know no matter what."
"Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune. Ushiwakamaru."
"O descendant-dono born of tomorrow, already deceased — again, I ask of you."
"— why is it that you fight?"
Kagekiyo: "— ?"
Kintoki: "Why do you kill? Why do you take?"
"It ain't just talk of a matter of survival, yeah? Or at the very least, that shouldn't be the case for you." (edited)
"Guda, from a thousand years hence, would to the point of calling forth Heroic Spirits continue to fight, and fight, and fight. She's an existence that would fight it out all the way to the very ends of tragedy. There should be a reason for that."
"Why is it that you strive? Being the Hero that you are."
Kagekiyo: "Hero ... ?"
Kintoki: "Indeed."
"You became a Hero. It's on that account that I wanted to ask this of you."
"For what reason do you slay a hundred; slaughter a thousand?"
"At the outcome of it all, what's the justification? I ask this of you, who in the midst of battle arrived as of the standing of a Hero."
"Why do you fight?"
Kagekiyo is silent for a moment.
Kagekiyo: "... why. Why, do you ask ..."
"A Hero, did you say?"
Danzou reports that in the course of Kintoki's questioning, Kagekiyo's presence has shifted in nature.
What now manifests is distinct from her nature as an incarnation of vengeance.
She poses that it's a temporary expression of personality — of that which exists as this corpse layered with Curses, perhaps alike to the circumstance with Tawara Touta and Suzuka-Gozen.
Danzou: "Even that she's rendered as a corpse ... tormented by Curses, it yet remains. As a Heroic Spirit — a Hero engraved upon the Human Order, her dignity (矜持, kyouji)!"
Kagekiyo smiles. Kagekiyo: "I'm astounded, Sakata-no-Kintoki." (edited)
"That borne of power so far in excess the domain of men (人の域, hito no iki), you who would nevertheless stand alongside men would be unaware of such a thing. Fufu." (edited)
"Inconceivable, you what would be as a Kaidou (怪童, "monstrous / bizarre child"). Ashigara-Yama-no-Kintarou."
Kintoki: "... this is the second time that I've been called that."
Kagekiyo: "Why do I fight? Absurd."
"All are alike; all are equal."
"Therefore — it's as to carry to permeation one's own will; to devote to this the entirety of mine being."
"Know that it is in this that I pride myself a warrior of the Genji."
Kintoki seems for a moment taken aback, but he quickly recovers.
Kintoki: "I concur!" (edited)
"I'll take it to mean that a battle of warriors is as a competition of wills!"
"Will, hm? I see. So it's a matter of will."
"If that be the case, it seems that the you of present are sorely lacking! This is my victory! I've won!"
Kagekiyo: "Fufu. Draw thy weapon!"
fallacies 12-Dec-20 06:27 PM
"O you who are borne of strength." "Who for the sake of thy dream do thirst; do strive; do claw against the soil."​ "Therefore, conquer." "Therefore, kill."​ "If you seek to realize your wish, there is aside from forcing your way through by the strength that you bear no other path."​ "This would be as the battlefield of blood; the Limbo (辺獄, hengoku) what consumes Heroic Spirits succumbed to defeat."​ "— that what over the black sun presides, called as the Tenran Shiai Butai (天覧死合舞台, "the stage of the deathmatch presided over by the Skies")."​ "The inami (忌名, lit. "taboo name") of mine corpse be as Minamoto-no-Yoshitsune (源義経)!" "The inami (忌名, lit. "taboo name") of mine soul be as Saikyoujin (歳刑神), Taira-no-Kagekiyo (平景清)!" Mine vengeance, which I cry — this shall hereby bring thy path to closure."​ "Laugh, O Kijin (鬼神, lit. "oni god"). Shine, O Daystar."​ "Come — for the sake of thy own tomorrow."​ "— let that I here witness thy strength."​

fallacies 12-Dec-20 06:49 PM
After combat:
Kagekiyo and Kintoki continue to exchange blows.
Danzou looks on, observing that for some reason — they look as if they're enjoying the match, even that they're on the boundary of death. (edited)
Shuten comments that it's almost as if the boy were reverted back to the way he once was.
Shuten: "Indeed, as he was back then —"
"In such a manner —"
"His own life. His own flesh. His own bones."
"Clashing as if the end of days weren't to come —"
"— never ceasing, except perhaps in death."
Looking upon the battle, Danzou gives that Kintoki has just by a slight margin pushed brought things into his favor. (edited)
Kintoki: "I'm pushing my way through!"
"Daishou (大将, "chief / leader")! Help me out!"
Guda: "By this Command Seal!"
"To our battle, I pledge!"
"— unto victory!"
Kintoki: "Hissatsu (必殺, lit. "certain kill")!"
Kagekiyo: "Noble Phantasm, Release. 「All Things Must Come to Pass (諸行無常, shogyou mujou); the Prosperous Must Necessarily Fall (盛者必衰, jyouja hissui)」 —!" (edited)
The second part of this True Name Release is a line from the Humane King Sutra. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humane_King_Sutra (edited)
The first part of this True Name Release is one amongst the three premises included amongst the Dharmamudrā. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dharmamudr%C4%81
In the aftermath of the clash, Kagekiyo laughs.
She praises Kintoki for a battle well fought.
The miasma spilled forth by Kugamimi-no-Mikasa was in fact a thing borrowed from her. Her very existence is as the font of the poison unto the Genji. She is as an Avenger — a being who cannot but prosecute the eradication of the Genji.
Her attacks; her exhalation; her line of sight are all as to render the slaughter of the Genji.
But even that Kintoki should've known as such from the moment they crossed weapons, he persisted in battle unwavering.
Kagekiyo: "To so advance; to be so absent of conceit."
"It is as I would expect one who contributed to the foundations of we the Genji. Splendidly done."
"That being the case ..."
"I know not the extent to which my words hold meaning, but ..."
"... Kintoki. One amongst the Four Heavenly Kings of Yorimitsu — O Sakata-no-Kintoki-dono."

"If these lives of ours ..."
"If they be interlinked beyond the end of this deathmatch ..."
"Advance onwards as you will." (edited)
"Already, your path is of your own footsteps ..." (edited)
"... run forth."
"Even that you become as I — a corpse consumed with vengeance — shake it off."
"It's fine that you merely run forth; that you devote to this the entirety of your being."
"Without hesitation, merely advance; merely run."
"By such alone, you'll certainly ..."
"You'll certain accomplish much. You'll certainly overcome."
"Even that it's presumptuous of me, this I guarantee."
"— that is all. These are my words. Don't forget your dreams."
At the bridge at Kamogawa, Kintoki comes to.
After releasing his lightning slash, his consciousness started to become hazy, and all he could think was that if this went on, he was certain to die.
Guda gives that he's won; that the Saint Graph of Saikyoujin, Taira-no-Kagekiyo is entirely vanquished.
Kintoki: "... I see."
Danzou gives that if Seimei's ofuda is deployed, it should prevent Kagekiyo's soul from being absorbed by the Hell-Realm Mandala. (edited)
Kintoki gives that as he's been inundated with the poison unto the Genji, he doesn't think he has long to live.
Therefore, he says, being as he's never learned of poetry, he asks that you recite something in his place.
Guda refuses, giving that that isn't necessary.
Kintoki gives that that isn't very Golden of her. Being as he battled Yoshitsune with all that he had, at the very least, he wants to offer her a proper seeing-off. (edited)

Guda tells him not to keep saying that he's going to die.
Shuten calls him an idiot, and tells him that he's not going to die.
Danzou affirms this, giving that his vitals indicate no threat to his life — even as he's bleeding; even as he suffered multiple bone fractures and ruptured organs. (edited)
It would seem that his natural healing has kicked in, she says. She gives that it's as one might expects of a child of the Sekiryuu (赤龍, "crimson dragon").
Kintoki is surprised, asking aloud if he won't die.
Guda: "You won't die."
"Therefore, you should advance as you are."

fallacies 13-Dec-20 03:03 PM
Chapter 13
Simultaneously, at the Ooe-Yama Oni Goden (大江山鬼御殿, "palace of the oni at Mount Ooe") —
At the newly constructed Oni-Goden Rajoumon (鬼御殿羅城門), a bizarre scene unfolded.
Oni were under normal circumstances disinclined to gather in bands.
Being as oni, which were comprised of organisms (生物種, seibutsu-shu; generally, "species") of aberrant form (異形, ikei), did typically exceed the strictures of ecological context (生態, seitai, "ecological habitat / ecosystem"), they generally did form unto packs. and were for the most part solitary.
In more recent times, the numerous oni which per the draw of "oni nobility" what was as Shuten-Douji had come to aggregate as of the Ooe no Oyama (大江の御山) were amongst the few exceptions to this.
Subsequent the army of oni once suppressed by the great shogun Tamuramaro, the oni of Ooe were said to be an exception among exceptions.
And present, these oni ...
Ibaraki: "Wh-, what's this ... ?"
"Why would you lot ... stand here in array, alike to the warriors of men ... ?" (edited)
"... why ..."
Before the Oni-Goden Rajoumon —
More than several dozen oni had abruptly gathered, standing in array as to embark upon a march.
What had such a phenomenon brought to manifestation was verily — loyalty!
Expressed of this band of oni was, impossibly, an overwhelming loyalty — unlikely to come to inspiration even on account of uncommon nobility of Shuten-Douji! (edited)
As proof of this, they had come to march.
Ibaraki: "Aah ..."
"Aa, aaaaa ... aaaaa ..."
"This shouldn't be ... this manner of ..."
"This manner of thing shouldn't ... !"
"You lot- Nay, we oni shouldn't be as such ... !"
"Shuten ... Shuten ..."
"Aa, aa ... aaaa ... aaa ... !"
"... who is it!?"
"Who are you, what could so easily impose order unto we the oni who are firmly set in our disobedience!?" (edited)
"— who are you!?"
— as of the Palace of the oni of Ooe, the 5th of the Shoushin (将神, "god-general") had manifested.
Something, which had in an instant grasped to her command the band of oni; which marched now upon the Kyo-no-Miyako.
A brilliant existence, which stood beneath the crimson Moon.
That what surfaced a gentle smile; what commanded the fearsome oni.
With a single gesture; with a single call —
A strength to which all should submit was brought to hand; to swirl —
Resistance was impermissible. Refusal was denied.
Even Ibaraki-Douji — successor to the Makoku (魔国, "country of ma") what should return; who had upon her back shouldered the flame as to act in the capacity of a chieftain of the oni — couldn't but bow her head. (edited)
Such was this brilliance. Such was the standing of this existence.
That what was alike to the skies — upwards to which all the living raise their eyes. (edited)
In short —
— that was as a God.
fallacies 13-Dec-20 07:44 PM
Next arrow:
Several dozen odd warriors of the Genji were gathered upon the Avenue of Suzaku.
These were the last among the combat-capable forces within the Miyako, hastily assembled. At their lead were the acting head of the Genji, Minamoto-no-Yorimitsu; and of her Four Heavenly Kings, Tsuna and Kintoki.
This was as a combat formation as to confront the oncoming threat.
And the threat here spoken of would be —
That what had easily broken through the Bounded Field placed as of the western boundary of the Miyako — the regiment of oni that presently marked along the Nijou-Ooji (二条大路, "second avenue"), toward the Avenue of Suzaku.
Per the strategy devised by Abe-no-Seimei, who had foreseen a harsh battle, the warriors of the Genji were deployed in formation as of the Avenue of Suzaku.
At present, the brigade of oni hadn't yet arrived as of the Avenue —
-
Raikou orders that her men should brace themselves, as the oni are coming.
She gives that it's a circumstance beyond her comprehension as well.
She's heard before that Ibaraki-Douji acts as a chieftain to the oni of Ooe, but as of present, the Genji have with Shuten-Douji entered into a temporary alliance; a pact of mutual non-aggression . (edited)
fallacies 13-Dec-20 08:16 PM
But Shuten-Douji is amongst the oni the one regarded most proximate to those the oni extol as creatures of Makoku — even that she royality in all but name, an unsurmountable kariki ranshin (怪力乱神, lit. "bizarreness / monstrosities, strength, chaos, gods"; in Confucianism, a list of the influences that can throw and ordered society to disarray; but maybe used here literally to mean "a chaotic god of monstrous strength?").
But at present, irrelevant of such a reality, the oni have nevertheless descended from their mountain and advanced upon the Miyako. (edited)
Raikou gives that the situation is incomprehensible. (edited)
fallacies 13-Dec-20 08:27 PM
Taking this as praise, Shuten gives that she can only offer wine in reciprocation; or perhaps some peaches.
Raikou seems uneasy at the offer, and gives that she doesn't any peaches or so forth.
Shuten asks if she dislikes them, even though they're so sweet and tasty.
She asks Kintoki his opinion. To this, Kintoki gives that he does indeed like peaches. (edited)
Raikou seems hurt by this for some reason, and Nursery Rhyme silently consoles her by patting her on the back.
Danzou here announces that the 5th of the Shoushin presently arrives from Ooe, per Abe-no-Seimei's predictions.
Guda voices her confusion as well, giving that their party visited Ooe only a few hours prior, and didn't get the sense that the oni there intended to march upon the Miyako.
Kintoki here observes that whereas the first two of the Shosshin approached from the south, within the bounds of the Miyako, before the Rajoumon; the second two manifested in the east, at the end of Gojou-Ooji, just beyond Kamogawa. (edited)
But this time around, the enemy is coming all the way from Ooe, about a hundred kilometers in the northwest.
Even that Limbo appears to be operating under certain restrictions, isn't that a bit too far away?
Tsuna gives that the Grand Bounded Field erected by Abe-no-Seimei along the four sides of the Miyako is as an existence intended as to obstruct the incursion of potent kai'i.
The present circumstances, he gives, can be taken as evidence that the Bounded Field does in fact act in response to the strength of the Shoushin.
If it's a Shoushin of potent strength, they are at some efficacy obstructed from directly manifesting within the bounds of the Miyako; from simply appearing as of the Gates of Suzaku.
Danzou posits that perhaps the bounded field responds to standing of Mystery; or if not, it may be as a multilayered Bounded Field that reacts to mana capacity.
She gives that it's as she would expect of Abe-no-Seimei — a spell protocol of frightful potency, perhaps in excess of the holy relics that remain of ascetics that enacted miraculous works. (edited)
fallacies 13-Dec-20 09:00 PM
Alternatively, she gives, perhaps this Bounded Field makes use of the Śarīra (仏舎利, busshari; pearl-like beads that are found in the ashes of high Buddhist clerics; translated in Sekiro as "shelter stones") of a Buddha of Bodhisattva. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%9Aar%C4%ABra
Guda gives, per the above explanation, that perhaps the opponent this time around is potent indeed.
Kintoki gives that thanks to Medea, his and Danzou's wounds are healed; and that Tsuna and Raikou are ready for combat. Even that this time, they can't rely on numbers, Minamoto-no-Yorimitsu and her Four Heavenly Kings are as ikki-tousen (一騎当千, lit. "a single unit matches a thousand").
Whatever the scale of the opposition the oni have assembled, Kintoki believes that the Genji won't fall behind them.
fallacies 13-Dec-20 09:12 PM
Shuten makes a bit of small talk with Kintoki, but Raikou gives that they should shut their mouths. The oni have arrived. (edited)
Danzou reports that the brigade of oni are in sight. Further, she's confirmed amidst them things alike to shikigami in the form of corpses.
The enemy signatures number in the hundreds.
Medea calls for Tsuna to look upon the figure that walks at the forefront. (edited)
Reinforcing her vision, Danzou confirms that it's Ibaraki.
Guda asks why that would be, given that Shuten is here with the Genji.
Danzou gives that she isn't certain as to how things stand with the other oni, but that at the very least, Ibaraki is strongly loyal to Shuten. Even that the oni have gathered as an army, at the very least, Ibaraki alone shouldn't have been amongst them. (edited)
Ibaraki: "Shuten."
"I'm sorry. I'm sorry."
"I don't comprehend it."
"Because, it's almost as of that ..."
"Her eyes are alike Shuten's, and because I gazed at them, I ... I ..."
"A, aaa ... aaaaaaaaaa —"
"Shuten, Shuten ... !"
"Shuten!!!!"
Flames are released from Ibaraki's body, as if as some manner of signal to the assembled oni. (edited)
Danzou gives that it looks as of Ibaraki-Douji has succumbed to some manner of mental disarray. (edited)
The greater oni (大鬼, ooki) and the corpselike shikigami are advancing.
Raikou calls for her forces to engage.
fallacies 13-Dec-20 09:36 PM
After combat: (edited)
Raikou: "Well, then. Of the lynchpin of the enemy forces, what remains is —"
Ibaraki: "Haa, haa, haa ... ! I am ... I am ... !"
"Incapable except to pursue your deaths ... That lady ..." (edited)
"If she so desires, then ... !"
"Does it matter if this flesh of mine be cut to pieces!? For, I am — I am, incapable of existing except in the capacity of an oni!"
Tsuna: "Ibaraki. Have you forgotten?"
"Your arm was claimed by me. Are you so willing to die that you'd set that aside as well?"
Ibaraki: "Tsuna ... !"
"I-, I ... I am ... you'll ... ! But ... I cannot but do as such; as such, as such!"
"It's as if I cannot hear the words spoken from my own heart!"
Shuten appears behind Ibaraki.
Shuten: "Dummy."
She does something to Ibaraki.
Ibaraki: "... that, hurt."
"Shuten ... Th- this is ... You've planted my legs into the ground ..."
Shuten: "Naa, Ibaraki? It seems that you have the wrong idea."
"Even that you'd to the oni of Ooe as a chieftain or something-or-other — that you should assemble everyone and lead them down the mountain ..."
"When was it that I told you to do that?"
"It's praiseworthy that you'd be able to rouse Kanekuma and the bears, but what precisely are you doing?"
"If you so wish to play, I cannot but answer your call, yes?"
"Naa — Ibaraki."
Ibaraki: "Shuten ... ! Aah, Shuten, Shuten, Shuten, Shuten, Shuten!"
"I ... ! I saw! I saw her!"
"She's there even now!"
"Even now, even now, even now, even now ..." (edited)
"Aaa ... ! I; I cannot overcome my fear!"
Shuten: "— ?"
Guda detects something.
Guda: "There's an invisible accumulation of mana! There's some manner of resemblance to a Grail, but this is!"
Danzou reports that a vast amount of mana is accumulating in the space ahead.
Medea: "A summoning ... ?"
"N-, no! This would be the annulment of some Heroic Spirit's astralization!" (edited)
"But under normal circumstances, it shouldn't result in anything along the lines of a spatial distortion! Even so!"
Danzou: "Mana escalating; mana escalating ... nay ..."
"The quantity of mana can't be evaluated!"
"It's of such a level as to be comparable to the extraordinary standing of the Kings of the Apocryphal Belts / Lostbelts!"
Kintoki: "What's with that ... ?"
"There's something over there ..."
"There's something I don't like about this ... no ..." (edited)
"Even that there shouldn't be anything there, a form ... is gradually manifesting ... !"
Shuten: "That's ... —"
Kintoki: "Is it — Shuten?"
- Manifestation —
There, she manifested.
Though she bore a form closely alike to a human, a human she was not. (edited)
Though she was as a supernatural existence closely alike to an oni, an oni she was not. (edited)
She was as Nature / a God. (edited)
She was as a Concept / a God.
Distinct from the countless lives borne of corpus, psyche, and spirit, she was as a manifestation of that what births; nurtures; and steals away — a manifestation of the World / a God.
— a God / phenomenon of the antiquity was here present.
Ancient God: "Fu. Fu. Fu."
"Well have you grown."
"Well have you prospered."
"Borne of the knowledge of this and that, to think that you would do such a thing — to furnish me with standing amongst the Shoushin as the Taisaijin (太歳神)." (edited)
"Fu. Fu. Fu."
"I haven't a need for it. I haven't a need for such a thing."
"I was, from very beginning ..." (edited)
"As a God."
"Hear mine name, lives that subsist as of Utsushiyo (現世, "the manifest world"; in Shinto, the realm of mortals)." (edited)
"Witness mine form, lives that sleep as of Tokoyo (常世, "the eternal world"; in Shinto, the realm of Gods)." (edited)
"Mine name be as Ibuki (伊吹). Ibuki-no-Douji (伊吹の童子) —"
"— the Dragon / God of Calamity."
"— both mountain / God and water / God; both soil / God and steel / God."
"— both skies / God and storm / God; that what is both as fire / God and war / God."
"Therefore."
"I be as the Yamata-no-Orochi (八岐大蛇) —"
"It is I who would of the eight branches (八岐, yaki) be as a fragment / the first of mitama (御霊) / head separated forth."
"I am as the calamity descended from the mountains."
"To put it in words that you lot would more easily comprehend — indeed."
"I would be as a calamity to all of you what are borne of life."
Raikou: "A mitama separated forth from the Yamata-no-Orochi ..."
"Put in such a manner, that would be as."
Danzou: "Ya- — Yamata-no-Orochi!!!"
"This is ... this is ... ! I apologize ... this circumstance is entirely beyond the calculation of Danzou's cerebral domain (頭脳領域, zunou ryouiki) ... !"
"The Dragon of Calamity (災害竜, saigai-ryuu), Yamata-no-Orochi!"
"The great keshou (大化生, oo-keshou), also worshiped and called as the Daimyoujin (大明神) of Ibuki!"
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/My%C5%8Djin
"That what is called as the greatest Dragon of Calamity in all Hi no Moto! One amongst the Three Great Keshou (三大化生, sandai keshou)!" (edited)
"Written of in the Kojiki (古事記, "Records of Ancient Matters") and the Nihon Shoki (日本書紀, "Chronicles of Japan") as a great and savage snake god, it is as of present time as an existence held as a Daimyoujin!"
"As of Chaldea, its classification per the taxonomy of the Phantasmal Species (幻想種, gensou-shu) would be as Dragonkind! Simultaneously, in the capacity of a manifestation of Nature, it is as one amongst the malevolent Gods (荒ぶる神々, araburu kamigami)!"
"Ibuki-Douji would be as a miko (御子, "child" held in reverence) ..."
"A singular being (個体, kotai, lit. "individual body") said to be as manner of bunrei (分霊) ..."
"Ergo, that there oni would be as!"
"The Divine Spirit (神霊, shinrei), Ibuki-Douji!"
Guda: "Ibuki-Douji —"
Danzou: "As of Chaldea's database, this would be as a childhood name of the Heroic Spirit Shuten Douji ..."
"Though she was predicted to be as a different aspect (別側面, betsu-sokumen), or alternatively, an existence in the capacity of a Heroic Spirit or Divine Spirit what expresses a divergent possibility ..."
"Certainly not ... something that would be to such an extent ..."
"The valuation of the instantiated mana is ever beyond measure!"
"She stands as of the same domain as the Gods of Grecia come of the 5th Apocryphal Belt / Lostbelt!"

3
Shuten: "... heh, so it was to such an extent."
Ibuki: "Fu. Fu. Fufu."
"Don't make such a clamor. Don't make such a clamor." (edited)
"Don't open your mouths. Open your eyes, that they shall certainly not be closed."
"Look up to me as to the skies / God."
"Kiss me as you might the soil / God."
"... fu. Fu. Aah, that can't be simultaneously done, can it?"
"In that case."
"Prostrate thyself."
A pressure descends on all gathered on the scene.
Raikou is shocked at the bizarre weight imposed upon her body.
Guda: "I've experienced such a thing once before!"
"Certainly, it would be proximate to that asserted by the Great God Zeus ... !" (edited)

4
Kintoki asks of Shuten what it means that this Ibuki could be some other aspect of her.
For whatever reason, the pressure seems not to be acting upon Shuten.
Shuten replies that as the marionette says, that's also herself.
Even that she doesn't look the part, she's a child of the God of the mountains of Ibuki.
That over there — alike to a mist (靄, moya), in Shuten's words — would be something alike to another of her faces.
Shuten: "Isn't that the case, Ibuki-no?" (edited)
"But now,"
"it's my"
"turn, no?"
Energy is released from Shuten's body.
Danzou finds that she's able to stand, and reports that the escalated gravitational force rendered by way of Ibuki's high density mana has been neutralized. She wonders aloud if this would be the effect of some magecraft cast by Shuten.
Shuten: "Stand, warriors!"
"Or do you intend to sleep there in leisure?"
"If that be the case, you must no longer have a need for this Miyako, naa?"
"If I be as a substitute to you warriors, what sort of expression would your ancestors bear, looking upon you from on high? Naa —"
"Chief of the Genji!"
Lightning descends.
Raikou: "... I comprehend your words, but I won't forgive it if you further speak."
"Tsuna! Kintoki!"
Raikou gives that irrelevant of the manner of threat that the Miyako faces, it's the role of the Genji to suppress it.
Kintoki and Tsuna assent, readying themselves for combat.
Guda: "Readying for Anti-Divine-Spirit combat!"
Danzou: "— Acknowledged! Ready to commit my mana supply as my Saint Graph and Spiritual Core permit!"
Kintoki: "You won't be crossing past the Gates of Suzaku! Maybe you've just only awakened, but here! We'll have you fall again slumber, Divine Spirit, Ibuki-Douji!"
Raikou smiles.
Raikou: "Advance, Genji! Advance, Genji!"
"— hereforth, we slay a God! All men, prepare for combat!"
Ibuki laughs. There's a pulse, and her body grows.
Danzou reports that the hostile Divine Spirit has escalated its Saint Graph from just shy of 2 meters to a scale of over 3 meters. (edited)
The party enters combat.

fallacies 14-Dec-20 01:21 AM
However, nothing communicates unto Ibuki, on account of the defensive Bounded Fields that inherently envelop her flesh; that Ibuki expresses as a dispensation by her birth.
This strength that Ibuki brings to bear; this sense of presence she exudes — it's as if the party is picking a fight with Nature itself.

Ibuki: "Lives."
"Transient beings."
"Devote thyself."

Shuten delivers a surprise attack from behind Ibuki, tearing through her Bounded Field and piercing to her flesh. (edited)
Danzou confirms that direct damage has been dealt to Ibuki's Saint Graph, penetrating deep within.
Danzou gives that to begin with, Ibuki was as an alternate aspect of Shuten. Even that their forms differ, they stem from the same root (大本, oomoto) / original.
There's bloodshed, and a fleshy noise. (edited)

Ibuki: "Amusing."
She reasserts the pressure from before.
Narration:
With just a single word.
By this one word was induced once more a gravitational burden come of ultra-high density mana — rendering that all the oni and the humans present were incapable of movement.
By this was Shuten-Douji likewise afflicted, even that she bore to this menacing Divine Spirit a common root and derivation.
Comparative to the weight from earlier, what here manifested was heavier still. (edited)
In this place —
The only one that as yet stood upright was the Divine Spirit Ibuki-Douji alone.
All others were prostrated upon the soil, with their heads bowed.
Before the true ruler of the land, all those what were borne of life were helpless, except so as to look upon her acts.
